ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 34-1-34-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICES 

Sec. 34-31. - Consent for inclusion of city by county. 
(a)  Findings. It is ascertained, determined and declared that: 
(1)  The board of county commissioners of Hernando County, Florida, has enacted ordinances authorizing the county to create or identify a municipal service taxing or benefit unit or other specific geographic area within which the county imposes and collects uniform assessments for advanced life support and transport services, hereafter referred to as emergency medical services, within incorporated and unincorporated areas of the county. 
(2)  The city council has determined that the inclusion of the incorporated area of the city within such municipal service benefit or taxing unit or other specific geographic area by the county for the purpose of providing emergency medical service is in the best interests of the owners of property within the corporate limits of the city. 
(b)  Consent of city. The city council consents to the inclusion of all of the incorporated area of the city within an identified municipal service taxing or benefit unit or specific geographic area created or identified by the county to provide emergency medical services, facilities and programs and to the imposition of a special assessment by the county to fund such services, facilities and programs; however, such consent shall automatically be revoked for a municipal service taxing unit if the millage levied therefore exceeds 0.6. Such consent shall become effective upon adoption of the ordinance from which this section is derived for the upcoming fiscal year. The city council finds that the provision of emergency medical services is an essential municipal purpose. 
(c)  Annual renewal of consent. Consent of the city council given to the county by this section shall be deemed given in advance for each fiscal year hereafter and shall be automatically renewed for each succeeding fiscal year unless such consent is subsequently withdrawn as provided in this section. Consent shall be irrevocable for any fiscal year in which the subject emergency medical services assessments are levied by the county within the incorporated area. The city council may only withdraw such consent for any subsequent fiscal year by adopting an ordinance abandoning its consent and providing a certified copy of such ordinance to the county prior to May 1 preceding the fiscal year for which consent is being withdrawn. 
(Ord. No. 640, §§ 1-3, 6-17-2002) 
Secs. 34-32-34-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - FIRE AND BURGLAR ALARM SYSTEMS 

Sec. 34-61. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alarm systems means any mechanical, electrical or radio-controlled device that is designed to be used for the detection of any unauthorized entry or fire in a building, structure or facility or for alerting others of the commission of an unlawful act within a building, structure or facility, or both, which emits a sound or transmits a signal or message when activated. Alarm systems include, but are not limited to, direct-dial telephone devices, audible alarms and proprietor alarms. Excluded from the definition of alarm systems are devices which are designed or used to register alarms that are audible, visible or perceptible in or from any motor vehicle or auxiliary devices installed by telephone companies to protect telephone systems from damage or disruption of service. 
    Automatic dialing device means an alarm system which automatically sends over regular telephone lines, by direct connection, or otherwise, a prerecorded voice message or coded signal indicating the existence of the emergency situation that the alarm system is designed to detect, but shall not include such telephone exclusively dedicated to an alarm system which are permanently active and terminate within the communication center of the city police department and that of any other law enforcement agency. 
    City means the incorporated limits of the city as they are or as the same may be established hereafter, as well as other areas under contract with the city for fire protection. 
    Commercial premises means any structure or area which is not defined in this section as residential premises. 
    Enforcement officer means the chief of police of the city or his designated representative. 
    False alarm means the activation of an alarm system through mechanical failure, malfunction, improper installation, or the negligent or intentional misuse by the owner or lessee of an alarm system or by his employees, servants or agents; or any other activation of the alarm system not caused by a forced entry or attempted forced entry, robbery or attempted robbery or by fire; such terminology does not include alarms caused by acts of nature such as hurricanes, tornadoes, other severe weather conditions, or alarms caused by telephone line trouble, external power failure, or other conditions which are clearly beyond the control of the alarm user. 
    Fee means an assessment of costs imposed pursuant to this article to defray the expense of responding to a false alarm. 
    Residential premises means any structure or combination of structures which serve as dwelling units including single-family as well as multifamily units. 
(Code 1988, § 10-101) 
Sec. 34-62. - Notification. 
    Every person who shall own, operate or lease any alarm system within the city whether existing or to be installed in the future, shall notify the law enforcement officer, on forms to be provided, of: 
(1)  The type, make, model of the alarm system. 
(2)  Whether installed in a residential or commercial premises. 
(3)  The name, address, business or home telephone number of no less than two persons to be notified in the event of an alarm activation. 
(Code 1988, § 10-102) 
Sec. 34-63. - Response to false alarm; required reports; corrective action, penalties and disconnection. 
(a)  For the purpose of this article, responsibility for a false alarm shall be borne by the owner or lessee of the alarm system or his employees, servant or agent occupying or controlling the premises at the time of the occurrence of the false alarm. 
(b)  A response to a false alarm shall result when any police/fire department personnel are dispatched to or otherwise learn of the activation of any alarm system. 
(c)  The following shall be required of each person who owns, operates, leases or controls any premises, commercial or residential, having an alarm system, for each incident of a response to a false alarm: 
(1)  First through third false alarm. The occupant of the premises or, if it is unoccupied, the owner of the premises, shall, within ten days after the response to the false alarm, file a written report, in forms provided by the police department, whichever responds to the alarm, setting forth cause of such false alarm and the corrective action taken. 
(2)  Fourth and succeeding false alarm response. For each response to a false alarm occurring or within six months after such third response within six months of the preceding response, the occupant of the premises or, if it is unoccupied, the owner 
of the premises will be assessed a fine as set by the city council and shall be required to take corrective action. 
(3)  Audible alarms. In instances where alarms are audible outside the premises, it shall be considered an additional false alarm for each hour that such alarm remains audible after telephone notification to the occupant or owner by the fire or police departments enforcement officer. 
(d)  If such fourth false alarm or any succeeding false alarm results from the failure to take necessary corrective action, the enforcement officer may order disconnection of such alarm system, provided that no disconnection of such alarm system shall be ordered when the premises or facility is required by law to have an alarm system in operation. An order of disconnection shall be rescinded by the enforcement officer upon presentation of evidence of corrective action, subsequent inspection and finding by the enforcement officer that adequate corrective action has been taken. 
(Code 1988, § 10-103) 
Sec. 34-64. - Requirement to respond to premises when alarm activated. 
    Every person who owns, operates or leases an alarm system and who shall knowingly or purposefully fail to respond by appearing at his premises or facility after notification by the enforcement officer of the activation of any alarm system, whether false or not, within one hour of notification shall be deemed in violation of this article. 
(Code 1988, § 10-104) 
Sec. 34-65. - Automatic dialing devices. 
    It shall be a violation of this article for any person to install, maintain, own, possess or operate any automatic dialing device alarm system regulated or programmed to make connection with any telephone number installed in any law enforcement facility or fire department, except to such telephone number determined and designated by the enforcement officer. In addition thereto, the enforcement officer may establish a reasonable fee to defray the installation and recurring charge for such special telephone equipment, to be paid by persons who shall program any automatic dialing device to the telephone number mentioned in this section. 
(Code 1988, § 10-105) 
Sec. 34-66. - Right to a hearing. 
    Upon request of the person assessed a fee or ordered to disconnect an alarm, a hearing may be held with the enforcement officer to review such assessment or order to disconnect. Such request must be made within 15 days of receipt of the notice of assessment or order to disconnect. Evidence and testimony in opposition to such assessment or order to disconnect may be presented at the hearing. 
(Code 1988, § 10-106) 
Sec. 34-67. - Penalty. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly fail to comply with the provisions of this article, or to fail to pay any fee assessed hereunder, and upon conviction of any such violation, the offending person may be punished as provided by section 1-7. 
(Code 1988, § 10-107) 
Sec. 34-68. - Disposition of fees. 
    Fees collected by the enforcement officer pursuant to section 34-63(c)(2) or when ordered by the court upon conviction shall be paid into the general fund of the city. 
(Code 1988, § 10-108) 
Secs. 34-69-34-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - EMERGENCY SERVICES COST RECOVERY ORDINANCE 

Sec. 34-91. - Purpose and title. 
(a)  The foregoing recitals (Whereas clauses) are hereby adopted as the legislative findings of the City Council of the City of Brooksville and incorporated into this article as if set forth in haec verba. 
(b)  The purpose of this article is to establish regulations to implement fees for calls or responses by emergency services to include police, fire, and emergency medical services. This part shall be known and may be cited as the "City of Brooksville Emergency Services Cost Recovery Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 766, §§ 1, 15, 10-6-2008; Ord. No. 766B, § 1, 8-17-2009) 
Sec. 34-92. - Definitions. 
    Emergency medical service response means the deployment by the City of Brooksville of any emergency medical equipment and/or personnel from a central or remote location to a specific location within the City of Brooksville, where the equipment and/or personnel provide protection or other emergency response services. 
    Emergency services means the services provided by the City of Brooksville fire department, police department or emergency medical services as defined in fire department emergency response, police response, and emergency medical services response. 
    Emergency services charges and fees means those charges and fees as set out and identified in the emergency services cost recovery schedule. 
    Emergency services cost recovery schedule means a schedule of charges and fees for certain fire, emergency medical services (EMS) and police services provided in response to particular incidents. 
    Fire department emergency response means the deployment by the City of Brooksville of any fire equipment and/or personnel from a central or remote location to a specific location within the City of Brooksville, where the equipment and/or personnel provide protection or other emergency response services. 
    First responder means a law enforcement officer as defined in F.S. § 943.10, a firefighter as defined in F.S. § 663.30, or an emergency medical technician or paramedic as defined in F.S. § 401.23, including volunteer personnel, who are employed by the state or local government; as may be subsequently amended. 
    Hazardous materials incident means an incident involving hazardous materials as defined in the International Fire Code and Florida Statute, as they may be amended from time to time. 
    Police response means the deployment by the City of Brooksville of any police equipment and/or personnel from a central or remote location to a specific location within the City of Brooksville, where the equipment and/or personnel provide protection or other emergency response services. 
    Structure fire means any fire in, on or about a commercial or residential structure, which threatens to or actually damages or destroys the structure. 
    Vehicle incident means any incident involving a motor vehicle which threatens to or actually damages or destroys the motor vehicle; or threatens to or actually injures passengers in a motor vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 766, §§ 2, 15, 10-6-2008; Ord. No. 766B, § 2, 8-17-2009) 
Sec. 34-93. - Authorization. 
    The city is hereby authorized to implement charges and fees for emergency service calls or responses, including police, fire, emergency medical service (EMS) and certain public works responses, provided within the city. These charges and fees may be established at usual, customary and reasonable rates for certain and specific types of incidents or equipment, apparatus, or materials used, or for actual costs incurred by the responding emergency service department. The city may amend such charges and fees from time to time with the council's approval. The city is authorized to promulgate such rules or regulations as are necessary and reasonable to carry out the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 766, §§ 3, 15, 10-6-2008; Ord. No. 766B, § 3, 8-17-2009) 
Sec. 34-94. - Liability for emergency service costs. 
    The city shall have the authority to bill both private persons and entities, including insurance companies that provide insurance coverage to said private persons and entities, for the reasonable costs that are related to the use, loss, damage, and wear and tear to said apparatus, tools, equipment, and materials necessary to provide the fire services and 911 response rendered to said persons and entities, subject to the conditions and limitations of this article. 
(1)  In the event that there is an emergency response by the fire department, the police department or by the EMS department for (i) a fire; (ii) a medical emergency incident and/or (iii) a hazardous materials incident, and the owner of the effected property or other insured party has insurance coverage for the payment of such fees under an insurance policy, said owner or other party shall pay to the city a fee not to exceed the actual cost of the response. 
(2)  Under no circumstance will either the city or its authorized agent bill federal entitlement programs such as Medicare and Medicaid which do not provide coverage for such incidents. 
(3)  Residential property incidents. A notice outlining emergency services charges and fees shall be sent to the residential property owner indicating that a claim shall be filed. An additional notice shall be sent to the residential property owner indicating whether or not the claim shall be paid by the insurance carrier. 
(4)  Commercial property incidents. Commercially operated or zoned property shall not be eligible for any exemption from the emergency services charges and fees. Commercial property owners shall respond freely and cooperatively to inquiries regarding their insurance coverage. Commercial property owners shall be notified at the time a claim is filed, and at the time a claim is paid. Commercial property owners shall be invoiced directly under the terms of this article if they do not carry insurance sufficient to cover the impact to the City of Brooksville's loss of capital or material. 
(5)  Chemical or hazardous materials response fees. The costs incurred by the City of Brooksville Fire, Police, EMS and Public Works departments for emergency response to a chemical hazardous materials spill or leak will be billed for actual operational costs including but not limited to equipment, supplies and manpower; except that, with respect to motor vehicle incidents, only those costs to contain or clean up hazardous materials in quantities reportable to the Florida State Warning Point at the division of emergency management will be billed. 
(6)  Multiple property protection. When a particular emergency service rendered by the city directly benefits more than one person or property, the owner of the property so benefited and each person so benefited where property protection is not involved shall be liable for the payment of the full emergency services charge or fee. The interpretation and application of these provisions are delegated to the city manager subject only to appeal, within the time limits for payment, to the city council and shall be administered so that charges shall only be collected from the recipients of the service. 
(Ord. No. 766, §§ 4, 15, 10-6-2008; Ord. No. 766-A, §§ 1, 5, 11-3-2008; Ord. No. 766B, § 4, 8-17-2009) 
Sec. 34-95. - Emergency services cost recovery schedule. 
    Charges and fees for certain emergency services shall be set forth in the City of Brooksville Emergency Services Cost Recovery Schedule. This schedule is developed, using national standards and generally accepted methods, by the appropriate departments, submitted to the city manager and provided to the city council for review, discussion and approval. Upon resolution by the city council, the emergency services cost recovery schedule will be published to the public. 
(Ord. No. 766, §§ 5, 15, 10-6-2008; Ord. No. 766B, § 5, 8-17-2009) 
Sec. 34-96. - Invoicing and collection. 
    The city, or its authorized agent, subject to the conditions and limitations of this article, shall submit an invoice to the person, entity or relevant insurance company for applicable emergency services charges and fees for the emergency services rendered. 
(1)  If it can be reliably determined that there is no insurance coverage for a particular emergency incident which causes the City of Brooksville to use, or incur loss, damage, and wear and tear to apparatus, tools, equipment, and materials; the city may recover any such fees from the person or entity that received said emergency services or the person or entity responsible for the debts and obligations of the person or entity that received such emergency services, again subject to the conditions and limitations provided herein. 
(2)  Third party billing service. The city is authorized, if it so deems necessary, to undertake the engagement of a third-party billing and revenue recovery contract with a professional services company, referred to herein as an "authorized agent," qualified to bill and recover the charges and fees and with an established valid reputation in recovering such charges. The appropriate emergency service department administration shall utilize applicable incident report information provided to the authorized agent as the basis for the charge and recovery of the emergency services charges and fees for each incident where the city authorizes such billing. 
(3)  Time for payment. In each case, the emergency services charges and fees provided for in this article shall be billed by the City of Brooksville, or its authorized agent, within 30 days of the date service is rendered and paid in full to the City of Brooksville no later than 60 days of the date the invoiced is issued. 
(4)  Delinquency of payment. If not paid within that period, then such fee shall be deemed delinquent. If full payment of a emergency services charge or fee is not made within the provisions of subsection (c) time for payment, the delinquent fee shall become a lien on such real estate or vehicle to which the emergency service call was made as of the date of such delinquency and shall automatically be extended upon the current or next tax roll as a delinquent tax against the property. All proceedings in relation to the collection, return, and sale of property for delinquent real estate taxes shall apply to such delinquent emergency services charges and fees. 
(Ord. No. 766, §§ 6, 15, 10-6-2008; Ord. No. 766B, § 6, 8-17-2009) 
Sec. 34-97. - Exemptions and fee waiver. 
    Except as otherwise provided herein, emergency services charges and fees will not be assessed for costs or expenses incurred for services provided by a first responder in response to motor vehicle accidents. Emergency services charges and fees will not be assessed for responses to city property, or for services provided or performed outside the jurisdiction of the city under a mutual aid contract with another municipality. The city manager, depending upon circumstances, maintains the authority to waive charges or fees if unusual or unforeseen circumstances are found to exist or if a hardship is determined. An unforeseen circumstance could include but not be limited to a lightning strike, power failure or surge, arson, etc. 
(Ord. No. 766, §§ 7, 15, 10-6-2008; Ord. No. 766B, § 7, 8-17-2009) 
Sec. 34-98. - Dispute resolution and hardship claims. 
(a)  Billing or invoicing disputes. Invoicing for charges and fees shall become final after 30 days from issuance. An owner may dispute the charges and fees as invoiced by submitting a written request to the city within 30 days of issuance of the invoice. The request to review charges and fees will be reviewed by the appropriate department (e.g., if disputing a fire service fee, it is to be reviewed by the fire chief; if disputing a EMS fee, it is to be reviewed by the fire chief; if disputing a police fee, it is to be reviewed by the police chief). Decisions of the department director concerning billing adjustments shall be completed within 30 days of receipt of the request for review unless unusual or unforeseen circumstances exist. The appropriate department director has the authority to amend the billing with the approval of the city manager. The city manager's decision to either grant or deny billing adjustments is final. 
(b)  Hardship claims. An owner may request a waiver of charges and fees where paying such charges and fees would be a hardship. Such hardship claims must be submitted in writing to the city manager within 30 days of issuance of the invoice. Decisions of the city manager concerning the granting of a hardship waiver shall be completed within 30 days of receipt of the request for review unless unusual or unforeseen circumstances exist. The city manager's decision to either grant or deny the hardship waiver is final. 
(Ord. No. 766, §§ 8, 15, 10-6-2008; Ord. No. 766B, § 8, 8-17-2009) 
Sec. 34-99. - Penalty. 
    A penalty of ten percent of the emergency services charges and fees applicable to each incident shall be added for the failure to pay the installment within the timeframes established in this article. Such delinquent fees and penalties may be, at the discretion of the city council, recovered through civil action filed in the courts of this state and county. In such case the city council is authorized to recover its court costs and fees, if any, including attorney's fees. The city shall have any and all other remedies afforded by the Florida Statutes. 
(Ord. No. 766, §§ 9, 15, 10-6-2008; Ord. No. 766B, § 9, 8-17-2009) 
Sec. 34-100. - Use of revenue collected. 
    Charges and fees collected, under the provisions of this article, shall be deposited in a separate fund established for cost recovery revenue and shall be used to defray the costs of continuance, maintenance, enhancement or improvement of emergency services within the city. Such funds shall be allocated, during the budget process, to departments providing emergency service response, including police, fire, EMS, and other departments responding to cost recovery incidents. 
(Ord. No. 766, §§ 19, 15, 10-6-2008; Ord. No. 766-A, §§ 1, 5, 11-3-2008; Ord. No. 766B, § 10, 8-17-2009) 
Sec. 34-101. - Annual reporting. 
    Each year this article is in effect, the appropriate department director for the various emergency services shall prepare a summary report of the emergency services charges and fees collected as per this article and shall submit it to the city manager. The city manager shall forward the report to the city council. 
(Ord. No. 766, §§ 11, 15, 10-6-2008; Ord. No. 766B, § 11, 8-17-2009) 
Sec. 34-102. - Non exclusive funding. 
    The emergency services charges and fees shall not be exclusive of any other funding mechanisms that may be used by the city to fund the cost and expenses of providing emergency services, but shall only be supplemental thereof. Funding may additionally be collected by the city through general taxation or by a special assessment established under other ordinances. General fund appropriations may also be made to cover such additional cost and expenses. 
(Ord. No. 766, §§ 12, 15, 10-6-2008; Ord. No. 766B, § 12, 8-17-2009) 
Secs. 34-103-34-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - DECLARATION OF A STATE OF LOCAL EMERGENCY 

Sec. 34-111. - Purpose and intent of ordinance. 
    It is the intent of the city to designate a city official to declare a state of local emergency in conjunction with Hernando County Emergency Management Comprehensive Emergency Management Plan (CEMP) as currently adopted and updated in accordance with F.S. ch. 252, in the event of a natural, technological or manmade disaster or emergency, or the imminent threat thereof, and to authorize certain actions relating thereto when a quorum of the city council is unable to meet. 
(Ord. No. 827, § 1, 6-4-2012) 
Sec. 34-112. - Designation of certain city officials with authority to declare a state of local emergency. 
    Pursuant to F.S. ch. 252, which authorizes the waiver of procedures and formalities otherwise required of political subdivisions to take whatever prudent action is necessary to ensure the health, safety and welfare of the community in the event of a state of emergency, when a quorum of the city council is unable to meet, the mayor of the city council, or the vice mayor in his absence, or the senior council member in succession, in the absence of the mayor and vice mayor, is hereby designated and empowered to declare a state of local emergency whenever he or she shall determine that a natural, manmade disaster, technological or emergency has occurred or that the occurrence or threat of one is imminent and requires immediate and expeditious action. 
(Ord. No. 827, § 2, 6-4-2012) 
Sec. 34-113. - Definition of "emergency". 
    As defined in F.S. ch. 252.34(3), "Emergency" means any occurrence, or threat thereof, whether natural, technological, or manmade, in war or in peace, which results or may result in substantial injury or harm to the population or substantial damage to or loss of property. 
(Ord. No. 827, § 3, 6-4-2012) 
Sec. 34-114. - Length of time authorized for a declared state of local emergency and provisions for extension and/or termination of declared emergency. 
    A state of local emergency shall be declared by proclamation by the city official designated in section 34-104 herein for a period of time up to seven days, which may be extended as necessary in seven day increments by subsequent proclamation, pursuant to F.S. ch. 252.38(3)(a)5. The state of local emergency shall continue until terminated by proclamation by the designated city official when he finds that the threat or danger no longer exists and/or until an emergency meeting of a quorum of the city council can take place to terminate the state of local emergency. 
(Ord. No. 827, § 4, 6-4-2012) 
Sec. 34-115. - Activation of disaster emergency plans. 
    A declaration of a state of local emergency shall activate the disaster emergency plans applicable to the City of Brooksville as described in Hernando County's CEMP and shall be the authority for emergency measures such as evacuation orders and declaration of certain areas as being off limits, as well as authorize the use or distribution of any supplies, equipment, materials, and facilities assembled or arranged to be made available pursuant to such plans. 
(Ord. No. 827, § 5, 6-4-2012) 
Sec. 34-116. - Imposition of certain emergency measures or regulations. 
    Upon the declaration of a state of local emergency pursuant to this article, emergency measures may be imposed by proclamation by the city official designated in section 34-104, or duly approved and adopted by city council when available pursuant to Brooksville City Charter or Code to protect the life, health, property, welfare, or public peace of the community. The purpose of this article is to provide authority and enforcement power as adopted and updated in F.S. ch. 252. 
(Ord. No. 827, § 6, 6-4-2012) 
Sec. 34-117. - Disclaimer of limitation of authority. 
    Nothing in this article shall be construed to limit the authority of the city council to declare or terminate a state of local emergency and take any action authorized under F.S. ch. 252 when sitting in regular or special session. 
(Ord. No. 827, § 7, 6-4-2012) 
Sec. 34-118. - Penalties. 
    Any person, firm or corporation who refuses to comply with or violates any section of this article, or the emergency measures or regulations which may be made effective pursuant to this article, shall be punished according to law and upon conviction for such offense, shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $500.00 or by imprisonment not to exceed 60 days in the county jail, or both. Each day of continued non-compliance or violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
    Nothing herein contained shall prevent the city from taking such other lawful action in any court of competent jurisdiction as is necessary to prevent or remedy any refusal to comply with, or violation of, this article or the emergency measures or regulations which may be made effective pursuant to this article. Such other lawful action shall include, but shall not be limited to, an equitable action for injunctive relief or an action at law for damages. 
(Ord. No. 827, § 8, 6-4-2012) 
Secs. 34-119-34-125. - Reserved.

ARTICLE II. - JUNKED, WRECKED, ABANDONED, LOST, SEIZED PROPERTY[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Seized, abandoned, wrecked or derelict property, F.S. § 705.01 et seq.; supplementary procedure for abandoned personal property of nominal salvage value, notice to remove, seizure and destruction, F.S. § 705.16; title to property found in public places, F.S. § 715.01 et seq.; reporting of unclaimed motor vehicles, F.S. § 715.05; vehicles parked on private property, towing procedure, F.S. § 715.07; disposition of property held by city for owner, F.S. § 717.10. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 38-31-38-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ABANDONED OR JUNK PROPERTY[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 765, § 2, adopted Oct. 6, 2008, amended the former Div. 2, §§ 38-51-38-65, and enacted a new Div. 2 as set out herein. The former Div. 2 pertained to abandoned property on public property and derived from Code 1988, §§ 9-1-9-15, 9-17; Ord. No. 639, § 1, adopted June 3, 2002. 

Sec. 38-51. - Purpose. 
    The purpose and intent of this article is to protect the public health, safety and welfare, and to protect the aesthetic and property values of properties by providing for abatement of unsanitary and unsafe conditions, including the accumulation of junk and abandoned property on public or private property or waterways. 
(Ord. No. 765, § 2, 10-6-2008) 
Sec. 38-52. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. 
    Abandoned property means all tangible personal property that does not have an identifiable owner and that has been disposed of on public property in a wrecked, inoperative or partially dismantled condition or has no apparent intrinsic value to the rightful owner. (Vessels determined to be derelict by the Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission or a county or municipality in accordance with the provisions of F.S. § 823.11 are included within this definition. 
    Appliance means furniture, refrigerators, washing machines and dryers, water heaters, microwaves, and other similar household goods and fixtures. 
    Enforcement officer means employees of the county or municipality whose duty it is to ensure code compliance or enforce codes and ordinances, including police officers. 
    Inoperable vehicle means any vehicle which remains for a period of 30 days in such condition that it cannot be started or moved under its own power or in its normal and usual manner without repair; or the automobile which is more than 20 years old which is undergoing active repair or restoration for display, use or sale as an antique. 
    Junk means any litter, debris, waste materials of any kind, dead or decaying vegetation or vegetative refuse, dead animals, used or unserviceable automobile and machinery parts, used and nonfunctional furniture and appliances, dilapidated mobile homes in an uninhabitable condition, and used and nonfunctional tools, equipment and implements but shall not include compost piles for normal personal, noncommercial use. 
    Junkyard means any lawfully maintained and operated enterprise in the business of handling, selling or storing junk. 
    Litter means garbage, rubbish, trash, refuse, sludge from a waste treatment facility, water supply treatment plant or air pollution control facility, or any of the following which is discarded, used up, inoperable or destroyed: can, bottle, container, paper, tobacco product, tire, appliance, mechanical equipment or part, building or construction material, tool, machinery, wood, motor vehicle or motor vehicle part, vessel, aircraft, farm machinery or equipment, or substance in any form resulting from domestic, industrial, commercial, mining, agricultural, or governmental operations. 
    Lost property means all tangible personal property which does not have an identifiable owner and which has been mislaid on public property, upon a public conveyance, on premises used at the time for business purposes, or in parks, places of amusement, public recreation areas, or other places open to the public in substantially operable functioning condition or which has an apparent intrinsic value to the rightful owner. 
    Notice of code violation means a citation issued for violation of this article or any other city code provision. 
    Owner means the person or entity identified by the license or registration agency as the registered owner of the vehicle, such term shall also means a lessee of a vehicle pursuant to a lease of six months or more; or the person or entity identified as the owner of title as recorded in the public record. 
    Person means individuals, firms, associations, joint ventures, partnerships, estates, trusts, business trusts, syndicates, fiduciaries, corporations, governmental entities, and all other groups or combinations of the foregoing. 
    Personal property means all goods, chattels, and other articles of value capable of manual possession and whose chief value is intrinsic to the article itself. 
    Police officer means any person who is elected, appointed, or employed full-time by the city; who is vested with authority to bear arms, and make arrests; and whose primary responsibility is the prevention and detection of crime or the enforcement of the penal, criminal, traffic or highway laws of the state. This definition includes all certified supervisory and command personnel of the police department, but does not include support personnel employed by the city police department. 
    Public property means lands and improvements owned by the federal government, the state, the county, or a municipality and includes sovereignty submerged lands located adjacent to the county or municipality, buildings, grounds, parks, playgrounds, streets, sidewalks, parkways, rights-of-way and other similar property. 
    Unlicensed vehicle means any vehicle required to be licensed by the state if used on public streets or waterways which is unlicensed for a period of 30 days or more. 
    Vehicle means every device capable of being moved upon a public highway or public waterway and in, upon or by which any person or property may be transported or drawn upon a public highway or public waterway, including any watercraft, boat, ship, vessel, barge or other floating craft. 
(Ord. No. 765, § 2, 10-6-2008) 
Sec. 38-53. - Derelict, unattended and abandoned vehicles and personal property. 
(a)  No person shall abandon or leave unattended any vehicle, appliance or any other personal property on any public street or private or public property or waterway, for such time and under such circumstance as to cause the vehicle or other personal property to reasonably appear to have been abandoned. Any unclaimed vehicle, appliance or other unclaimed personal property left unattended for more than 72 hours without the approval of the city or, if located on private property, the owner of said private property, shall be deemed abandoned. The city's code enforcement department shall document the time of original inspection of the abandoned vehicle and shall follow proper notification procedures, including but not limited to the placement of a conspicuous label on the vehicle in question warning of its prospective impoundment. The city shall take all necessary and proper care in removing and impounding vehicles deemed "abandoned". Nothing in this section shall be construed to limit a property owner's right to due process. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for the owner or occupant of any land to cause, permit or have stored on such land any unlicensed or inoperable vehicle, appliance or other personal property except as provided herein. 
(c)  Exemptions. Nothing in this division shall be construed to apply to: 
(1)  Inoperable vehicles stored on the premises of a lawfully established and maintained junkyard, vehicle repair business, garbage or waste disposal site or sanitary landfill; 
(2)  Any vehicle, appliance or other personal property stored within a completely enclosed building; 
(3)  Unlicensed vehicles, appliance or other personal property stored on the premises of a lawfully established and maintained business that sells or repairs such vehicles, appliances or other personal property. 
(4)  Any vehicle, appliance or other personal property stored on the premises of a business enterprise being operated in a lawful place and manner, which vehicle, appliance or other personal property is necessary to the operation of such business enterprise. 
(Ord. No. 765, § 2, 10-6-2008) 
Sec. 38-54. - Authority to seize, impound or remove abandoned property. 
(a)  Whenever an enforcement officer ascertains that any vehicle, appliance or other personal property is on public property, in violation of this division, then: 
(1)  If the vehicle, appliance or other personal property is of such nature that it can be easily removed, the enforcement officer shall take the property into custody and shall make a reasonable attempt to ascertain the rightful owner or lien holder pursuant to other provisions of this division; 
(2)  If the vehicle, appliance or other personal property is of such nature that it cannot be easily removed, the officer shall cause a notice to be placed upon such vehicle, appliance or other personal property in accordance with section 38-57; or 
(3)  If the vehicle, appliance or other personal property is of such nature that it constitutes a traffic or other public hazard, the enforcement officer is hereby authorized and empowered to take and remove the property, without notice, to protect the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the community. 
(b)  When a vehicle, appliance or other personal property is deemed to be in violation of this division and the enforcement officer places a written notice as required, such notice will indicate that the item must be removed within five calendar days or it will be subject to removal by the city. 
(1)  If no appeal, as provided for in section 38-57, is made and the vehicle, appliance or other personal property remains in violation of this division after the five calendar day period, an enforcement officer is authorized and empowered to take and remove the property to a storage facility, approved by the city manager, and thereafter disposed of in accordance with applicable sections of this article, other ordinances and state law. 
(2)  If an appeal, as provided for in section 38-57, is made and the vehicle, appliance or other personal property remains in violation of this division after three calendar days after receipt of a decision, an enforcement officer is authorized and empowered to take up and remove the property to a storage facility, approved by the city manager, and thereafter dispose of in accordance with applicable sections of this article, other ordinances and state law. 
(Ord. No. 765, § 2, 10-6-2008) 
Sec. 38-55. - Immunity of enforcement officer and other city representatives from prosecution. 
    The enforcement officer and any other authorized representative of the city shall be immune from prosecution, civil or criminal, for ordering or performing reasonable good faith trespass upon real property while in discharge of duties imposed in this division. 
(Ord. No. 765, § 2, 10-6-2008) 
Sec. 38-56. - Notice to owner; owner liability. 
(a)  Any enforcement officer of the city shall cause to be placed a notice either on a vehicle, appliance, or other personal property or on the property where the item is in violation of this division, and five calendar days shall be allowed from the posting of such notice for the owner of the vehicle, appliance or other personal property to either cause it to be removed or to appeal the removal requirement to the city manager, which time shall be stated in the notice. 
(1)  In addition to posting notice on the vehicle, vessel, trailer, appliance or other personal property, the enforcement officer shall make reasonable effort to ascertain the name and address of the owner of any vehicle or other licensed or registered personal property determined to be in violation of this division, and if such name and address are reasonably available to the enforcement officer, the officer shall provide by certified mail, return receipt requested, a copy of the notice specified in section 38-57 to the owner, as designated on the most recent tax rolls, of any private real property on which such article or vehicle is located. 
(2)  If the property is a motor vehicle defined in F.S. § 320.01(1) or a vessel as defined in F.S. § 327.02, the police department shall contact the department of highway safety and motor vehicles in order to determine the name and address of the owner and any person who has filed a lien on the vehicle or vessel as provided in F.S. § 319.27(2) or (3) or F.S. § 328.15(1). On receipt of this information, the enforcement officer shall mail a copy of the notice by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the owner and to the lien holder, if any. 
(b)  If a vehicle, appliance or other personal property was seized, impounded, or removed under subsections 38-54(a)(1) or (a)(3), following such an impoundment or removal, the enforcement officer shall make reasonable efforts to determine who the owner of the vehicle, appliance or other personal property is and provide notice of the impoundment to the owner by certified mail, return receipt requested, or personal delivery. 
(c)  Notices provided under this section shall also notify the owner of a five calendar day period, from the date of the notice, to appeal the determination of the violation or the impoundment to the city manager or his designee, in the same manner as an appeal under subsection 38-57(b). 
(Ord. No. 765, § 2, 10-6-2008) 
Sec. 38-57. - Form of notice; appeal; time extensions. 
(a)  Form of notice. Whenever the enforcement officer shall ascertain a violation of this division has occurred he or she shall cause a notice to be securely placed upon such vehicles, vessels, trailers, appliances or other personal property in substantially the following form: 
NOTICE OF VIOLATION TO THE OWNER 
AND ALL PERSONS INTERESTED 
IN THE ATTACHED PROPERTY 
This property, to wit: (setting forth brief description of the property) is unlawfully upon public or private property known as (setting forth brief description of location) and must be removed within five calendar days from date of this notice, otherwise it will be presumed to be abandoned property and will be removed and disposed of by order of the City Council of the City of Brooksville, Florida. The owner will be liable for the costs of removal, storage, and publication of notice. 
You may, within said five-day period, appeal the determination of a violation to the city manager, by initiating an appeal on a form to be provided by the city manager(s office and delivering the signed appeal form to the city manager at Brooksville City Hall, 201 Howell Avenue, Brooksville, Florida. 
Code section: (setting forth the code section being violated). 
Dated this: (setting forth the date of posting of notice). 
Signed: (setting forth name, title, address, and telephone number of enforcement officer). 
(b)  Appeals. Within the five calendar day period provided for removal of any vehicle, appliance or other personal property, the owner of such vehicle or personal property, or the owner of the property upon which such vehicle, appliance or other personal property is alleged to be unlawfully located, may appeal the notice of violation to the city manager. 
(1)  The city manager shall provide forms for such appeals requiring the signature, address and telephone number of the person filing the appeal, the reasons such person claims to not be in violation of the code section cited in the notice of violation, and other pertinent information. 
(2)  Such a form must be completed, signed and filed with the city manager at city hall within the five calendar day period. 
(3)  The city manager or his designee shall decide such appeal within five working days after it is filed. A written decision shall be delivered to the address designated in the appeal form, either by personal delivery or by certified mail, return receipt requested. 
(4)  The vehicles, appliances or other personal property identified in the notice of violation must be removed within three calendar days after receipt of a decision of the city manager denying the appeal. 
(c)  Extensions of time. For good cause shown, the city manager, or any enforcement official issuing a notice of violation, may, but need not, extend the time for removing any vehicle, appliance or other personal property unlawfully located on any property in the city. 
(Ord. No. 765, § 2, 10-6-2008) 
Sec. 38-58. - Storage and disposal of seized or impounded property; custodian designated; receipts; records. 
(a)  The chief of police is designated as and shall be ex officio the custodian of all abandoned, lost, captured, impounded or stolen property. It shall be the duty of all officers or employees of the city into whose hands, custody or control any such abandoned, lost, captured, impounded or stolen property shall come to deliver the same to the custodian who shall receive the same and shall execute in triplicate receipts which shall be dated. One copy shall be attached to the article. It shall be the duty of the custodian to safely keep or store the property until disposed of as provided in this division. 
(b)  The police department and public works department shall keep and maintain adequate safes, storage rooms, garages, or warehouses where the vehicles and other personal property seized, impounded or removed under this division shall be stored and kept in accordance with this section. 
(1)  The rates of storage or cost of keeping property, impounded under this division, per day or fraction thereof shall be based upon a scheduled adopted by the city council by resolution, except that no storage fee shall be charged if the vehicle, appliance or other personal property is stored less than six hours. 
(2)  The cost of towing any such property to a place of storage shall be added to the foregoing, the rate thereof to be that specified in the contract between the city and the company contracting for towing service on the date service is rendered, or in the absence of any such contract it shall be the actual cost of such towing. 
(c)  Any vehicle which is deemed abandoned, and which is deemed to have a value in excess of $100.00 shall be retained in storage for a period of 90 days after notice has been sent certified mail, return receipt requested, to the owner and lien holder of record. Any vehicle or vessel which remains unclaimed after 90 days may be disposed of by public sale. 
(d)  Any vehicle which is deemed abandoned, and which is deemed to have a value of less than $100.00 shall be retained in storage for a period of 45 days after notice has been sent certified mail, return receipt requested, to the owner and lien holder of record. Any vehicle which remains unclaimed after 45 days, and upon determination that such vehicle or vessel is not reported stolen, may be disposed of by the custodian or his duly authorized representative by any means determined to be in the best interest of the city, including without enumeration, giving said property away, junking said property with a salvage yard, or depositing same in an authorized waste disposal facility. 
(e)  Any personal property other than vehicles deemed to be abandoned which remains unclaimed for a period of 30 days after taking possession of the property by the city, may be disposed of by the custodian or his duly authorized representative by any means determined to be in the best interest of the city, including without enumeration, giving said property away, junking said property with a salvage yard, or depositing same in an authorized waste disposal facility. 
(f)  If not disposed of by public sale, the custodian shall maintain an inventory of said property, a record of the date and disposal including any consideration received for the property, if any, and the name and address of the person taking possession of the property. Such inventory shall be kept as a public record for a period not less than two years from the date of the disposal of the property. 
(Ord. No. 765, § 2, 10-6-2008) 
Sec. 38-59. - Redeeming impounded property; failure to claim. 
(a)  All abandoned, lost, captured or stolen property shall be held by the custodian as required by state law during which time it shall be his duty to deliver the same to the rightful owner thereof upon demand and satisfactory proof of ownership, if of lawful character and not directed to be destroyed. 
(b)  The rightful owner shall be liable for the costs for transportation and storage or abandoned property, and for cost of publication of notice of disposition. Before delivery to such rightful owner, the owner shall pay to such custodian the storage or cost of keeping charges as prescribed in this division and any other fines or penalties as provided by city ordinance. If the rightful owner does not pay such costs within 30 days of making claim to the property, title to the property shall vest in the city. 
(c)  Each vehicle, appliance or other impounded personal property not reclaimed by its rightful owner or lien holder may be sold or otherwise disposed of in accordance with this division and applicable state laws. 
(Ord. No. 765, § 2, 10-6-2008) 
Sec. 38-60. - Notice of disposition, sale or disposal of impounded property. 
(a)  The custodian may elect to: (1) retain any or all the property for its own use or for use by the local government, (2) trade such property to another unit of local government or state agency, (3) donate the property to a charitable organization, (4) sell the property, (5) notify the appropriate removal service, or (6) surrender such property to the finder, The custodian shall give notice of such election. 
(1)  If the value of the property is more than $100.00, notice shall be made by an advertisement published once a week for two consecutive weeks in a newspaper of general circulation in the county where the property was found. The notice must describe the property in a manner reasonably adequate to permit the rightful owner of the property to claim it. 
(2)  If the value of the property is $100.00 or less, notice shall be given by posting a description of the property. The notice must be posted for not less than two consecutive weeks in a public place designated by the custodian. The notice must describe the property in a manner reasonably adequate to permit the rightful owner of the property to claim it. 
(Ord. No. 765, § 2, 10-6-2008) 
Sec. 38-61. - Notice of sale to be published. 
    If the custodian elects to sell the property, he or she must do so at public sale by competitive bidding. 
(1)  Notice of the time and place of the sale shall be given by an advertisement of the sale published once a week for two consecutive weeks in a newspaper of general circulation in the county where the sale is to be held. 
(2)  The notice shall include a statement that the sale shall be subject to any and all liens, except the city's lien for storage. 
(3)  The sale must be held at the nearest suitable place to that where the lost or abandoned property was held or stored. This requirement does not preclude the use of web-based sales as long as the notice indicates internet sale as the method of sale. 
(4)  The advertisement must include a description of the goods and the time and place of the sale. 
(5)  The sale may take place no earlier than ten days after the final publication. If there is no newspaper of general circulation in the county where the sale is to be held, the advertisement shall be posted at the door of the courthouse and at three other public places in the county at least ten days prior to sale. 
(6)  Notice of the custodian's intended disposition shall describe the property in a manner reasonably adequate to permit the rightful owner of the property to identify it. 
(Ord. No. 765, § 2, 10-6-2008) 
Sec. 38-62. - Property exempt from sale. 
    The provisions of this division shall not apply to the possession or disposition of any property otherwise held as evidence in a court having jurisdiction thereof, nor to property held by the city under the terms of any other ordinance. These provisions shall not apply to pistols, revolvers, knives, slingshots, dirks, or other property of like character, the possession of which is made unlawful. All such unlawful property may be summarily destroyed by the custodian. 
(Ord. No. 765, § 2, 10-6-2008) 
Sec. 38-63. - Sale to highest bidder, bill of sale, transfer of title, and disposition of proceeds from sale. 
(a)  If the property is sold at public sale pursuant to this division, the finance department shall deduct from the proceeds the costs of transportation, storage and publication of notice, and any balance of proceeds shall be deposited into an interest-bearing account not later than 30 days after the date of sale and held there for one year. 
(b)  The finance department shall provide a bill of sale clearly stating that the sale is subject to any and all liens. 
(c)  The rightful owner of the property may claim the balance of the proceeds within one year from the date of the deposit stated in subsection (a) of this section by making application to the custodian. 
(d)  If no rightful owner comes forward with a claim to the property within the designated year, the balance of the proceeds shall be deposited into the state school fund. 
(e)  Any and all property not disposed of at such sale shall become the property of the city and may thereafter be disposed of in accordance with the provisions of applicable law. 
(Ord. No. 765, § 2, 10-6-2008) 
Sec. 38-64. - Liability of owner of abandoned property. 
(a)  The owner, agent, and/or tenant of the property on which the violation occurs and the owner of the vehicle, appliance or other personal property shall be jointly and individually responsible for compliance with the requirements of this division. 
(b)  The owner of any abandoned or lost property who, after notice as provided in this division, does not remove such property within the specified period shall be liable to the city for all costs of removal, storage, and destruction of such property, less any salvage value obtained by disposal of the property. Upon final disposition of the property, the finance department shall notify the owner, if known, of the amount owed. 
(c)  In the case of an abandoned boat or motor vehicle, any person who neglects or refuses to pay such amount is not entitled to be issued a certificate of registration for such boat or motor vehicle, or any other boat or motor vehicle, until such costs have been paid. The police department shall supply the department of highway safety and motor vehicles with a list of persons whose boat registrations privileges or whose motor vehicle privileges have been revoked under this section. Neither the department nor any other person acting as agent thereof shall issue a certificate of registration to a person whose boat or motor vehicle registration privileges have been revoked, as provided in this section, until such costs have been paid. 
(Ord. No. 765, § 2, 10-6-2008) 
Sec. 38-65. - Penalties for violations; administrative charges; collection of fines. 
(a)  In addition to costs of towing, storage and disposal of property as set forth in this division, any person, firm, or corporation who violates the provisions of this division shall be subject to a fine of not less than $10.00 nor more than $200.00. 
(b)  Administrative charges in the amount of the city's actual costs and attorney's fees shall be assessed in the event of an unsuccessful appeal or the necessity to institute collection procedures. 
(c)  The city manager may establish procedures and processes for the collection of any cost, penalty, or administrative charge imposed or assessed under the provisions of this division and may enforce such penalty by civil action in the nature of debt. 
(d)  Whoever opposes, obstructs, or resists any police officer or any person authorized by a police officer in the discharge of his or her duties as provided in this section is guilty of a misdemeanor of the second degree, punishable as provided in F.S. § 775.082 and § 775.083. 
(Ord. No. 765, § 2, 10-6-2008) 
Secs. 38-66-38-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PROPERTY MAINTENANCE 

Sec. 38-91. - Purposes and goals. 
    The purpose and intent of this article is to protect the public health, safety, and welfare, and to protect the aesthetic and property values of properties by providing for abatement of unsanitary and unsafe conditions, including the accumulation of litter and debris and overgrown vegetation, which constitutes a code violation on land subject to and in violation of this article. 
(Code 1988, § 8-67; Ord. No. 765, § 3, 10-6-2008) 
Sec. 38-92. - Prohibited conditions; exemptions. 
(a)  The excessive accumulation of weed growth, grass, excluding seed pods, to a height in excess of 18 inches high, or an accumulation of rubbish, trash, debris, litter or manmade materials upon any lot, tract or parcel of land where such growth or accumulation increases the conditions leading to a haven or breeding place for snakes, rats or rodent or other vermin of like or similar character, or creates a breeding place for mosquitoes, creates a fire hazard to adjacent properties, or adversely affects or impairs the economic welfare of adjacent properties or creates a hazard at road intersections or rights-of-way within the city is declared a public code violation and is prohibited. 
(b)  A dead, decaying or living tree that poses an actual threat of damage to permitted buildings or public infrastructure on adjacent properties is declared to be a public code violation. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for the owner or occupant of any land to permit, cause or have on such land any accumulations of junk, except for: 
(1)  Junk stored in enclosed litter receptacles or completely enclosed buildings; 
(2)  Junk which will not fit into standard sized litter receptacles and which is set out for no more than 96 hours for pickup and removal; 
(3)  Recyclable material stored in receptacles provided for recycling such materials; and 
(4)  Junk stored in a lawfully established junkyard, garbage or waste disposal site or sanitary landfill. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any owner, agent, contractor or other person in charge of a construction, demolition or development site to: 
(1)  Cause or permit the accumulation of junk or litter on such site, except in enclosed litter receptacles; 
(2)  Fail to furnish on-site litter receptacles; or 
(3)  Leave unused construction materials on site for more than seven days after the completion of the development, demolition, or construction, or the expiration of the permit. 
(e)  Public code violations shall be unlawful in any area of the city meeting the following criteria: 
(1)  Commercial, industrial or residential zoning district. 
(2)  A parcel or tract of land, except parcels or tracts zoned agricultural, lying adjacent to the boundary of any improved property, and within 100 feet of the property. 
(f)  Agricultural properties are exempt from this article with the exception of trash and debris. 
(Code 1988, § 8-68; Ord. No. 765, § 3, 10-6-2008) 
Sec. 38-93. - Duty of property owners. 
    It shall be the duty of the owner of any lot, tract or parcel of land within the areas of the city to reasonably and effectively control the excessive growths and accumulations described in section 38-92. The owner of vacant or undeveloped lots, tracts or parcels of land must reasonably and effectively maintain natural vegetation; and must reasonably and effectively control excessive trash and debris as described in section 38-92. 
(Code 1988, § 8-69; Ord. No. 765, § 3, 10-6-2008) 
Sec. 38-94. - Notice to property owner to correct prohibited conditions. 
(a)  If a city enforcement officer finds and determines that a public code violation exists, as described in section 38-92, the record owner of the offending property shall be so notified in writing with a demand that such owner cause the situation to be remedied. The notice shall be given by certified mail, return-receipt requested, addressed to the owner of the property described with the names and addresses as shown upon the most recent records of the county property appraiser, and shall be determined completed and sufficient when so addressed and deposited in the United States mail. Within 30 days of the mailing of the notice required in this section, if the owners have not reached an agreement with the city as to abatement of the code violation, then the city shall post the offending property for a period of ten days. If the property is not shown on the records of the county property appraiser, no letter is necessary and the property shall be posted for a period of 30 days. Upon the expiration of the posting period, if the owners have not reached an agreement with the city as to the abatement of the code violation, the city shall order the property mowed, cleaned or other corrective action taken to eliminate the violation at the expense of the property owner as defined in section 38-95. 
(b)  The notice shall be in substantially the following form: 
NOTICE of PUBLIC CODE VIOLATION 
DATE: ____________ 
NAME OF OWNER(S): ____________ 
ADDRESS: ____________ 
Our records indicate that you are the owner of the following property in the City of Brooksville, Florida: 
{Legal Description of Property} 
An inspection of this property disclosed that a public code violation exists thereon so as to constitute a violation of section 38-92 of the City of Brooksville Code of Ordinances. 
{Description of Condition of Property} 
You are hereby notified that unless the condition above described is remedied as required by this article within 30 days of the mailing of this letter, the city will abate this condition and the cost of the work, including advertising costs, a nuisance administrative surcharge of $25.00, inspection fee of $20.00 per site visit, and other expenses, will be imposed as a special assessment lien upon the property. 
Furthermore, please be advised that the City of Brooksville has the right to foreclose on properties upon which a lien has been placed and not paid within one year. 
(Code 1988, § 8-69.1; Ord. No. 580-A, § 1, 8-16-1999; Ord. No. 765, § 3, 10-6-2008; Ord. No. 580-B, § 1, 3-20-2006) 
Sec. 38-95. - Collection of costs and records. 
(a)  Lien for unpaid expenses. Generally, after causing a condition prohibited by section 38-92 to be remedied, the enforcement officer shall certify to the city council the expenses incurred in remedying the condition including any unpaid administrative costs whereupon such costs shall be payable within 30 days, after which a special assessment lien and an administrative surcharge will be made upon the property which shall be payable with interest at a rate of ten percent per annum from the date of such certification until paid. Such lien shall be enforceable in the same manner as a special assessment lien in favor of the city and shall be satisfied at any time by payment thereof including accrued interest. Notice of such lien shall be filed in the office of the clerk of the circuit court and recorded among records of the county. 
(b)  Penalties and fines. If the special assessment lien is not paid within one year, the city attorney may commence foreclosure proceedings to foreclose upon the special assessment lien. The foreclosure shall be conducted pursuant to procedure set forth in general law for the foreclosure of special assessment liens. If the lien is foreclosed upon, the owner of the property which is subject to foreclosure shall, in addition to any other charges, pay the city's reasonable attorney's fees in such foreclosure proceedings. The city shall have the right to compromise or settle any lien by accepting payment of less than the full amount of the lien for good cause. 
(Code 1988, § 8-69.2; Ord. No. 765, § 3, 10-6-2008) 
Sec. 38-96. - Additional enforcement. 
    Nothing contained in this article shall prohibit the city from enforcing its codes or ordinances by any other means allowed or permitted by law. 
(Code 1988, § 8-69.3; Ord. No. 765, § 3, 10-6-2008) 
Sec. 38-97. - Permit denial. 
    While any unpaid charges or liens exist on the subject property, no building or zoning permit or license in any other form of city approval shall be issued to anyone affecting or relating to the subject property until such lien or charges are satisfied or satisfactory arrangements are made with city for payment. 
(Code 1988, § 8-69.4; Ord. No. 765, § 3, 10-6-2008) 
Secs. 38-98-38-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - CLEANUP OR ABATEMENT OF HAZARDOUS MATERIALS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Police powers to abate declared nuisances and hazards, F.S. § 166.021. 

Sec. 38-131. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Environment means any surface water, groundwater, drinking water supply, land surface or subsurface strata or ambient air within the city, whether public or private. 
    Extraordinary expenses means that expense and those related costs and fees that are incurred by the city for any extraordinary service, including, but not limited to, the city's actual cost of labor and materials associated with the use of any specialized extinguishing or abatement agent chemical, neutralizer or similar equipment (or equipment damage) or materials that are employed to extinguish, confine, neutralize, contain or clean any hazardous material that is or may be involved in a fire, accidental spill or the threat of any fire or accidental spill. Extraordinary expenses include, but are not limited to, actual costs of personnel, such as salary, worker's compensation benefits, fringe benefits, administrative overhead and medical monitoring, equipment operation maintenance and replacement, rental or leasing of equipment used for a specific response, special technical services, laboratory costs, services and supplies contracted or purchased for a specific response and any other costs authorized by state or federal law. 
    Extraordinary service means a service performed by the city's fire department, police department, public works department or any other city department (or any person contracted or hired by the city for the purpose of responding to the release or threatened release of a hazardous material), that is additional to or above the normal services provided by such departments or divisions. Extraordinary services may include, but are not limited to, crowd safety, security and traffic control; evacuation and emergency housing; the abatement and disposition of hazardous and harmful materials, spills or the threat of spills of toxic or hazardous gases; utility line breaks or leakages; other imminent or perceived or possible threats to the health, safety or welfare of the city residents that may be detailed or contemplated as an extraordinary expense; and those instances where a property owner has been previously warned about violations of the city Code that, in the judgement of the city manager or his designee, are a particular threat to the health, safety or welfare of the city residents and for which the owner (or owner's agent or person in charge of the property) has neglected to comply or has refused compliance therewith. 
    Hazardous material means any material defined, listed, characterized or classified as a hazardous material, hazardous substance, hazardous waste or toxic substance according to any of the following state or federal codes or regulations: 
(1)  Florida Substance List, F.A.C. ch. 38F-41. 
(2)  Identification and Listing of Hazardous Wastes, 40 CFR 261. 
(3)  Designation of Hazardous Substances, 40 CFR 302.4. 
(4)  List of Extremely Hazardous Substances, 40 CFR 355 Appendices A and B. 
(5)  Hazardous Materials Tables, 49 CFR 172.101 and 172.102. 
The term "hazardous material" also includes any solution, mixture or formulation containing such material and any material which, due to its chemical or physical characteristics, is determined by the city staff to pose a substantial threat to the life, health or safety of persons or property or to the environment. The term includes, but is not limited to, explosives, radioactive materials, petroleum products, gases, poisons, etiologic (biologic) agents, flammables and corrosives. 
    Release means any spilling, leaking, pumping, pouring, emitting, emptying, discharging, injecting, escaping, leaching, dumping or disposing of hazardous materials into the environment (including the abandonment or discarding of barrels, containers and other closed receptacles containing hazardous material) in such a manner as to endanger the public health or welfare or the environment or in violation of any federal, state or local law, rule, regulation or order. Such release may be accidental or willful, sudden or gradual. 
    Remedy and remedial action mean those actions consistent with a permanent remedy taken instead of or in addition to removal actions in the event of a release or threatened release of a hazardous material into the environment to prevent or minimize the release of hazardous materials so that they do not migrate to cause substantial danger to the present or future public health or welfare of the environment. The term includes, but is not limited to, such actions at the location of the release as storage; confinement; perimeter protection using dikes, trenches or ditches; clay cover; neutralization; cleanup of released hazardous materials or contaminated materials; recycling or reuse: diversion; destruction; segregation of reactive wastes; dredging or excavations; repair or replacement of leaking containers; collection of leach and runoff; onsite treatment or incineration; provision of alternative water supplies and any monitoring reasonably required to ensure that such actions protect the public health and welfare and the environment. 
    Remove and removal mean the cleanup or removal of released hazardous materials from the environment, including such actions as may be necessary to monitor, assess and evaluate the release or threat of release of hazardous materials; the disposal of removed materials or the taking of such other actions as may be necessary to prevent, minimize or mitigate damage to the public health or release or threat of release. The term includes, in addition without being limited to, security fencing or other measures to limit access, provision of alternative water supplies, temporary evacuation and housing of threatened individuals not otherwise provided for and any emergency assistance which may be provided. 
    Respond and response mean any activity taken to remove or remedy the effects of a release or threatened release of a hazardous material, including any enforcement activities related thereto. 
(Code 1988, § 8-72) 
Sec. 38-132. - Purpose; intent and scope. 
    It shall be the purpose of this article to provide for the reimbursement of extraordinary expenses incurred by the city in order to clean up or abate the effects of any hazardous material deposited or discharged upon or into property or facilities within the city. The authority to recover the extraordinary expenses shall not include services which are normally or usually provided by the various departments of the city. The remedy provided by this article shall be in addition to any other remedies provided for by law. 
(Code 1988, § 8-71) 
Sec. 38-133. - Responsibility for removal and remedial action. 
    Any person responsible for the release of a hazardous material shall immediately institute and complete all action necessary to remove and remedy the effects of such release of a hazardous material in accordance with the applicable state and federal law and in the following circumstances: 
(1)  At the request of another governmental agency. 
(2)  When any other person responsible for a release does not take immediate action to remove and remedy the effects of such release. 
(3)  When a release occurs on private property and the owner cannot be identified, located or notified. 
(4)  When the city manager or his designee determines that such response is reasonably necessary under the circumstances to protect the public health, safety or welfare or the environment. 
(Code 1988, § 8-73) 
Sec. 38-134. - Reimbursement of extraordinary expenses. 
    Except as otherwise provided by law, any person responsible for the release of a hazardous material shall reimburse the city for all extraordinary expenses incurred by the city in response to such release. 
(Code 1988, § 8-74) 
Sec. 38-135. - Collection of extraordinary expenses. 
    The city finance department shall collect all extraordinary expenses as follows: 
(1)  Within 30 days of the date of the extraordinary or dangerous occurrence giving rise to the extraordinary service, the affected department shall submit its extraordinary expenses to the finance department for review. At such time as all extraordinary expenses have been submitted to and reviewed by the finance department, but in any case not later than 60 days from the date of the rendering of the extraordinary services, the finance department shall send a bill of consolidated extraordinary expenses to the property owner, agent or manager with a demand that a full remittance be made within 30 days of receipt of bill. 
(2)  It is contemplated that local, state or federal agencies may bill, fine or penalize the city for matters, including, but not limited to, a cleanup cost, fee or expense, relating to an extraordinary or dangerous occurrence; and the finance department shall, when possible, include any and all such costs or fees in the consolidated bill sent to the property owner. The city shall not, however, waive any right to collect such local, state or federal costs if they are not included with the consolidated bill and are not charged to the property owner or his agent within the consolidated billing 60-day period. In this regard, the finance department shall expect reimbursement of all local, state or federal costs within 30 days of the owner's (or his agent's) receipt of the bill for these particular costs, fees and so forth. 
(3)  In cases of hardship or where circumstances are such that a full remittance cannot be made to the city within the 30-day period, the city attorney is authorized to enter into negotiations with the property owner or his agent for an extended payback period of time not to exceed six months. 
(4)  All monies received under the provisions of this section shall be placed in an account established for the express purpose of reimbursing the various departments for those actual extraordinary expenses necessary to furnish police and other emergency or public safety or protection provided by the city as outlined herein. 
(Code 1988, § 8-75) 
Sec. 38-136. - Litigation. 
(a)  The city may enforce these provisions by civil action in a court of competent jurisdiction for the collection of any amounts due under this article plus attorneys' fees or for any other relief that may be appropriate. A certified copy of a judgment in favor of the city may be recorded in the public records and, therefore, shall constitute a lien upon any real or personal property owned by such person; and such lien shall be co-equal with the lien of all state, county, district and municipal taxes superior in dignity to all other liens, titles and claims until paid or extinguished. 
(b)  This article shall not prohibit the city from pursuing any other remedy, whether civil or criminal, or from instituting any appropriate action or proceeding, including injunction, in a court of competent jurisdiction. Nor shall the recovery of extraordinary expenses under this article in any way release the various parties or limit them from legal liability incurred as a result of hazardous material cleanup or abatement as defined under any local, state or federal rule or regulation. 
(Code 1988, § 8-76) 
Secs. 38-137-38-160. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - LITTERING[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Florida Litter Law, F.S. § 403.413 et seq.
