(Common brand names currently being used include, but are not limited to, "AK-47", "Aroma", "Atomic", "Aura", "Aurora Incense", "Barely In", "Black Mamba", "Black Rob", "Bliss", "Blizzard", "Blue Silk", "Bonzai Grow", "Boombay Blue", "Brain Storm", "Bullet", "Buzz", "California Dreams", "Charge Plus", "Charlie", "Chill X", "Chronic Spice", "Cloud 9", "Dank", "Daylights", "Dead Man Walking", "Demon", "Diable Botanical Incense", "Dragons Fire", "Drone", "D-ZL", "Earth Impact", "Earthquake", "Eight Balls", "Energy- I", "Euphoria", "Fake Weed", "Fuzzy Wuzzy", "G-13", "G-20", "Galaxy Gold", "Genie", "Grape Ape Herbal Incense", "Green Buddha", "Guerrilla Warfare", "Hayze", "Hypnotig", "Hurricane", "Hurricane Charlie", "Hush", "Ivory Wave", "Jazz", "Joker", "K-2", "K-3", "K-3 Legal", "Kryptonite", "Kush", "Kush Mania", "Lovely Dovey", "Lucid", "Lunar Wave", "Maddie", "Mad Hatter", "Makes Scents", "Man of Steel", "Matrix", "Maui Wowie", "MCAT", "MDPV", "MDPK", "Meow Meow", "Meph", "Mind Trip", "Moon Rocks", "Mr. Happy", "Mr. and Mrs. Marley", "Mr. Nice Guy", "MTV", "Mystery", "Nightlights", "Ocean", "Ocean Blue", "Ocean Burst", "OMG", "O-Zone", "Peeve", "Pineapple Express", "Pixie Dust", "Posh", "Pot-Pourri", "Puff', "Pulse", "Pure Ivory", "Purple Haze", "Purple Wave", "PV", "Red Dove", "Scarface", "Scooby Snax", "Scope", "Sence", "Serenity", "Skunk", "Sky High", "Smoke", "Snow Leopard", "Solar Flare", "Soul Sence", "Space Truckin", "Spice", "Spice 99", "Spice Gold", "Spice Silver", "Stardust", "Stinger", "Sugar Sticks", "Supper Coke", "Three Monkey Incense", "Tiger Shark", "Vanilla Sky", "Voodoo", "Voodoo Child", "White Dove", "White Knight", "White Lightening", "Zohai", and a group of products marketed as from "The Spice Guy".) 
(g)  Ingredients: A product which has been enhanced with a synthetic chemical or synthetic chemical compound that has no legitimate relation to the advertised use of the product but mimics the effects of a controlled substance when the product, or the smoke from the burned product, is introduced into the human body. 
(h)  Verbal or written representations: Verbal or written representations made at the place of sale or display regarding the purpose, methods, use, or effect of the product. 
(Ord. No. 837, § 3, 7-1-2013) 
Sec. 58-45. - Prohibited acts. 
(a)  The possession, use, sale, distribution, production, or manufacture of synthetic drugs, as defined in this article, is prohibited in the City of Brooksville. 
(b)  The display for sale or marketing of synthetic drugs, as defined in this ordinance, on retail store shelves is prohibited in the City of Brooksville. 
(c)  The advertisement of synthetic drugs, as defined in this article, is prohibited in the City of Brooksville. 
(d)  The display for sale, marketing, advertisement, or other offer for sale of any product described in section 58-44 above is prohibited in the City of Brooksville. 
(Ord. No. 837, § 3, 7-1-2013) 
Sec. 58-46. - Laboratory analysis. 
    Any laboratory analysis of suspected synthetic drug products shall be conducted by a state certified private laboratory, competent to provide expert testimony in a court of law as to the chemical contents of the product and to the effect such contents may have if introduced into a human body. Upon the administrative determination of a violation, costs for such analysis and expert testimony shall be assessable against the person or entity charged with the violation. 
(Ord. No. 837, § 3, 7-1-2013) 
Sec. 58-47. - Enforcement and penalties. 
    Primary responsibility for the enforcement of this article shall be with the City of Brooksville Police Department. Any law or code enforcement officer designated by the city is hereby empowered to initiate enforcement proceedings when, based upon personal investigation, the officer has reasonable cause to believe that the person has committed a violation of this provision. This article may be enforced as a violation of the City of Brooksville Code of Ordinances pursuant to article VIII, section 8-1.5.G. of the City of Brooksville Land Development Code. For the purposes of enforcement of this article, a separate code violation shall be considered to occur each day the original violation continues. This article is enforceable against any natural person, business entity, trust, partnership, corporation, lessee, or property owner. Due to the dangerous medical and health effects the products prohibited by this ordinance can have on the user of the product, each violation shall be considered a serious threat to the public health, safety, and welfare of the citizens of the City of Brooksville. 
(Ord. No. 837, § 3, 7-1-2013)

ARTICLE II. - FEDERAL OLD-AGE AND SURVIVORS INSURANCE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Social security, F.S. ch. 650; social security coverage for employees of political subdivisions, F.S. § 650.05. 

Sec. 66-31. - Adoption of plan. 
    It is declared to be the policy and purpose of the city to extend, effective as of January 1, 1953, to the employees and officials thereof not excluded by law, and whether employed in connection with a governmental or proprietary function, the benefits of the system of old-age and survivors insurance as authorized by the Federal Social Security Act and amendments thereto, including Public Law 734 of 81st Congress, and by Laws of Fla., ch. 26841(1951), and to cover by such plan all services which constitute employment as defined in F.S. ch. 650, performed in the employ of the city by employees, thereof. In pursuance of this policy, and for that purpose, the city shall take such action as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. 
(Code 1988, § 12-16) 
Sec. 66-32. - Execution of agreement with state. 
    The mayor is authorized and directed to execute all necessary agreements and amendments thereto with the state for the purpose of extending the benefits provided by the system of old-age and survivors insurance to the employees and officials of this city, which agreement shall provide for such methods of administration of the plan by the city as are found by the state agency to be necessary for the proper and efficient administration thereof, and shall be effective with respect to services in employment covered by such agreement performed after January 1, 1953. 
(Code 1988, § 12-17) 
Sec. 66-33. - Employee contributions. 
    Withholdings from salaries, wages or other compensation of employees and officials for the purpose provided in this article are authorized to be made, and shall be made, in the amounts and at such times as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations, and shall be paid over to the state agency designated by those laws or regulations to receive such amounts. 
(Code 1988, § 12-18) 
Sec. 66-34. - City contributions. 
    There shall be appropriated from available funds, derived from general operating funds, such amounts, at such times, as may be required to promptly pay the contributions required of the city as employer by applicable state or federal laws or regulations, which shall be paid over to the lawfully designated state agency at the times and in the manner provided by law and regulation. 
(Code 1988, § 12-19) 
Sec. 66-35. - Records and reports. 
    The city shall keep such records and make such reports as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations, and shall adhere to the rules and regulations of the state agency for the enforcement of those laws and regulations. 
(Code 1988, § 12-20) 
Sec. 66-36. - Acceptance of terms of federal act. 
    The city adopts the terms, conditions, requirements, reservations, benefits, privileges, and other conditions thereunto appertaining, of Title 11 of the Social Security Act as amended by Public Laws 734, 81st Congress, for and on behalf of all the officers and employees thereof and of its departments and agencies, excepting any official or employee who occupies any position, office or employment not authorized to be covered by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. 
(Code 1988, § 12-21) 
Sec. 66-37. - Custodian of funds; withholding and reporting agent. 
    The finance director is designated the custodian of all sums withheld from the compensation of officers and employees and of the appropriated funds for the contribution of the city, and the human resources director is made the withholding and reporting agent and charged with the duty of maintaining personnel records for the purposes of this article. 
(Code 1988, § 12-22) 
Secs. 66-38-66-70. - Reserved.

Sec. 66-91. - Declaration of policy and purpose. 
    It is declared to be the policy and purpose of this city to extend, effective October 1, 1972, to the employees and officials thereof, not excluded by law or excepted by this article, the benefits of the Florida Retirement System as authorized by F.S. § 121.051(2)(b), to cover by such plan all services which constitute employment as defined in F.S. § 121.021, performed in the employ of the city by employees and officials thereof.

Sec. 66-92. - Referendum to elect coverage. 
    There is excluded from this article any authority to include in any agreement entered into under section 66-93 any service, position, employee or official now covered by or eligible to be covered by an existing retirement system sponsored by the city except social security only after holding a referendum, in which all employees and officials in the affected units have the right to participate. Only those employees and officials electing coverage under the Florida Retirement System by affirmative vote in the referendum shall be eligible for coverage, and those not participating or electing not to be covered by the Florida Retirement System shall remain in their present system and shall not be eligible for coverage. After the referendum is held, all future employees shall be compulsory members of the Florida Retirement System.

Chapter 70 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes:

State Law reference- Municipal Home Rule Powers Act, F.S. ch. 166; litter control, F.S. § 403.413 et seq.; resource recovery and management, F.S. § 403.702 et seq.; local government solid waste management responsibilities, F.S. § 403.706; local hazardous waste collection programs, F.S. § 403.7265. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 70-1-70-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Resource recovery and management, F.S. § 403.702 et seq.; local government solid waste management responsibilities, F.S. § 403.706; local hazardous waste collection programs, F.S. § 403.7265. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 70-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Call backs means that service provided by the city on an unscheduled basis at the commercial, residential curbside, or residential centralized service customer's request and is required as a result of customer negligence or an inability of the city to collect the waste at the scheduled time through no fault of the city. Such service shall be considered a special service and shall be assessed at the rate specified for such service in accordance with section 70-111(b). 
    Capital recovery fee means that fee or assessment that shall be levied on all new commercial or residential centralized customers or property owners at such time dumpster service is either requested or a building permit is applied for, whichever is the earlier, and is a fee structured to recover that initial capital cost incurred by the city in providing the service. 
    City means, unless otherwise stated in this article, the city council or its designee. 
    Commercial service means any refuse service provided to hotels, motels, roominghouses, tourist courts, travel/recreational vehicle parks, business establishments, churches, schools, office buildings, and any other establishments whatsoever other than those that are defined as a residential curbside or residential centralized collection service in this section. The term "commercial service" shall also apply to mobile home developments/subdivisions, bungalow courts, cluster homes, apartment buildings, cooperative apartments, condominiums and all other multifamily type developments which have consolidated, centralized refuse receptacles and which receive a monthly billing to a single entity or person of sole responsibility for payment of such billing. 
    Curbside means the designated physical location for the placement of refuse accumulations intended for residential service collections and disposal by the city. This designated location shall be as near as possible to the traveled streets or alleys normally serviced by city refuse collection vehicles, but in no case upon such streets or alleys. The intention of a curbside designation is to allow collection by city waste control personnel in a rapid manner with walking or reaching being held to the minimum. In all cases, the city shall have the authority to approve or specify the precise location for such curbside placement. 
    Dumpster service means that method of solid waste collection which requires the placement of dumpsters as a manner of containerizing such waste. This shall include both categories of commercial and residential centralized services. 
    Garbage means every refuse accumulation of animal, fruit or vegetable matter that attends the preparation, use in cooking and dealing in or storage of meats, fish, fowl, fruit or vegetables; any matter of any nature whatsoever which is subject to decay and the generation of noxious or offensive gases or odors, or which, during or after decay, may serve as breeding or feeding material for flies or other germ-carrying insects; and any bottles, cans or other containers, utilized in normal household use, which due to their facility to retain water may serve as breeding places for mosquitoes or other insects. 
    Garden and lawn trash means all accumulations of grass, leaves, shrubbery, vines, tree branches and trimmings that are normally associated with the care and maintenance of landscaping. 
    Hazardous waste means solid waste, or a combination of solid wastes, which, because of its quantity, concentration, or physical, chemical or infectious characteristics, may cause, or significantly contribute to, an increase in mortality or an increase in serious irreversible or incapacitating reversible illness or may pose a substantial present or potential hazard to human health or the environment when improperly transported, disposed of, stored, treated or otherwise managed. The term does not include human remains that are disposed of by persons licensed under F.S. ch. 470. 
    Hazardous waste facility means any building, site, structure or equipment at or by which hazardous waste is disposed of, stored or treated. 
    Hazardous waste management means the systematic control of the collection, source separation, storage, transportation, processing, treatment, recovery, recycling and disposal of hazardous wastes. 
    Household trash means the accumulations of paper, magazines, packaging, containers, sweepings, and all other accumulations of a nature other than garbage or lawn trash, which are usual to housekeeping and to the operation of stores, offices and other business places. 
    Infectious waste means those wastes which may cause disease or reasonably be suspected of harboring pathogenic organisms. Wastes resulting from the operation of medical clinics, hospitals and other facilities producing wastes which may consist of, but are not limited to, discarded human and animal parts, contaminated clothing and surgical gloves are included. Additionally included in this category of infectious waste are wastes containing any form of human or animal feces matter not sealed in a proper container. 
    Land clearing debris means the uprooted or cleared vegetation resulting from a land clearing operation and does not include yard trash. 
    Land clearing operations means the uprooting or clearing of vegetation in connection with construction of buildings, rights-of-way, residential or industrial development, mineral operations, or the initial clearing of vegetation to enhance property value and does not include yard trash. 
    Level of service means that method and manner of solid waste collection to be rendered by the city. It shall encompass descriptions as to the number, capacity and type of solid waste collection containers; for example four-cubic-yard or eight-cubic-yard dumpsters; five-gallon or ten-gallon garbage cans, etc. This term does not apply to the frequency of collection. 
    Refuse means and includes garbage and trash, and all other trash, rubbish, paper, glass, metal and other discarded matter which is abandoned to the city for disposal. 
    Refuse regulations means the regulations prescribed by this article together with such administrative rules, regulations and procedures as may be established for the purpose of carrying out or making effective the provisions of this article. 
    Residential centralized collection service means those structures or developments categorized as multifamily; e.g., condominiums, apartments and cluster homes, etc., or mobile home developments/subdivisions, bungalow courts, and all other such residential dwelling units not meeting the criteria established as either commercial or residential curbside service as contained in this article. Such residential dwelling units are those that do in fact have consolidated or centralized solid waste collection receptacles, but which are billed on an individual unit basis. Rates charged for this type of service shall be as stipulated in section 70-87. 
    Residential curbside service means the refuse collection service provided to any single-family residence, mobile home developments/subdivisions, and all other residential type dwelling units which do not have consolidated, centralized refuse collection receptacles, and which receive individual curbside collection service and which are billed individually or on a per unit basis for such service. 
    Special service means any collection or disposal service provided on a call back basis or which exceeds the uniform level of service provided, to include the disposal of bulk solid waste or refuse not containerized, under commercial, residential curbside or residential centralized service systems or such service which is provided on an on call basis; for example, contractor, etc., and for which a special service charge is applied. 
    Yard trash means vegetative matter resulting from landscaping and yard maintenance operations and includes materials such as tree and shrub trimmings, leaves, grass clippings, palm fronds, trees and tree stumps subject to normally scheduled trash collection. 
(Code 1988, § 7-2) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 403.703. 
Sec. 70-32. - Purpose. 
    This article is adopted to promote and protect the public health, safety and general welfare of the citizens of the city. The regulations, authority and rates established in this article are for the purpose of providing a city-operated solid waste collection and disposal system that equitably balances the level of service provided with the cost of providing that service. 
(Code 1988, § 7-1) 
Sec. 70-33. - Authority of city to make and enforce regulations concerning storage, collection, disposal of refuse and land clearing debris. 
(a)  The city is responsible for the supervision of all storage, collection and conveyance of refuse generated within the city. The city shall have the authority to make regulations concerning the days of collection, type and location of refuse containers and such other matters pertaining to the storage, collection, conveyance and disposal as it shall find necessary and to change or modify the same after reasonable notice. 
(b)  The city is responsible for the collection and disposal of all refuse generated within the city, including accumulations of refuse that may be in violation of this article or other refuse regulations. A notification of violation shall be made, which violation shall be corrected, in the time specified by such notice. 
(c)  Failing correction, the city is authorized to collect and dispose of the violating refuse and to bill the customer for the cost of providing this additional collection and disposal service. 
(d)  The city shall have the right to refuse to accept for collection, transportation and disposal any waste, which in the judgment of the director of public works or his representatives, would prove injurious to city personnel, the general public or in accordance with equipment and property. 
(Code 1988, § 7-5(a)-(d)) 
Sec. 70-34. - Disposition of refuse. 
    The city council shall have the power to provide for the collection and disposal by the city of garbage, ashes, trash, wastepaper or any other refuse. 
(Code 1988, § 7-3) 
Sec. 70-35. - Prohibited acts. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to do any of the following: 
(1)  To place or cause to be placed any garbage or trash upon the property of another, except as provided in this article. 
(2)  To collect or dispose of solid waste or refuse within the city limits as a commercial venture without either a franchise having been granted or a contract executed by or with the city pursuant to the provisions contained in this article. 
(3)  To deposit or dispose of any refuse on the paved or traveled portion of any public street, alleyway, sidewalk, bikepath, stream, ditch, river, pond, bay, creek, park or public place in the city, except at areas as may be designated by the city. 
(4)  To deposit, dump or dispose of any garbage or trash at, upon, or in any incinerator or landfill without first obtaining the permission of the custodian thereof. 
(5)  To burn any refuse within the city, except at designated incinerators or landfills, without first obtaining a permit from the city pursuant to section 46-132. 
(6)  To produce or accumulate any refuse such as building wastes or tree branches while acting in the capacity of a contractor (such as a tree surgeon, landscaper or building contractor), without removal of the same to a designated disposal area. This prohibition does not apply to those individuals who have contracted with the city to remove such refuse under the special services provisions of this article. 
(7)  To allow any scattered refuse to remain at or near the curbside, or to fail to remove any windblown or animal-scattered refuse from the public area and right-of-way which have blown or otherwise scattered from the dwelling residence curbside collection point. 
(8)  To place any refuse out for collection by any alley, service drive, easement or right-of-way not serviced by city trucks. 
(9)  To place any garbage, trash or refuse out for collection adjacent to the street if city trucks service the area from any established alley. 
(10)  To place any garbage, trash or refuse in an underground container for pickup. 
(11)  To do any act prohibited or failure to do any act required by the regulations affecting the collection and disposal of refuse within the city. 
(12)  To dump or dispose of garbage, trash, litter, solid waste materials and all other forms of matter or things being disposed of or abandoned, into commercial garbage bins owned by the city, by anyone other than the business or entity to which such bin is assigned. It shall be prima facie evidence of a violation of this subsection if the disposed of or abandoned material, as outlined in this subsection, can be established as having originated with a particular individual and he has allowed it to be so dumped, discarded or abandoned in any area other than an approved solid waste landfill. 
(13)  To dispose of either hazardous wastes or infectious wastes in containers either provided by the city or which shall be collected by city personnel. All such wastes shall be disposed of by the procedures established in accordance with appropriate federal and state laws, statutes, city ordinances, and other rules and regulations. 
(14)  To place or cause to be placed any object that would preclude normal access by city personnel to any refuse containers during regularly scheduled collection activities. 
(15)  To burn any trees or vegetation from any land clearing operation within the city limits without submitting to the fire department a detailed drawing or map showing the location of the burn site, and receiving from the city fire officials an on-site inspection of the area and approval to burn per the restrictions reflected in section 46-133. 
(Code 1988, § 7-4) 
Sec. 70-36. - Periodic review of rates and charges. 
    At the direction of city council, a rate analysis will be performed to determine sufficiency of rates and methods of assessment. 
(Code 1988, § 7-7; Ord. No. 652-A, § 2, 9-21-2005) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 652-A, § 2, adopted September 21, 2005, repealed § 70-36, which pertained to the solid waste renewal and replacement fund and derived from the Code of 1988, § 7-6; and Ord. No. 652, § 1, adopted on April 7, 2003, renumbering §§ 70-37-70-39 as 70-36-70-38. The historic notation remains with the affected provisions. 
Sec. 70-37. - Ability of city council to contract and franchise services. 
    The city council shall have the right, pursuant to the proprietary powers granted it by section 1.03 of the city Charter, to negotiate and execute written agreements to provide solid waste collection and disposition to outside persons when to do so has resulted from a finding of fact that such action would best serve the public interest, or if a determination has been made that circumstances prohibit the city from providing such service from either an actual or economic viewpoint. The term "best public interest" shall be broadly interpreted to ignore cost effectiveness if necessary in order to enhance the long range endeavor of the city regarding solid waste collection or disposal or to improve environmental pollution control techniques. 
(Code 1988, § 7-9; Ord. No. 652-A, § 2, 9-21-2005) 
Note- See the editor's note to § 70-36. 
Sec. 70-38. - Contractual authority of city manager. 
    In keeping with and enforcing the policies that have been outlined in this article, the city manager, or his designee, shall have the authority to negotiate and execute those contracts on behalf of the city in those instances in which a written contractual arrangement is required as has been provided for in this article, and a finding of fact on the part of the city council is not required to substantiate such a contractual arrangement. 
(Code 1988, § 7-10; Ord. No. 652-A, § 2, 9-21-2005) 
Note- See the editor's note to § 70-36. 
Secs. 70-39-70-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - COMMERCIAL SERVICE 

Sec. 70-61. - Generally. 
(a)  Delineation. Commercial service shall be provided to business establishments, lodges, churches, schools, motels, apartments, office buildings and other places as required, where refuse is generated or accumulated. 
(b)  Collection frequency and method. Customers of sites receiving commercial service shall enter into an agreement with the city for the frequency and method of refuse collection. When necessary to protect the public health or to enforce the purpose of this division, the city shall have the authority to stipulate the frequency of collection. Service shall consist of the mechanical dumping of commercial receptacles as provided by the city or a manual hand service dumping of containers located at agreed sites upon the property, or other levels of service as may be required and agreed to. 
(c)  Preparation and storage. Refuse containers shall be drained free of all liquids prior to accumulation for collection. Storage areas and areas adjacent to the storage area shall be maintained by the customer in a neat, sanitary and sightly manner. Collectors are not allowed to sweep, pick up or otherwise clear up storage areas unless such service has been specifically agreed to and is billed accordingly. Customers are responsible for maintaining the accessibility to storage containers or areas. Collections which are agreed to but missed due to the customer's failure to maintain accessibility shall not constitute violation of agreement on the part of the city, and customers requesting later service of missed pickups shall be billed for the cost of providing this added service. Customers are required to keep all the refuse in the containers and to keep the container lids closed. 
(d)  Rates. In order to cover the costs of inspecting, collecting, handling, hauling and disposal of refuse, city council shall, by resolution, fix the rates to be paid monthly to the city. The rates assessed to multiple customers sharing a common bulk container unit ("dumpster") shall be in proportionally equal amounts for each such customer according to dumpster size except that in no case shall the rate be less than the minimum commercial curbside can service rate set forth by resolution. 
(e)  Surcharge. The city council shall, by resolution, fix surcharge rates for certain services that are not included in regular service. 
(Code 1988, § 7-41; Ord. No. 721, § A, 8-7-2006) 
Sec. 70-62. - Commercial compactor service. 
(a)  Delineation. Commercial compactor service shall consist of providing refuse collection service by an on-site refuse compactor to those entities defined in this article as commercial who by virtue of the high volume of refuse generated have need of such type of refuse containerization. At the discretion of the city this service may be provided by either the city or by a private contractor subject to conditions as prescribed in this division. 
(b)  Preparation, storage and placement for collection. Refuse shall be drained free of all liquid to every extent possible prior to accumulation for collection. The customer will ensure that only personnel properly trained in the operations of the compactor will be allowed to operate the same. Storage areas and areas adjacent to the storage area shall be maintained by the customer in a neat, sanitary and sightly manner. Collectors, whether city personnel or contracted personnel, are not allowed to sweep, pick up or otherwise clean up storage areas unless such service has been specifically agreed to. Customers are responsible for maintaining the accessibility to the compactor area for collection purposes. Collections which are agreed to but are missed due to the customer's failure to maintain accessibility shall not constitute a violation of agreement on the part of the city or contractor, if applicable, and customers requesting later or make-up service as a result, shall be billed according to the agreed upon cost of such service being provided. The compactor and associated facilities and equipment on-site will be maintained by the party holding title of ownership to the same, and will be performed in such a manner that minimum interruption of service will be experienced as well as to provide the aesthetic level of acceptability required for such activities. 
(c)  Providing for service. The city shall have the right to provide commercial compactor service to any such commercial establishments as shall be determined by the city to require such service. If it is determined by the city that the rendering of such service by the city would not be in the city's or the customer's best interest, the customer may then be allowed in turn to acquire such service from a private or public contractor, subject to the city being a party to such a contractual arrangement in accordance with the following conditions: 
(1)  A two-party written agreement shall be entered into between the customer and the contracting collector outlining the terms, conditions and rates under which the service shall be provided. Terms and conditions shall be written in such a manner as to constitute no violation of any law, regulation, policy or directive of any competent jurisdictional authority governing solid waste storage, collection or disposal activities. 
(2)  The agreement, as described in subsection (c)(1) of this section, shall become a part of and be incorporated with a tri-party agreement which shall then be entered into between the city, the collector and the customer. This tri-party agreement shall incorporate certain applicable provisions of this division and shall define the terms and conditions upon which service shall be provided. As a condition precedent, the contracting collector shall provide the city and customer proof of liability insurance, proof of bonding or irrevocable letter of credit from an acceptable financial institution guaranteeing payment of damages to the customer for nonperformance or breach of the agreement on the part of the collector in that amount which would represent the average charge for compactor collection service over a 30-day period, not to exceed $2,000.00. A blanket bond or letter of credit may be provided to cover each such infractionary incident that might occur. 
(3)  The city shall charge a monthly fee when service is provided by written agreement with a private contractor approved by the city. Such fee, which shall be set by the city council, by resolution, shall be representative of the cost incurred by the city in administering the contract, inspection of compactor and storage facilities on a continuing basis, and controlling the overall storage, collection and disposal activities. The fee shall be paid monthly and the contractor will provide the city with a copy of the invoices rendered to such customers as an attachment to the check remitting the fee payment. The customer shall remit payment directly to the collector in accordance with the terms agreed to in the written agreement mentioned in subsection (c)(1) of this section. 
(d)  Rates for service. When the city shall provide the compactor service, such service shall be performed by a written agreement between the city and the customer. The agreement shall incorporate all applicable provisions of this division, and the fee for such service shall be assessed monthly in accordance with the following schedule: 
(1)  The monthly rates for compactor service shall be based on the cubic yard capacity of the compactor at a rate which shall be set by city council, by resolution. 
(2)  At the discretion of the city the customer may be allowed to furnish and maintain the compactor and associated equipment if such should be determined to be in the best interest of both the customer and the city. In such event, the customer would only be assessed the per cubic yard rate aforesaid. 
(3)  Should solid waste disposal costs change as has been delineated by section 70-134, then the provisions for rate adjustment so provided shall be implemented with the exception that such rate adjustment will not apply to that monthly amount assessed for rental of equipment. 
(Code 1988, § 7-42) 
Sec. 70-63. - Special commercial curbside. 
    The special category is limited to those customers defined as commercial which do not generate sufficient quantities of refuse, garbage or trash to justify the use of a container or receptacle as provided by the city or do not have sufficient space to accommodate a container of minimum size. This service is limited to five cans, bags or bundles picked up twice a week and the monthly fee shall be set by city council by resolution. 
(Code 1988, § 7-43) 
Secs. 70-64-70-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - RESIDENTIAL SERVICE 

Sec. 70-81. - Delineation. 
    Residential service shall consist of individual curbside collection of all refuse. For the purpose of establishing service charges, there shall be two categories of can service. The first category shall consist of curbside collection of all refuse where the disposal fees are paid directly by the customer to the disposal site. The second category shall consist of curbside collection of all refuse where the city pays the disposal fees directly to the disposal site. 
(Code 1988, § 7-56) 
Sec. 70-82. - Preparation, storage and placement for collection. 
(a)  Garbage and household trash. All garbage and trash shall be drained free of all liquids and stored in metal or plastic containers commonly called cans or sealed watertight plastic bags of not less than two-mil thickness, or greater if so required by the city. If a can is used, it shall have a tightly fitting lid, be insectproof, and meet state, county and city requirements, but in no instance shall the lid have a locking or tying device other than is supplied by the manufacturer as standard equipment. Bags or containers of accumulated garbage and trash shall be placed on the curb or roadside no earlier than 8:00 p.m. of the day preceding the scheduled collection day, but no later than 8:00 a.m. of the scheduled day of collection. 
(b)  Garden or lawn trash. If a customer desires, garden and lawn trash may be collected on the same days as the garbage and other trash and must be bundled or containerized in such a manner as to enable one man to lift the trash in a single lifting movement to place the trash into the compaction truck. Garden or lawn trash shall be cut and bundled or containerized in sizes not to exceed 40 pounds in weight and four feet in length. The city shall continue to provide garden and lawn trash pickup as has been their policy in the past on a schedule to be determined by the city. Such garden or lawn trash pickup charge is otherwise provided in this division. Concrete, dirt, bricks, appliances, furniture or similar refuse is not considered garden or lawn trash, and will not be collected except by special service as described in section 70-111. 
(Code 1988, § 7-57) 
Sec. 70-83. - Responsibility for scattered refuse. 
    Customers are responsible for the cleanup from bags torn or cans spilled by animals or otherwise spilled through no fault of the collectors. City collectors are not required to sweep, fork, shovel or otherwise clean up refuse that has become scattered or is otherwise not readily picked up and placed in the compaction truck, including spillage resulting from overloaded containers. 
(Code 1988, § 7-58) 
Sec. 70-84. - Limitation as to quantity. 
(a)  The maximum number of bundles or containers that may be placed for collection on any one day is five. Any customer exceeding this quantity will be assessed additional charges for each such additional bundle or container in accordance with rates for such service as have been provided for in section 70-86. 
(b)  Garbage and household trash will be limited to containers that weigh no more than 40 pounds including contents. 
(c)  Garden and lawn trash must be bundled or containerized in size not to exceed 40 pounds in weight and four feet in length. 
(d)  Large and bulky items, including foliage type debris, shall be placed by the curb, for collection by the city with the boom truck which shall be scheduled at the discretion of the city at no extra charge, during such periods of regular collection schedule. 
(Code 1988, § 7-59) 
Sec. 70-85. - Backyard option for invalids and persons who are incapacitated. 
    The residential service system will allow certain customers who are invalids or are incapacitated the option of requesting backyard collection (this does not include yard trash). Such requests must be certified by a physician and submitted in writing to the city 30 days in advance of the start of the service and once requested, such service shall remain in effect for a maximum period of six months. Customers who are invalids or are incapacitated must be certified as to the necessity for other than curbside collection by the city, which may impose such reasonable conditions as may be required for such service and certification. 
(Code 1988, § 7-60) 
Sec. 70-86. - Service charges. 
    In order to cover the cost of collection, hauling and disposing of residential curbside service refuse, service charges shall be paid monthly to the city, which shall be set by city council, by resolution, and shall either be included on the regular monthly statements for utility service, or other appropriate billing form as shall be determined by the city. Such charges are mandatory for each occupied dwelling unit not receiving commercial or residential centralized collection service. A dwelling unit is considered occupied and a service charge will be applied for each month that either a water bill is prepared for domestic consumption or for the individual unit for which water service was provided through a master meter for such use, regardless of whether the dwelling unit is actually occupied. A fee shall also be set by city council, by resolution, for those customers who make application to the city for periods when the dwelling will be vacant. Such period in which this vacancy rate shall apply shall not be less than three consecutive monthly billing periods. An additional fee shall also be set by city council, by resolution, for those customers who have exceeded the quantity limitation of five containers or bundles on any given day of collection, which will be added to the monthly charge. 
(Code 1988, § 7-61) 
Sec. 70-87. - Residential centralized collection service. 
(a)  Delineation. Residential centralized collection service shall consist of centralized collection service of all refuse generated from a development or group of dwelling units at a given source location. 
(b)  Preparation, storage and placement for collection. 
(1)  Garbage and household trash. All garbage and trash shall be placed in the solid waste receptacle furnished in a centralized location, and shall be drained free of all liquids prior to accumulation for collection. Storage areas and areas adjacent to the storage areas shall be maintained by the customers in a neat, sanitary and sightly manner. Customers are responsible for maintaining the accessibility to storage containers or areas. Collections which are agreed to, but missed due to a customer's failure to maintain accessibility, shall not constitute a violation of this section on the part of the city. Customers are required to keep all refuse in the containers and to keep the container lids closed. The city shall not be responsible for refuse clean-up or collection of any refuse not placed in the proper receptacles. Collection receptacles, other than commercial dumpsters, provided by the city, shall not exceed 40 pounds in weight including the refuse contained therein. 
(2)  Garden and lawn trash. All garden and lawn trash, and other types of rubbish generated from discarded foliage shall be collected as a special service on an on-call basis, and shall be rendered at the rates specified for such service contained in section 70-111(b). 
(c)  Limitations as to size and quantity. For those units being served by individual containers, rather than a dumpster provided by the city, such container shall not exceed 40 pounds in weight, including contents and shall be limited to two containers per dwelling unit. Any resident or customer exceeding this quantity will be billed for each such additional container per pick-up at rates to be adopted by city council by resolution. 
(d)  Service charges. In order to cover the cost of collection, hauling and disposing of residential centralized service refuse, the city council shall set, by resolution, service charges which shall be paid monthly to the city, which charges shall either be included on the regular monthly statements for utility service, or other appropriate billing form as shall be determined by the city. Such charges are mandatory for each occupied dwelling unit not receiving commercial or residential curbside collection service. A dwelling unit is considered occupied and a service charge will be applied for each month that either a water bill is prepared for domestic consumption or for the individual unit for which water service was provided through a master meter for such use regardless of whether or not the dwelling unit is actually occupied. 
(Code 1988, § 7-62) 
Secs. 70-88-70-110. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - SPECIAL SERVICE 

Sec. 70-111. - Conditions; schedule, rates. 
(a)  Delineation. Any refuse or waste which, by reason of its bulk, shape or weight, cannot be placed in a container or bundled, or which exceeds the size and weight limitations of any section of this article, or which has been rendered as a result of a call back by the customer through no fault of the city, will be collected and disposed of by the city, at the convenience of the city, or on an on-call basis, at rates herein specified at location and on conditions imparted by the city. This does not include that service provided to customers of the residential curbside service for such items on a regularly scheduled basis. 
(b)  Special service schedule and rates. Special collection for on-call and call back services will be scheduled upon request. Special service fees, which shall be set by city council, by resolution, shall be billed directly to the requesting party and shall be payable with and included in the monthly bill. Charges not paid within the time specified shall be included with the next regular billing, and shall become delinquent and penalized as specified in section 70-132. 
(Code 1988, § 7-76) 
Secs. 70-112-70-130. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - SERVICE CHARGES OR FEES 

Sec. 70-131. - When service charges payable. 
    Service charges, or fees, levied by sections 70-61, 70-81-70-86 and 70-111 shall be collectable at the same time and in the same manner as bills for a service charge for other utilities rendered by the city, as set forth in chapter 86, pertaining to utilities. 
(Code 1988, § 7-26) 
Sec. 70-132. - Delinquent date; penalty; charge to constitute debt; occupation of building as prima facie evidence of garbage, trash. 
(a)  Delinquent date; penalty. If any service charges shall not be paid within 20 days after the same shall be due and payable, same shall be delinquent and there shall be added to such charges a penalty of ten percent of such charges to cover the additional administrative costs incurred by the city by reason of the failure of the customer to pay the charges within 20 days after the same shall be due and payable and the department shall cease to serve the premises or parcel of land for which such delinquent charges are due and payable until such charges and penalty shall be paid, and, if such premises, or parcel of land, for which such charges shall be delinquent shall be served by the waterworks system of the city, the water department of the city shall cease to serve such premises with water until such delinquent charges and penalty shall be paid. The city may, but shall not be obligated to, give notice of delinquency of payment. 
(b)  Charge to constitute debt. The service charges hereinabove prescribed shall be and constitute a debt to the city for which the owner, tenant or occupant shall be jointly and severally liable. The records of the city shall be kept open for the inspection by the owner, tenant or occupant and it shall be the responsibility of each of them to ascertain that the prescribed service charges are paid or are being paid. 
(c)  Occupation of building or rendering of water service shall be prima facie evidence of garbage, trash, refuse, etc. The fact that any place or unit of abode or any place of business is either occupied or being rendered water service for domestic consumption and use shall be prima facie evidence that garbage, trash, or refuse, or all is being produced and accumulated upon such premises and that service charges for the collection and disposal thereof are due the city, notwithstanding the provisions contained in section 70-86, wherein residential curbside customers only have been approved for the vacancy rate as has been established and set forth herein. This rule applies regardless of the manner in which the unit is metered and billed for water service. It does not include those locations that are being provided water service for irrigation or fire protection purposes only. 
(Code 1988, § 7-27) 
Sec. 70-133. - Capital recovery fee. 
(a)  Delineation. A capital recovery fee is that assessment which shall be levied on all new commercial or centralized residential service customers and developments to recover that capital cost incurred by the city in providing dumpsters to service such customers or developments. This fee shall not apply for those properties previously receiving dumpster service. 
(b)  Payment. The fee shall be paid at time of issuance of the first building permit for the development, service request by the customer, or at such time as an increase in level of service shall be determined to be appropriate and provided by the city in accordance with and under the provisions of section 70-33(a), whichever is the earlier, in that amount as has been provided for in this section in order that dumpsters may be reserved and/or acquired by the city to serve the customer or entire development at build out, as appropriate. 
(c)  Changes in level of service. Should it become necessary to either install dumpsters or increase the capacity or number of dumpsters to serve the customer or development, as appropriate, an additional capital recovery fee shall be levied to such customer or development, on a pro rata basis according to the difference in the current cost of which shall be incurred by the city in providing the increased level of service versus that current replacement value of those dumpsters serving such customer or development prior to such increase. In the case of multiple customers sharing a common dumpster and which an increase in level of service shall be required, then a capital recovery fee shall be levied upon the customer, as appropriate, which shall have necessitated or requested such increase in level of service and such fee shall be payable at the time stipulated in subsection (b) of this section. 
(d)  Amount. The amount to be levied shall be determined by the director of sanitation and shall be based on the actual capital cost which has been or is expected to be incurred by the city in providing that level of service required for the customer or development. Such cost shall be predicated and calculated on either that cost actually incurred in acquiring the dumpsters needed, according to number and capacity, or that lowest amount reflected in the most current bid proposals for such dumpsters, whichever is the greater amount. 
(e)  Use of revenues. The revenue which shall be generated as a result of the provisions contained in this section, shall only be utilized to purchase new dumpsters when needed to maintain inventory or provide new service, or liquidate any debt obligation which might have been incurred in providing such dumpster service. 
(Code 1988, § 7-28) 
Sec. 70-134. - Rate adjustments as result of landfill tipping fee or disposal cost adjustments. 
    At such times as there shall be either increases or decreases in the landfill tipping fee or costs associated with solid waste disposal in excess of five percent as a result of modification in the manner or fashion of assessment, disposal techniques, or their economic reasons, such adjustments shall in turn result in either an increase or decrease in customer billing which shall be adjusted only as shall be approved by the city council by resolution without the need for further hearings on the matter. 
(Code 1988, § 7-91) 
Chapters 71-73 - RESERVED 
Chapter 74 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal Home Rule Powers Act, F.S. ch. 166. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 74-1. - Placing of objects on public streets, sidewalks and rights-of-way prohibited; exception; penalty. 
(a)  No person shall place or cause to be placed upon the public streets, sidewalks or rights-of-way of the city any goods, wares or merchandise for the purpose of display or sale. No person shall place or deposit upon the public streets, sidewalks and rights-of-way of the city any other object that shall obstruct or tend to obstruct any street, sidewalk or right-of-way. 
(b)  Subsection (a) of this section shall not apply to materials necessarily placed on sidewalks or rights-of-way in the course of alteration or construction of any building when materials are placed thereon by a person duly bonded for that purpose, and when objects or materials are illuminated in the nighttime and protected by appropriate warning devices. Nothing in this section shall prohibit the placing upon public sidewalks or rights-of-way any benches, shelter, postal installation, regulatory signs or other public use facility, placed thereon with the permission of the city council or any obstruction placed on a sidewalk or other right-of-way pursuant to, and in accordance with the terms and conditions of, a revocable license approved and issued by the city council. Additionally, the city council may authorize the temporary use of a street, sidewalk or right-of-way for the benefit of a special public or private event, provided that the petitioner applying for such use obtain a right-of-way closure and use permit and provide liability insurance in an amount appropriate to the use. In accordance with the city Charter, the city manager or his designee is authorized to adopt rules to effectively administer and implement this section. 
(c)  Those found violating any portion of this section shall be guilty of a civil infraction and shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $50.00. Each day any violation of any provision of this section shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1988, § 13-1; Ord. No. 665, § 1(13-1), 2-2-2004) 
Secs. 74-2-74-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PUBLIC WORKS AND LOCAL IMPROVEMENTS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal public works, F.S. § 180.01 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 74-31. - Paving, curbing and grading streets. 
(a)  On petition of not less than two-thirds of the owners of property abutting upon one or more blocks of any street, avenue or other thoroughfare of this city, the city council shall have the power to grade, curb and pave such street, avenue or other thoroughfare, and if they so determine, they shall pass a resolution or ordinance authorizing same to be done. Thereupon they shall cause the city clerk to advertise for bids for doing such grading, curbing and paving, and in such advertisement shall reserve the right to reject any or all bids, and any drainage that may be required in doing such work shall be considered and taken as a part thereof. 
(b)  In advertising for bids, the city council may request separate bids for grading, curbing, paving and draining, in accordance with the detailed specifications previously prepared, and may enter into separate contracts therefor. As soon as practicable after the city council shall have accepted any bid for any such work, they shall, at a regular or special meeting, assess against the property abutting on that part of such street, avenue or other thoroughfare so to be improved, two-thirds of the cost of such improvement, after deducting all cost at street intersections. However, one-third of such cost shall be assessed against the property so abutting on one side of such street, avenue or other thoroughfare, in proportion to the respective frontages thereon, and one-third of such cost shall be assessed in like manner against the property so abutting on the other side of such street, avenue or other thoroughfare. 
(c)  The remaining one-third of the cost of such improvement, together with the whole cost incurred at street intersections, shall be paid by the city. Where there is any public property not legally assessable for such improvements abutting as stated above, the city shall also pay the proportion of the cost that would be assessable against such property if it were privately owned. 
(Code 1988, § 13-71) 
State Law reference- Supplemental and alternative methods of making local improvements by municipalities, F.S. ch. 170. 
Sec. 74-32. - Sewer, water and gas connections. 
(a)  Before paving or otherwise surfacing or resurfacing any street, avenue or other thoroughfare of the city, the city council shall determine whether there should first be constructed thereunder any sewer, water, gas or other underground connections, and if so, the time within which such construction shall be completed, and shall give notice thereof to the person or corporations required to make the same. If any person or corporation so notified fails, neglects or refuses to make any such connection when so ordered, no permission to make the same shall thereafter be granted to him or it, or to his or its assigns, within five years thereafter, unless for special reasons approved by the city council and expressed by resolution adopted at a meeting at which all members are present. Such a resolution shall state the reasons for granting the permission. 
(b)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit the city council from providing that such connections shall be made by the city, and the cost thereof assessed against the lots and lands benefited thereby, and if such connections be so made by the city, the cost thereof shall constitute a lien against the property so assessed. 
(Code 1988, § 13-72) 
Sec. 74-33. - Sidewalks. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the city council to prescribe the grade, width, materials and manner of construction of all sidewalks on all public streets of the city. Hereafter no sidewalk shall be laid on any public street of the city, save in accordance with such specifications, on pain of such penalty as the city council may by ordinance provide. 
(b)  On petition of not less than two-thirds of the owners of property abutting upon either or both sides of one or more blocks of any street in the city, the city council shall have the power to order the laying of the sidewalk so petitioned for. Upon failure of any of the owners of the abutting property to lay any such sidewalk as so ordered, the city council shall cause such sidewalks to be laid, and shall assess the cost and expense of laying the same against the abutting property, in proportion to the respective frontages, and such assessment shall constitute a lien against the property so assessed, provided that in every such case the city council shall cause such sidewalk to be extended, at the expense of the city, from the property line of the corner property at each end of each block to the curb or curbline of the side street or cross street in question. 
(Code 1988, § 13-73) 
Sec. 74-34. - General powers. 
    The city council shall have the power to condemn, purchase, acquire, lease or construct, within or without the city limits, and to maintain, conduct and operate, streets, drives, boulevards, avenues, causeways, parks, bridges, telephone systems, electric systems, waterworks, transportation system, cemeteries, pest houses, schools, hospitals, libraries and other public works of whatsoever nature, and to make any needful or convenient contracts in connection therewith, and may enforce purchases, if necessary, by eminent domain. 
(Code 1988, § 13-74) 
Sec. 74-35. - Governmental right-of-way takings. 
    If, as a result of governmental right-of-way takings, by either negotiation or condemnation, existing building or vehicular use areas or other permitted uses would, but for this section, become nonconforming or further nonconforming with the setback and landscape provision of this Code, the following provisions shall apply: 
(1)  Subject to the procedure set forth in subsection (4) of this section, existing building and vehicular use areas or other permitted uses which are not within the part taken, but which, because of the taking, do not comply with the setback, landscape or other requirements of this Code, shall not be required to be reconstructed to meet such requirements and the remainders shall be deemed thereafter to be conforming properties. The exemption thus created shall constitute a covenant of compliance running with the use of the land. 
(2)  Subject to the procedure set forth in subsection (4) of this section, any conforming building or vehicular use areas or other permitted uses taken either totally or partially may be relocated on the remainder of the site without being required to comply with the setback provisions of this Code except that the relocated building or vehicular use areas or other permitted uses shall be set back as far as is physically feasible without reducing the utility or use of the relocated building or vehicular use areas or other permitted uses below its pretaking utility use. The exemption thus created shall constitute a covenant of compliance running with the land. 
(3)  Any properties exempt according to subsections (1) and (2) of this section which are thereafter destroyed, other than by voluntary demolition, to an extent of more than 75 percent of the value at the time of destruction, may be restored but only to the predestruction condition. 
(4)  As to the exemptions in subsections (1) and (2) of this section, either the condemning authority or the landowner or both of them may apply in writing to the city manager for a determination by him that the granting of the exemption will not result in a condition dangerous to the health, safety or welfare of the general public. The city manager shall, within 30 days of the filing of applications, determine whether or not the exemption to the setback granted by this section will endanger the health, safety or welfare of the general public. If the city manager determines that the granting of the exemption under this section will not constitute a danger to the health, safety or welfare of the general public, the city manager shall issue a signed letter to all parties granting exemption. The letter shall specify the details of the exemption in a form recordable in the public records of the county. If the application is denied, the city manager shall issue a signed letter to the applicant specifying the specific health or safety ground upon which the denial is based. 
(5)  Any development permits or variances necessary to relocate building or vehicular use areas or other permitted uses taken or partially taken may be applied for by the condemning authority and granted for the property in question. 
Secs. 74-36-74-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SPECIAL ASSESSMENT 

Sec. 74-61. - Authority to issue. 
    In case of any lien authorized by this Code resulting from any assessment, other than an assessment for general taxes, against any real estate in the city, the city council, as soon as such assessment is made, shall cause to be issued a special lien certificate against each lot or parcel of land so assessed, for the amount of the assessment, which certificate shall contain a description of that land and a description of the general nature of the improvement or work done, for which the assessment is made, and the lien represented by such certificates shall be liens prior to all other liens and claims whatsoever on the real estate so assessed, except the lien for general taxes, and shall have equal dignity with the latter. The amount of the certificates shall be made payable to bearer, in not to exceed 15 equal annual installments, the number of such installments to be determined in each case by the city council, which, with the maximum interest rate permissible under state law or such lower rate as determined by the city council, shall be payable annually on the unpaid balance, with the proviso that in case of default in the payment of any installment, either of principle or interest, the entire unpaid balance may, without notice, be declared immediately due and payable, and may be foreclosed by suit in equity. 
(Code 1988, § 13-86) 
Sec. 74-62. - Custody of special lien certificates. 
    Special lien certificates shall be held in the custody of the city tax collector until otherwise ordered by the city council, as provided in this division. 
(Code 1988, § 13-87) 
Sec. 74-63. - Sale of special lien certificates. 
    If and when so ordered by resolution of the city council, the tax collector shall sell or dispose of any special lien certificates held by him, in such a manner as may be provided in such resolution, whether in payment for the work or improvement as a result of which such certificates were issued, or for cash. The city shall guarantee the payment of these certificates, provided that no such sale or other disposition shall be made without first giving notice thereof by publication, in at least two consecutive weekly issues of a newspaper published in the county in which the city lies; provided further that at any time up to the date of actual sale, these certificates shall be held subject to cancellation upon full payment of the unpaid balance due thereon, including accrued interest; and further provided that the amount of any such certificates so sold shall be considered a part of the bonded indebtedness of the city, or payment of which it is liable as guarantor, as though represented by actual bonds of the city, and no such sale shall be held which will increase the total of such indebtedness, including bonded indebtedness, beyond the maximum limit prescribed for bonded indebtedness. 
(Code 1988, § 13-88) 
Sec. 74-64. - Procedure in case of default. 
    The procedure in case of default in the payment of any installment, either of principal or interest, due under any special lien certificate shall be substantially the same as in case of the foreclosure of tax lien certificates. If the city, as guarantor, shall have been called upon to pay any such defaulted installment, then it shall forthwith direct the city attorney to foreclose the defaulted certificate for the full amount due thereunder, and thereafter the city shall pay each maturing installment under such certificate. Notwithstanding the sale of any such certificate, such suit may be brought by and in the name of the city in all cases where the city has been called on under its guaranty to pay any defaulted installment, and a certified copy of such certificate may be introduced in evidence in such foreclosure suit. The costs and expenses of bringing such suit, including such reasonable attorney's fees as the city may have agreed to pay, shall be considered and held an additional charge and lien, by way of penalty, against the property involved, and the city shall be entitled to recover the same in such suit. 
(Code 1988, § 13-89) 
Sec. 74-65. - Bonds may be based on special lien certificates. 
    The city council may, at its discretion, cause any special lien certificates held by the city to be deposited with the city finance director, the proceeds thereof to be thereafter held as a special bond fund, and may thereupon issue and sell bonds of the city based thereon, to an amount no greater than 80 percent of the unpaid balance still due on the certificates so deposited, provided that the maximum limit of city indebtedness prescribed in this Code shall not be exceeded by reason of such bond issue. 
(Code 1988, § 13-90) 
Secs. 74-66-74-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - QUADRANT ADDRESS SYSTEM 

Sec. 74-91. - Adopted. 
    There is adopted a quadrant address system whereby the city address number district is divided into four sections designated as north, south, east and west, for the numbering, naming and designation of existing and platted streets, alleys and public ways within the district. Names of public or private streets shall not duplicate existing or platted street names within the city or the county unless a street is a continuation of or in alignment with an existing or platted street. 
(Code 1988, § 13-111) 
Sec. 74-92. - Address numbering district established. 
(a)  For the purpose of assigning numbers to locations, the following address numbering district has been established as described: 
Start at the intersection of U.S. 98 and Yontz Road for the point of beginning, thence follow U.S. 98 south to Manecke Road; thence go west on Manecke Road to East Avenue; thence go south on East Avenue to Fort Dade Avenue; thence go west on Fort Dade Avenue to Cobb Road; thence go south on Cobb Road to S.R. 50 (Truck Route) thence continue south and easterly on S.R. 50 to Jasmine Drive; thence go north on Jasmine Drive to Mondon Hill Road; thence go east on Mondon Hill Road to McIntyre Road; thence go north on McIntyre Road to Croom Road; thence go west on Croom Road to U.S. 41; thence go north on U.S. 41 to Howell Avenue; thence go south on Howell Avenue to Yontz Road; thence go west on Yontz Road to the point of beginning. 
(b)  Parcels that front on either side of the boundaries located on U.S. 98 North and on East Avenue shall utilize the numbering of the city address system as outlined in section 74-91. Parcels that front on the other described boundaries in addition to parcels outside the district will be assigned numbers based on the county's grid address numbering system. The county grid address numbering system is adopted by reference for utilization in the assignment of numbers within the city's jurisdiction as described in this section. All other parcels within the district's boundaries shall be assigned numbers utilizing the city quadrant address numbering system. 
(Code 1988, § 13-112) 
Sec. 74-93. - Effectuating system; rules and regulations. 
    The city council or duly appointed designees are authorized to put the street numbering and designation system into effect in such stages as may be feasible and practicable and shall require any new subdivision or new streets hereafter laid out in the city's jurisdiction to bear a designation in accordance with the addressing system established hereby. The city council or other duly appointed designees are further authorized to establish and promulgate reasonable rules and regulations regarding the system hereby adopted and the means and manner of accomplishing the same. Name changes for existing streets or public ways within the city's jurisdiction shall be accomplished by resolution. An official map of the city showing the new designations shall be prepared and maintained at the city hall and copies shall be furnished to the post office and to the clerk of the circuit court. 
(Code 1988, § 13-113) 
Sec. 74-94. - Numbers to be displayed. 
(a)  Numbers assigned; type; size; placement. The owner or occupant of any building or structure, residential or commercial, shall be assigned a number under the appropriate numbering system by the building official or his designee. Only Arabic block-type numbers shall be permitted after this article is enacted with the exception of commercial structures with correct, existing numbers posted. Such numbers shall be of a minimum of three inches in height for residential and a minimum of six inches in height for commercial properties, and displayed in a conspicuous place above, on, or at the side of the building or structure, or to a permanent fixture located in the front yard of the property on which the building or structure is located. Whenever any building or structure is situated more than 25 feet from the street line, the number shall be affixed to a permanent fixture located near the front walk, driveway or common entrance to such building or structure. 
(b)  Owner to procure correct number. Whenever any building or structure shall be erected or located in the city, it shall be the duty of the owner, or the contractor on behalf of the owner, to procure the correct number designated and assigned to the building or structure and to affix the number in the manner provided in subsection (a) of this section. A certificate of occupancy shall not be issued by the city building official until the number is affixed as provided by this section. 
(c)  Number color; replacement of missing numbers. The number required to be affixed as provided in subsections (a) and (b) of this section shall be of a color that contrasts with the color of the part of the building or structure or other fixture to which the number is affixed, and shall be located in a position to be easily discernible from the street fronting the building or structure. Once the number is affixed as provided in this section, it shall be the duty of the owner or occupant of any building or structure to replace the number if the same is removed for any reason. 
(d)  Compliance. Proper compliance with any provision of this section will be determined by the building official or his designee. 
(Code 1988, § 13-114) 
Sec. 74-95. - Enforcement. 
    Whenever an official from the fire department, police department or department of development finds an address not posted according to this article, a certified letter from the city manager or his designee bearing the following information will be sent to the property owner: 
(1)  Date violation noted; 
(2)  Type of violation noted and referencing specific section of Code; 
(3)  Requirement that compliance be made within ten days from receipt of the notice; and 
(4)  Notification that penalties of $50.00 for each day the violation continued could be incurred for failure to comply by the end of the ten-day period listed in subsection (3) of this section. 
(Code 1988, § 13-115) 
Sec. 74-96. - Penalty. 
    Those found violating any portion of this article shall be guilty of a civil infraction and shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $50.00. Each day any violation of any provision of this article shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1988, § 13-116) 
Secs. 74-97-74-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - RIGHT-OF-WAY UTILIZATION REGULATION 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 74-131. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Abandoned means to give up by leaving permanently or ceasing to operate a utility facility. 
    Actual crossing operation means that phase of the work authorized by a utility permit, when the casing or carrier pipe is being placed within the right-of-way and will include preliminary work such as jacking pit construction, equipment set-up, pavement cutting for open trench crossing, etc. 
    Adequate means the ability to satisfy a requirement of the city. 
    As built means plans that show horizontal locations and vertical elevations linked to a known reference point (e.g. state plane coordinates or other acceptable reference points) including all deviations from submitted/approved plans. 
    Auxiliary lane means the portion of the roadway adjoining the traveled way which may be used for parking, access ramps, speed change turning, storage for turning, or other purposes supplementary to through traffic movement. 
    Blanket right-of-way utilization permit allows extension/attachment from existing permitted structures and facilities, utility service drops, maintenance of existing facilities, and other types of minor construction activity. 
    City means the City of Brooksville, Florida; the city council, city manager, or designee as appropriate. 
    Contractor means the individual, firm or company, contracting with a UAO or the city, furnishing materials or as a subcontractor for a prime contractor, firm or company. 
    Damage means any contact with another utility which necessitates repairs; and such repairs will be subject to supervision and inspection by the relevant UAO. 
    Emergency means a situation or occurrence of a serious nature, developing suddenly and unexpectedly, that will effect the safety of the public, or a condition that will cause damage to the city's right-of-way demanding immediate action. During a situation of this type the UAO can and may protect the public safety sooner by using equipment on hand or alternative methods other than by strictly complying with the requirements of this article. 
    Erosion control means the method used to protect city rights-of-way and any of its facilities by complying with all city, county, state and federal regulations; typically this is accomplished by placing sod in all areas disturbed by the utility construction. 
    FAC means the Florida Administrative Code. 
    FDOT means the Florida Department of Transportation. 
    FHWA means the Federal Highway Administration. 
    Inspector means an authorized representative of the city. 
    Interference with traffic means obstructing, impeding or otherwise disrupting vehicle or pedestrian movement. 
    Manhole means an opening in an underground system which workmen or others may enter for the purpose of making installations, inspections, repairs, connections and tests. 
    Mark means to indicate the horizontal location of any utility within 24 inches on either side by stakes, paint or other suitable means generally accepted within the construction industry. Upon request by the excavator for depth locations in specific areas, depth within 18 inches vertically shall be indicated. Any warning or other type facility indicator, to be installed or left after the completion of construction, shall be approved in advance by the city. 
    Median means the portion of a divided highway or street separating the traveled ways for traffic moving in opposite directions. 
    MOT means maintenance of traffic. 
    MUTCD means the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices. 
    Pavement means a paved travelway, normally including an asphaltic or concrete surface. 
    Permittee means the right-of-way user responsible for permitted maintenance or construction in the right-of-way, whether by their own employees, or by contractors and subcontractors properly licensed by the city, the county or the state. 
    Placed out of service/deactivated means the language used when UAO's are allowed to leave their facilities in place on a city right-of-way after the facility is no longer active. 
    Qualified means the ability, shown by license registration, certification, etc., to perform required tasks as needed to accomplish certain job duties. 
    Relocation means the adjustment of utility facilities required by a road or related construction project, or any city authorized or permitted work. 
    Right-of-way, public right-of-way and city right-of-way have the same meaning in these regulations. All three terms refer to a right-of-way dedicated to the public, city or county either by recorded plat, deed, easement, or prescription, and includes both city-maintained and nonmaintained city rights-of-way. The term "right-of-way," as used in this article, does not include private rights-of-way. 
    Right-of-way user means the individual, firm, company or governmental agency having a facility on, or occupying any part of, the city right-of-way under permit, agreement or any legal right to use. 
    Routine maintenance means the everyday maintenance and repair of utility facilities by a UAO. 
    Traveled way means the portion of the roadway for the movement of vehicles, exclusive of shoulders and auxiliary lanes. 
    UAO means utility agency/owner.
