ARTICLE IV. - BUSINESS LICENSE REQUIREMENTS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 78-131-78-150. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CONSTRUCTION CONTRACTORS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- State licenses for contractors, F.S. § 489.101; state licensee required to exhibit state license and pay local occupational license fee, F.S. § 489.113(4); applicants entering the business of building contracting in a city having a local board which requires a local competency examination shall comply with the local examining and licensing requirements and file with the state board evidence of successful compliance on a form prescribed by the state board accompanied by a registration fee, F.S. § 489.117. 

Sec. 78-151. - Licenses, certificates of competency and classes of building contractors. 
(a)  Licenses and certificates of competency required. It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business or act in the capacity of a building contractor within the city without having a certificate of competency issued by the state or a certificate of registration issued by the state, a county certificate of competency issued by the county, a city certificate of competency, unless particularly exempted by other provisions of this division or Code. 
(b)  Classes of building contractors. There shall be three classes of building contractors as follows: 
(1)  Class A. Those contractors qualified to construct, alter, repair, add to, subtract from or improve any building or other structure. 
(2)  Class B. Those contractors qualified to construct dwellings containing not more than two residential units, and to alter, repair, add to, subtract from or improve dwellings, and to repair commercial or industrial buildings. 
(3)  Class C. Those contractors qualified to alter, repair, add to, subtract from or improve single-family residences; these contractors may perform repairs to existing residential, commercial or industrial buildings where no change or impairment of physical structure of such building or structure is involved. 
(c)  Certificate of competency renewal and initial issue requirements. The following requirements shall apply to the renewal and the initial issuance of certificates of competency: 
(1)  Valid state registration; 
(2)  Certificate of competency card and a letter of reciprocity from the county building department; and 
(3)  Proof of liability insurance and workers compensation insurance as required by state statutes. 
(Code 1988, § 10-61; Ord. No. 757, § 3, 3-17-2008) 
Sec. 78-152. - Certificates of competency and registration of contractors. 
(a)  Issuance period, renewals and renewal fees. Every building contractor's certificate of competency shall be issued for one year from October 1 to September 30 and shall remain in force and effect for that period unless sooner cancelled, revoked or suspended. The fee for renewal shall be $30.00 for Class A general contractor, $25.00 for Class B building contractor and $20.00 for Class C residential contractor certificates of competency. 
(b)  Late renewals, fees. Certificate renewal applications received after September 30 shall be considered late and shall be subject to penalty as follows. Late certificate renewal applications received after September 30 but on or before October 31 shall be assessed a double renewal fee. Late certificate renewal applications received after October 31 but on or before January 31 shall be assessed a triple renewal fee. Certificates not renewed by February 1 may not be renewed. Entities holding such unrenewed certificates may be recertified only after establishing competency in accordance with the then-current certificate eligibility requirements including examination if applicable. 
(c)  Inactive certificates. Certificate of competency may be rendered inactive upon written request by the certificate holder. The fee for an inactive certificate shall be half of the active fee for certificates as specified by this division. 
(d)  Reactivation of certificates. Inactive certificates may be reactivated upon written request by the holding entity when accompanied by the full renewal fee specified by this division for active certificates and such other pertinent supporting information as the building official may deem necessary. Proof of insurance or bond is not required for inactive certificates. 
(e)  Registration of building contractors with certificates of competency. Before any person possessing a state certificate of competency shall carry on or engage in the business of building contracting, or construction, or labor at the trade of building construction or repair, he shall first register his name and address together with such other information as the building official may require. 
(f)  Registration of specialty contractors; additional qualifications; annual fee; renewal of registration; transfer prohibited. 
(1)  It shall be the duty of every contractor, subcontractor, independent contractor or other artificer, as herein defined, or who, by activity, shall come within the purview of this division, or other chapter of the Code, or who shall make contracts, verbal, written or otherwise, for the erection, construction, addition, repair, alteration, demolition or change of any building, structure, system or other facility, or who shall subcontract or independently contract to do or perform such services, to register with the city. Those persons, firms and corporations covered by these provisions shall include, but shall not be limited to, the following: 
a.  Concrete and masonry subcontractors. 
b.  Framing contractors. 
c.  Plaster and dry wall contractors. 
d.  Stucco, tile and stone contractors. 
e.  Heating and air conditioning contractors. 
f.  Roofing contractors. 
g.  Painting contractors. 
h.  Paving contractors. 
i.  Aluminum sales and installations. 
j.  Sign and display contractors. 
k.  Swimming pool contractors. 
l.  Cabinet sales and installations. 
m.  Utility contractors. 
n.  Mechanical contractors. 
(2)  Additional qualifications shall include: 
a.  A valid state registration. 
b.  A valid county registration and a letter of reciprocity. 
c.  Proof of liability insurance and worker's compensation insurance, as required by state statute. 
(3)  The annual fee for certificates of registration shall be set by resolution by city council. Certificates of registration shall be renewable on or before October 1 of each succeeding year. Certificates of registration shall not be transferable except as to location or principal place of business. 
(Code 1988, § 10-62) 
Sec. 78-153. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 757, § 3, adopted Mar. 17, 2008, deleted § 78-153, which pertained to occupational license required; nontransferable; certificate of competency prerequisite to issuance and derived from Code 1988, § 10-63. 
Sec. 78-154. - Contractor to save and hold harmless city. 
    By application and acceptance of a permit or license under the provisions of this division, the contractor agrees to save harmless and indemnify the city from all claims arising from accidents and damage of any character whatsoever caused by the negligence of such contractor, person, firm, corporation or association engaged in the building construction and repair business, or by any other unfaithful inadequate work done either by themselves or their agents or employees, and that such person will maintain in a safe condition for a period of one year all ditches and excavations which may be opened in the performance of any building construction and repair work, and further that all soil and other materials excavated will be replaced in as good a condition with similar materials. Where such excavation is made in any street, paved or unpaved, the word "street" as herein used shall apply also to sidewalks, curbs, gutters and street paving. 
(Code 1988, § 10-64) 
Secs. 78-155-78-170. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - ELECTRICIANS 

Sec. 78-171. - General requirements in order to engage in electrical work and electrical contracting. 
    No person shall carry on or engage in electrical work or electrical contracting in the city either as a master electrician, an employing electrician, a journeyman electrician, or an electrical contractor unless and until such person has been issued a certificate of competency or a certificate of registration by the state, a county certificate of competency and a city certificate of competency. 
(Code 1988, § 10-81) 
Sec. 78-172. - Renewal of certificate of competency. 
(a)  Every electrician's license shall be issued for one year, from October 1 expiring on September 30, and shall remain in force and effect for that period unless sooner cancelled, revoked or suspended. 
(b)  Entities holding unrenewed certificates of competency may be licensed only after establishing competency in accordance with the then current state or county certificate eligibility requirements, including examination if applicable. 
(Code 1988, § 10-82) 
Sec. 78-173. - Registration of electricians and electrical contractors. 
(a)  Before any person shall carry on or engage in the business of electrician, electrical contracting or labor at the trade of electrician, he shall first register his name and address, together with such other information as the building official may require. 
(b)  The certificate of competency shall be in the name of the firm or corporation, and shall show on its face the name of the individual upon whose competency it is issued. 
(c)  A certificate under subsection (b) of this section shall be valid only as long as the individual shall remain in or with the firm or corporation in the capacity required in subsection (b) of this section. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for the individual upon whose competency a certificate is issued to a firm or corporation to sever his active connection with the firm or corporation without notifying the building official within ten days. If such individual shall fail to notify the building official, his registration shall be revoked or suspended and he shall not be issued another for a period not to exceed one year. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any firm or corporation to fail to give notice to the building official within 48 hours after the person upon the strength of whose competency a certificate of competency was issued to such firm or corporation has severed his connections with such firm or corporation or is no longer acting in the capacity required by subsection (c) of this section. If such firm or corporation shall fail to so notify the building official within ten days, a certificate of registration shall not be issued to such firm or corporation for a period of one year after the time when such notice should have been given under this section. 
(f)  The firm or corporation to whom a certificate was issued upon the competency of an individual who is no longer acting in the capacity as required by subsection (c) of this section may, if such firm or corporation has complied with subsection (e) of this section, designate some other qualified individual without the payment of an additional fee or occupational license fee for the remainder of the license year if such individual qualifies. 
(g)  An individual upon whose competency a certificate is issued shall not, so long as that certificate is outstanding and unsurrendered, be allowed to obtain a registration for any other firm or corporation, nor to contract in his own name or any other name, nor to obtain permits for anyone other than such firm or corporation. 
(Code 1988, § 10-83) 
State Law reference- Registration requirements, F.S. § 489.513. 
Sec. 78-174. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 757, § 3, adopted Mar. 17, 2008, deleted § 78-174, which pertained to master electrician-occupational license required; nontransferable; certificate of competency prerequisite to issuance and derived from Code 1988, § 10-84. 
Sec. 78-175. - Same-Use of certificate by others; penalty. 
    No person holding a master electrician's certificate shall lend such certificate to any other person or allow any other person to do any electrical construction work under any permit taken out in his name, except certified journeymen electricians in his employ. A violation of this section shall be grounds for revocation of such person's certificate in addition to the other penalties provided for by this division. 
(Code 1988, § 10-85) 
Secs. 78-176-78-190. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - PLUMBERS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Plumbing, F.S. § 553.01 et seq.; plumbing contractor, F.S. § 489.105(3)(m). 

Sec. 78-191. - Qualifications. 
    No person shall carry on or engage in the business of plumbing in the city, either as a master plumber or employing plumber or as a journeyman plumber unless such person has been issued a certificate of competency by the state or a certificate of registration by the state and a city certificate of competency. 
(Code 1988, § 10-156) 
Sec. 78-192. - Renewal of license. 
(a)  Every plumber's license shall be issued for one year, from October 1 to September 30, and shall remain in force and effect for that period unless sooner canceled, revoked or suspended. 
(b)  The fee for renewal shall be $20.00 for all master plumber's certificates of competency and $5.00 for all journeyman plumber's certificates of competency. 
(c)  Certificate renewal applications received after September 30 shall be considered late and shall be subject to penalty as follows. Late certificate renewal applications received after September 30 but on or before October 31 shall be assessed a double renewal fee. Late certificate renewal applications received after October 31 but on or before January 31 shall be assessed a triple renewal fee. Certificates not renewed by February 1 may not be renewed. Entities holding such unrenewed certificates may be recertified only after establishing competency in accordance with the then current certificate eligibility requirements including examination if applicable. 
(d)  Certificate of competency may be rendered inactive upon written request by the certificate holder. Inactive certificates may be renewed in accordance with and be subject to the same late penalties as other certificates. Inactive certificates may be reactivated upon written request by the holding entity when accompanied by the full renewal fee specified by this section for active certificates and such other pertinent supporting information as the board may deem necessary. 
(Code 1988, § 10-157) 
Sec. 78-193. - Registration of plumbers and plumbing contractors; issuance of certificates to firms or corporations. 
(a)  Before any person required to possess a certificate of competency by this division shall carry on or engage in the business of plumbing, or plumbing contracting, or labor at the trade of plumbing, he shall first register his name and address together with such other information as the building official may require. 
(b)  The certificate shall be issued in the name of the firm or corporation, and shall show on its face the name of the individual upon whose competency it is issued. 
(c)  A certificate shall be valid for only so long as the examined individual shall remain in or with the firm or corporation in that capacity. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for the individual upon whose competency a certificate is issued to a firm or corporation to sever his active connection with the firm or corporation without first or simultaneously notifying the building official. If such individual shall fail to notify the building official within ten days after severance, his registration shall be revoked or suspended and he shall not be issued another for a period not to exceed one year. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any firm or corporation to fail to give notice to the building official within 48 hours after the person upon whose competency a certificate of competency was issued to such firm or corporation has severed his connection with such firm or corporation or is no longer acting in the capacity required by subsection (b) of this section, and if such firm or corporation shall fail to so notify the building official within ten days after severance, such registration shall be revoked and a new registration shall not be issued to such firm or corporation for a period of one year after the time when such notice should have been given hereunder. 
(f)  The firm or corporation to whom a certificate was issued upon the competency of an individual who is no longer acting in the capacity as required by subsection (b) of this section may, if such firm or corporation has complied with subsection (e) of this section, surrender such registration and designate some other qualified individual to obtain another registration without the payment of an additional fee for the remainder of the license year if such individual qualifies. 
(g)  An individual upon whose competency a certificate is issued shall not so long as the certificate is outstanding and unsurrendered be allowed to obtain a registration for any other firm or corporation, nor to contract in his own name or any other name, nor to obtain permits for anyone other than such firm or corporation. 
(Code 1988, § 10-158; Ord. No. 757, § 3, 3-17-2008) 
Sec. 78-194. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 757, § 3, adopted Mar. 17, 2008, deleted § 78-194, which pertained to master plumber; occupational license required; nontransferable; certificate of competency prerequisite to issuance and derived from Code 1988, § 10-159. 
Sec. 78-195. - Use of certificate by others; penalty. 
    No person holding a master or journeyman plumbers' certificate shall lend such certificate to any other person or allow any other person to do any plumbing or drainage work under any permit taken out in his name. A violation of this section shall be grounds for revocation of such person's registration by the building official after the hearing by the appropriate jurisdiction on the certificate of competency in addition to the other penalties provided for by this division. 
(Code 1988, § 10-160) 
Secs. 78-196-78-220. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS 

Sec. 78-221. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Fixed location means a property classified as a commercial zoning district in which the applicant has submitted his intent to transact all of his business activity from this single location. 
    Peddler, which includes transient merchant, transient vendor or itinerant merchant, means any individual, whether as owner, agent or employee, whether a resident of the city or not, traveling either by foot, automobile, truck or other type of conveyance, from place to place, from house to house, or from street to street, who engages in the temporary business of selling and delivering goods, wares or merchandise of any type within the city, or who makes sales and delivers articles to purchasers, or offers same for sale, or who, without traveling from place to place, shall sell or offer the same for sale from an automobile, truck or other vehicle or conveyance or who shall perform the above activities at a fixed location. 
    Roadway means that portion of a highway or street improved, designated or ordinarily used for vehicular traffic/travel including the shoulder and inclusive of any median area contained therein, including the entire width between the boundary lines of any roadway of whatever nature when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for the purpose of vehicular traffic. 
    Solicitor and canvasser mean any individual, whether a resident of the city or not, traveling either by foot, automobile, truck or other type of conveyance, from place to place, from house to house, or from street to street, taking or attempting to take orders for the sale of goods, wares and merchandise, personal property of any nature whatsoever for future delivery, or for services to be furnished or performed in the future, whether or not such an individual has, carries or exposes for sale a sample of the merchandise of such sale or whether he is collecting advanced payments on such sales or not, and whether for present or future delivery. 
(Code 1988, § 10-126) 
Sec. 78-222. - Persons excluded from provisions of this article requiring permit. 
    The terms of this article shall not apply to: 
(1)  Those persons soliciting votes for a political candidate or for the support of a present political issue or candidate. 
(2)  Solicitors, salesmen or agents making a call or business visit upon the express invitation, oral or written, of the inhabitant of the premises. 
(3)  Sales or solicitations at a public event after receipt of approval by the chief of police or his then designee. 
(Code 1988, § 10-127; Ord. No. 757, § 3, 3-17-2008) 
Sec. 78-223. - Permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any peddler, solicitor or canvasser to engage in such business within the city without first obtaining a permit from the city police department in accordance with the provisions of this article. All applications for permits must be submitted at least 30 days in advance of the applicant's desired start date for activities covered by this article. 
(Code 1988, § 10-128) 
Sec. 78-224. - Permitting of peddlers, solicitors or canvassers. 
    All peddlers, solicitors or canvassers shall apply to the city's police department for a permit to engage in such business. The applicant shall complete an affidavit on a form to be furnished by the city police department, which shall provide, at a minimum, the following information: 
(1)  Name and date of birth of the applicant. 
(2)  Permanent home address and full local address of the applicant. 
(3)  A brief description of the nature of the business and the goods to be sold. 
(4)  The name and address of the employer furnishing the goods to be sold. 
(5)  The name and address of any employees of the registrant who will also be soliciting or canvassing within the city. 
(6)  Door-to-door or location at which business is to be transacted; subject to meeting land use/zoning and safety regulations if set up at a fixed location. 
(7)  A statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of any crime, misdemeanor or violation of any municipal ordinance, including traffic violations, the nature of the offense and the punishment or penalty assessed therefor. 
(8)  If the business is to be transacted from a fixed location, the applicant shall submit: 
a.  A notarized letter of authorization from the owner of such property granting permission to the applicant to use the property as indicated; and 
b.  A site sketch showing pertinent information on how the applicant plans to set up this activity at the fixed location. 
(Code 1988, § 10-129) 
Sec. 78-225. - Fees. 
    Except for those individuals engaged in interstate commerce or representing religious or charitable entities, the application fee for a permit for peddlers, solicitors and canvassers shall be established by resolution of the city council. No fees shall be charged for the issuance of a permit to those individuals engaged in interstate commerce or representing religious or charitable entities. To qualify as a religious or charitable organization such organization must show it is exempted as set forth in F.S. ch. 496 as presently existing or as hereinafter amended. 
(Code 1988, § 10-130) 
State Law reference- Authority to assess regulatory fees, F.S. § 166.221. 
Sec. 78-226. - Surety payment. 
    Prior to the issuance of any permit, every applicant shall file with the chief of police a surety bond running to the city and the citizens thereof in the amount of $500.00 with surety acceptable to and approved by the chief of police conditioned that the applicant shall fully comply with the provisions of the Code of the city and the statutes of the state regulating and concerning the business of solicitors and guaranteeing to any citizen of the city doing business with the solicitor or peddler that the property purchased will be delivered according to the representations of said solicitor or peddler. Action on such bond may be brought by any citizen of the city. No surety shall be required of any individual engaged in interstate commerce. 
(Code 1988, § 10-131) 
Sec. 78-227. - Exhibition of permit. 
    All individuals coming under the provisions of this article shall carry on their person, and exhibit upon request by valid authority, a permit required by this article. 
(Code 1988, § 10-132) 
Sec. 78-228. - Issuance of permit. 
(a)  No permit shall be issued by the police department until the applicant shall have complied with all the provisions and requirements of this article. 
(b)  Before any permit shall be issued under the provisions of this article, the applicant shall have paid the required application fee as provided by resolution of the city council and shall have posted the surety bond as required in section 78-226. 
(c)  Each permit issued under the provisions of this article shall be signed by the chief of police or his designee. Each permit shall be dated as of the date of its issuance and shall state the date of its termination on the face thereof. 
(d)  Permits issued under the provisions of this article shall be valid for a time period not to exceed three consecutive calendar months. 
(e)  No peddler's, solicitor's or canvasser's permit shall be issued to a corporation, partnership or other similar legal entity. Permits shall only be issued to individual persons and shall not be assigned nor may the permit be used by any agent or representative of any permitted person. 
(Code 1988, § 10-133) 
Sec. 78-229. - Contents of permits. 
    All permits issued pursuant to the provisions of this article shall have been issued, with the applicant's indication, in writing, of full understanding to the applicable provisions of F.S. ch. 501 relating to home solicitation sales. 
(Code 1988, § 10-134) 
Sec. 78-230. - Hours of operation. 
    It shall be unlawful for any peddler, solicitor or canvasser required to be permitted by this article to engage in the business of peddling, soliciting or canvassing within the city between the hours of 6:00 p.m. and 8:30 a.m. the following morning, or at any time on Sundays, except by specific appointment with or invitation from the prospective customer. Peddlers, solicitors and canvassers operating from an approved fixed location within the city's jurisdiction are exempt from this provision. 
(Code 1988, § 10-135) 
Sec. 78-231. - Entrance to premises; request to leave residential or business premises. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any peddler, solicitor or canvasser to enter upon any residential or business premises when the same are posted with a sign stating "No Peddlers Allowed" or "No Solicitations Allowed" or other words to such effect. 
(b)  No person shall remain in or upon any residential or business premises for soliciting or peddling when the owner or occupant thereof has requested any such person to leave. 
(Code 1988, § 10-137) 
Sec. 78-232. - Solicitation on public right-of-way. 
    It is unlawful for any peddler, solicitor or canvasser to obstruct, hinder or impede the free and uninterrupted passage of any vehicle, traffic or pedestrian located in any street, sidewalk or other public place. 
(Code 1988, § 10-138) 
Secs. 78-233-78-260. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - PUBLIC SERVICE TAX 

Sec. 78-261. - Tax levied. 
(a)  There is hereby imposed and levied by the city a tax on every purchase of electricity, and metered or bottled gas (natural gas, liquefied petroleum gas or manufactured gas) within the corporate limits of the city in the amount of ten percent of the charge for each service as collected by the seller of such utility service from the purchaser. 
(b)  There is hereby imposed and levied by the city a tax on every purchase of fuel oil within the corporate limits of the city in the amount of $0.04 per gallon as sold by the seller of such product to the purchaser. 
(Ord. No. 657, § 1(14-41), 8-26-2003) 
Sec. 78-262. - Exemptions. 
    The following purchases shall be exempt from the tax herein imposed: 
(1)  The purchase of any of the services set forth in section 78-261 by any recognized church in the state for use exclusively for church purposes; 
(2)  The purchase of natural gas or fuel by a public or private utility either for resale or for use as fuel in the generation of electricity; 
(3)  The purchase of fuel oil or kerosene for use as an aircraft engine fuel or propellant or for use in internal combustion engines; and 
(4)  Purchases by the United States government, the State of Florida, and all counties, school districts, and municipalities of the State of Florida. 
(Ord. No. 657, § 1(14-42), 8-26-2003) 
Sec. 78-263. - Collection responsibilities. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of every seller of electricity, metered or bottled gas (natural gas, liquefied petroleum gas or manufactured gas), and fuel oil within the corporate limits of the city to collect from the purchaser thereof for the use of the city the tax hereby levied at the time of collecting the selling price and to report and pay over on or before the last day of each calendar month to the city all such taxes levied and collected during the preceding calendar month. It shall be unlawful for any seller to collect for any utility service taxed by this article without, at the same time, collecting the tax hereby levied, unless such seller shall elect to assume and pay such tax without collecting the same from the purchaser. Any seller failing to collect such tax at the time of collecting such utility service taxed herein, where the seller has not elected to assume and pay such tax, shall be liable to the city for the amount of such tax; provided, however, that the seller shall not be liable for the payment of such tax upon any uncollected bill. 
(b)  If any purchaser shall fail, neglect or refuse to pay for such utility service, subject to the tax herein, including the tax hereby imposed, the seller shall have the right and is hereby authorized and empowered to immediately discontinue further service to such purchaser until the tax and the seller's bill shall have been paid in full. 
(Ord. No. 657, § 1(14-43), 8-26-2003) 
Sec. 78-264. - Record keeping and remittance. 
(a)  Each seller shall keep complete records showing all sales in the city at such commodities or services, which records shall show the price charged upon each sale, the date thereof and the date of payment thereof; and said records shall be kept open for inspection by the duly authorized agents of the city during business hours on all business days; and said duly authorized agents of the city shall have the right, power and authority to make such transcripts thereof as required for the proper supervision and enforcement of the terms of this article. 
(b)  In addition to make such records available for inspection, every seller is hereby required to execute and file, not later than the last day of each month, in city hall, a statement setting forth the amount of such tax to which the city became entitled under the provisions of this article on account of bills paid by purchasers during the preceding month and, contemporaneously with the filing of said statement, shall pay the amount of such tax to the city. 
(c)  Taxes not paid within 30 days after the due date established herein shall bear interest thereafter at the rate of five one-hundredths of one percent per day. 
(Ord. No. 657, § 1(14-44), 8-26-2003) 
Sec. 78-265. - Violations; penalty. 
    Any purchaser willfully failing or refusing to pay the tax imposed in this article where the seller has not elected to assume or pay such tax and any seller violating any of the provisions or terms of this article, or any officer, agent or employee of any seller who shall violate any of the terms or provisions of this article shall, upon conviction thereof, be subject to the penalties provided in section 1-7 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 657, § 1(14-45), 8-26-2003) 
Sec. 78-266. - Notification. 
    The city shall notify in writing any known seller of items taxable under this article of any change in the boundaries of the city or in the rate of taxation. 
(Ord. No. 657, § 1(14-46), 8-26-2003) 
Sec. 78-267. - Effective term of tax. 
    The tax imposed and levied under this article shall be applicable commencing with all utility service covered by this article for every purchase made after December 31, 2003. 
(Ord. No. 657, § 1(14-47), 8-26-2003) 
Chapters 79-81 - RESERVED 
Chapter 82 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Florida Uniform Traffic Control Law, F.S. ch. 316; powers of local authorities, F.S. §§ 316.007, 316.008. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 82-1. - Speed limits. 
(a)  The speed limit at which vehicles can be driven upon the streets of the city shall be 30 miles per hour, except in the following circumstances: 
(1)  School zones. 
(2)  Where posted signs state otherwise. 
(b)  No person shall operate a motor vehicle within the city at a speed greater than is reasonable and prudent under the impending conditions and having regard to the actual potential hazards then existing, and no person shall drive any vehicle in a manner that would endanger the life or property of any other person. 
(c)  The fact the speed of a vehicle is lower than the foregoing prima facie limit shall not relieve the driver from the duty to decrease speed when approaching and crossing an intersection, when approaching and going around a curve, when approaching a hill crest, when traveling upon any narrow or winding roadway, or when special hazards exist in respect to pedestrians or other traffic or by reason of weather or highway conditions, and speed shall be decreased as may be necessary to avoid colliding with any person, vehicle or other conveyance on or entering the street in compliance with legal requirements and the duty of all persons to use due care. 
(d)  No person shall drive a motor vehicle on any street at such a slow speed as to impede or block the normal and reasonable forward movement of traffic, except when a reduced speed shall be necessary for safe operation of such vehicle or in compliance with the law. 
(e)  The city manager shall, upon the showing of an investigation by the police division satisfactory to the manager, bring before the city council recommendations concerning the need to alter existing speed limits on city streets. 
(1)  The city manager's recommendation to alter the speed limit on a given street shall he brought before the council at a regularly scheduled or special city council meeting. 
(2)  The city clerk shall have a notice published in a local newspaper that the council will consider altering the speed limits of named streets giving the proposed new speed limit and the date and time of the appropriate council meeting. Such notice should be published at least five days prior to the meeting date. 
(3)  At the scheduled meeting, public input will be accepted on the proposed speed limit changes prior to the city council voting on the recommendations of the city manager. 
(4)  Changes to the existing speed limits of city streets shall be adopted by resolution of the city council. 
(Code 1988, § 15-51) 
State Law reference- Speed generally, F.S. § 316.183 et seq.; local speed limits, F.S. § 316.189. 
Secs. 82-2-82-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PARKING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate or prohibit stopping, standing or parking, F.S. § 316.008(1)(a); parking generally, F.S. § 316.1945 et seq. 

Sec. 82-31. - Application of article. 
    This article shall apply to all vehicles, both motorized and non-motorized, parked on streets within the city limits and any city municipal parking lot. 
(Code 1988, § 15-16; Ord. No. 872, 6-15-2017) 
Sec. 82-32. - Definitions. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Commercial motor vehicle means any self-propelled or towed vehicle used on the public highways in commerce to transport passengers or cargo, if such vehicle: 
(1)  Has a gross vehicle weight rating of 10,000 pounds or more; 
(2)  Is designed to transport more than 15 passengers, including the driver; or 
(3)  Is used in the transportation of materials found to be hazardous for the purposes of the Hazardous Materials Transportation Act, as amended (49 USC 1801 et seq.). 
    Double parking means parking a vehicle alongside another vehicle already parked in a designated space. 
    Dwelling unit means any single-family home, condominium, duplex, apartment, townhouse or any other unit used as an individual or single-family dwelling. 
    Fire lane means an area designated as such, and which is reserved solely for vehicles of the fire department or any firefighting organization, police department, public works department or any other public utility vehicles used to combat a fire. 
    No parking zones means areas designated as such, where no vehicles may be parked, except public vehicles in an emergency. 
    Obstructing a driveway means parking any vehicle so that a driveway or any portion of the driveway is being obstructed from use. 
    Obstructing a garbage dumpster means parking a vehicle in any manner which will prohibit the garbage truck from picking up the dumpster and disposing of garbage. 
    Overnight parking means leaving a vehicle parked and unattended from 5:00 p.m. to 6:00 a.m. 
    Overtime parking means parking a vehicle in a space (with a designated maximum parking period) fixed by any traffic sign or other means and allowing such vehicle to remain in such parking space beyond the period of time fixed for that space. 
    Park and parking mean the standing of a vehicle, whether occupied or not, otherwise than temporarily for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading merchandise or passengers as may be permitted by law under this article. 
    Parking at a fire hydrant means parking a vehicle in front of, or within 15 feet of, a fire hydrant. 
    Parking in a handicapped zone means parking in any zone specifically marked for handicapped vehicles unless such vehicles shall be marked indicating a handicapped occupant as set forth in F.S. §§ 316.1955, 316.1956. 
    Tow truck or roll back/slide bed wrecker means any self-powered vehicle manufactured with the capability to be utilized or which is actually utilized for the purpose of towing or transporting automobiles, trucks or buses. 
    Violation shall be defined as a violation of F.S. ch. 316, or this article, which shall be specified by the police officer issuing the citation. 
(b)  Except as set forth in this section, all other definitions are defined by F.S. ch. 316. 
(Code 1988, § 15-17) 
State Law reference- Definitions, F.S. § 316.003. 
Sec. 82-33. - Parking zones. 
    The city council may approve, upon recommendation of the chief of police, parking zones regulating the place and duration of parking on streets and highways as defined by F.S. ch. 316 within the corporate limits of the city. Parking in violation of such regulations shall be a violation of this article. 
(Code 1988, § 15-18) 
State Law reference- Definitions, F.S. § 316.003. 
Sec. 82-34. - Improper parking. 
    No person shall park a vehicle in a street of the city in such a manner as to impede the lawful flow of traffic, or so the vehicle encroaches on the exterior of the marked parking or adjacent spaces. 
(Code 1988, § 15-19) 
Sec. 82-35. - Parking of trucks. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to park or stand any tractor-trailer or truck which has a manufacturer's rated load capacity in excess of 11/2 tons at any time, in any area, including the public streets and rights-of-way and private property, within the city that is zoned residential. The parking of such trucks or tractor-trailers in residential zones is declared to be a public nuisance. This prohibition shall not apply to any truck or tractor-trailer that is temporarily loading or unloading. 
(b)  No person shall park or stand any tractor-trailer or truck, which has a manufacturer's rated load capacity in excess of 11/2 tons, overnight, in any area, including the public rights-of-way and private property within and part of that area which is designated as the original Town of Brooksville per plat book 3, pages 1 and 2. 
(c)  This section shall not apply to any vehicles parked in garages, service stations, repair shops, motel parking lots, storage and parking areas of public utility facilities, storage and parking areas used in connection with and located adjacent to existing light industrial facilities, and publicly owned facilities. 
(Code 1988, § 15-20) 
Sec. 82-36. - Parking of commercial vehicles in residential areas; exceptions. 
(a)  No person shall park, or cause to be parked, or allowed to have parked, whether on private property or upon the public right-of-way, in any residentially zoned area of the city, more than one commercial vehicle for each residential dwelling owned or occupied by such person. The commercial vehicle may not have a manufacturer's rated load capacity more than 11/2 tons in weight. No person shall park a commercial vehicle in any residentially zoned area of the city unless such person owns or occupies the residential dwelling at which the vehicle is parked. 
(b)  There shall be excepted from the provisions of subsection (a) of this section: 
(1)  Any emergency vehicle or vehicle necessary for service by any public utility. 
(2)  Commercial vehicles necessary for service to any dwelling, during the time such service is actually being performed. 
(3)  Any commercial vehicle of any size which is parked in a closed garage. 
(Code 1988, § 15-21) 
Sec. 82-37. - Parking of tow trucks and wreckers in residential areas. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, his employee or agent to park, stop or have standing any tow truck or roll back/slide bed wrecker in any residentially zoned area of the city. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any owner or tenant to have parked, stopped or have standing on his residential property any tow truck or wrecker. 
(c)  Any tow truck or roll back/slide bed wrecker actually performing towing or wrecking services to any motor vehicle shall be exempt from the provisions of subsection (b) of this section during the time such services are being performed; provided, that the services are pursued in a reasonable and diligent manner. 
(d)  This section shall supersede section 82-36 in regard to all tow trucks and wreckers. 
(Code 1988, § 15-22) 
Sec. 82-38. - Forms of notifying violators of this article to appear; attachment to vehicle; response by owner or operator. 
    The chief of police of the city shall provide, in triplicate, suitable serially-numbered forms for notifying violators to appear and answer to charges of violating this article and other traffic laws and regulations of the city. Such forms shall be issued and receipted by the chief of police, his duly authorized representative or any other person acting for him. Upon any violation of this article, any police officer shall attach to the windshield of a parked vehicle a notice in accordance with this section, stating that the owner or operator is in violation of this article and that the owner or operator may, within 72 hours of the time when such notice was attached to such vehicle, pay to the city police department as a penalty for, and in full satisfaction of, such violation the sum set forth in section 82-44. The failure of such owner or operator to make such payment to the city police department within 72 hours shall render such owner or operator subject to late charges or other enumerated penalties as are set forth in this article. 
(Code 1988, § 15-23) 
Sec. 82-39. - Surcharge for late payment. 
    Any of the fines set forth in section 82-44 which are not paid within 72 hours of issuance of the citation shall be subject to a surcharge. The surcharge will equal 50 percent of the stated fine and be due and payable to the city. 
(Code 1988, § 15-24) 
Sec. 82-40. - Payment of fine without trial. 
    Any person in violation of this article who desires to pay the fine and late payment charge, if any, without resort to the courts of the state, shall pay such fine to the city at the police department or the finance department, within seven days of issuance of notices of violation. Upon payment of any fine or late charge, the city shall accept the fine and issue a receipt to the violator. The city shall keep an easily accessible record of all violations during the preceding 12 months, whether such guilt was established in court or such violator has voluntarily paid the fine or late charge. The city shall keep records and submit summarized monthly reports to the city manager of all citations issued for violations of this article and other traffic laws of the city and the state within the municipal limits of the city. The city shall also keep a record of all the fines collected by the city and of the final disposition of each violation in every case handled by the city. Such records shall be so maintained as to show all types of violations and the totals of each. 
(Code 1988, § 15-25) 
Sec. 82-41. - Unpaid parking citations. 
    If a parking violation citation remains unpaid after a seven-day period, as set forth in section 82-40, then the city shall cause a summons to be issued by the clerk of the county court. The clerk of the county court shall mail to the registered owner of the cited vehicle a summons by registered mail, setting forth a date for a hearing of the cited violation. The summons shall advise the registered owner of the right to pay the fine, surcharge or delinquency fee, or that the violator shall otherwise appear at the hearing scheduled on the summons. The party summoned shall also be advised that if the court finds the party in violation, then the party shall be required to pay the fine plus a penalty. 
(Code 1988, § 15-26) 
Sec. 82-42. - Hearing before hearing officer or judge. 
    If the registered owner fails to pay the fines, any surcharges and delinquency fees as set forth in sections 82-39 and 82-44 or upon the hearing and a finding of a violation by the hearing officer or judge, then the penalty shall be not less than $50.00 nor more than $500.00, plus all hearing and administrative costs. If the registered owner fails to appear after being summoned by registered mail, then failure to appear shall be deemed as an admission of the violation, and a judgment of fine plus costs shall be entered against the summoned party, for not less than $50.00 nor more than $500.00, plus court costs. 
(Code 1988, § 15-27) 
Sec. 82-43. - Removal of vehicle. 
    F.S. chs. 316 and 705 are adopted and incorporated in this article. In addition, the city shall have the right to cause any vehicle to be impounded if such vehicle is parked either wholly or partially in a fire lane, is double parked, parked at a fire hydrant, or parked either wholly or partially on a sidewalk of a designated and marked pedestrian crossway. Upon the removal and impoundment of such vehicle, the owner shall be entitled to possession of same upon payment of all costs of removal, storage fees and fines imposed. 
(Code 1988, § 15-28) 
Sec. 82-44. - Violation and fine schedule. 
(a)  Each of the following shall be a violation of this article, the fine for which shall be as listed: 
(1)  Overtime parking. The fine for parking overtime shall be $10.00. 
(2)  Fire lane. The fine for parking in a designated fire lane shall be $50.00. 
(3)  No parking zone. The fine for parking in a no parking zone shall be $15.00. 
(4)  Improper parking. The fine for improper parking shall be $15.00. 
(5)  Leaving keys in ignition. The fine for leaving keys in the ignition of an unattended parked vehicle shall be $15.00. 
(6)  Double parking. The fine for double parking shall be $15.00. 
(7)  Fire hydrant. The fine for parking at a fire hydrant shall be $15.00. 
(8)  Sidewalk. The fine for parking on a sidewalk shall be $15.00. 
(9)  Handicapped zone. The fine for parking in a designated handicapped zone shall be $100.00 for the first offense and $250.00 for the second offense. 
(10)  Obstructing a driveway. The fine for obstructing a driveway shall be $15.00. 
(11)  Obstructing a garbage dumpster. The fine for obstructing a garbage dumpster shall be $15.00. 
(12)  Unlawful parking of trucks. The fine for the unlawful parking of trucks shall be $50.00. 
(13)  Unlawful parking of commercial vehicles. The fine for the unlawful parking of commercial vehicles shall be $50.00. 
(14)  Unlawful parking of tow trucks and wreckers in residential areas. The fine for the unlawful parking of tow trucks and wreckers in residential areas shall be $50.00. 
(b)  If found to be in violation, the violator will be responsible to pay all hearing and administrative costs associated therewith. 
(c)  All violations as set forth in this section are noncriminal infractions. 
(Code 1988, § 15-29; Ord. No. 872, 6-15-2017) 
Secs. 82-45-82-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - NOISE FROM VEHICLES 

Sec. 82-51. - Definitions. 
    Any words or phrases used in this article, which are defined in F.S. ch. 316, shall have the same meanings, for purposes of this article, as are provided in such chapter. Rules adopted by the State of Florida, Department of Highway Safety and Motor Vehicles, defining "plainly audible" and establish standards regarding how sound should be measured by law enforcement personnel, are hereby adopted by reference for purposes of this article. 
(Ord. No. 730, § 1, 12-4-2006) 
Sec. 82-52. - Operation of radios or other mechanical sound making devices or instruments in vehicles; exemptions. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person operating or occupying a motor vehicle to operate or amplify the sound produced by a radio, audio player, or other mechanical sound making device or instrument from within the motor vehicle so that the sound is: 
(1)  Plainly audible at a distance of 60 or more feet from the motor vehicle. 
(2)  Louder than necessary for the convenient hearing by persons inside the vehicle in areas adjoining public property, public roadways, churches, schools, or hospitals. 
(b)  If a motor vehicle which is unoccupied has sound being amplified or produced by a radio, audio player, or other mechanical sound making device or instrument from within the motor vehicle so that the sound is: 
(1)  Plainly audible at a distance of 60 or more feet from the motor vehicle; 
(2)  Louder than necessary for the convenient hearing by persons inside the vehicle in areas adjoining public property, public roadways, churches, schools, hospitals; 
then the registered owner of the motor vehicle will be responsible for a violation of this section. 
(c)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to any law enforcement vehicle equipped with any communication device necessary in the performance of law enforcement duties or to any emergency vehicle equipped with any communication device necessary in the performance of any emergency procedures. 
(d)  The provisions of this section do not apply to the noise made by a horn or other warning device required or permitted by F.S. ch. 316. 
(e)  This provision shall not apply to any permitted event. 
(f)  A violation of this section is a noncriminal infraction. 
(Ord. No. 730, § 1, 12-4-2006; Ord. No. 730-A, § 1, 10-21-2013; Ord. No. 730-B, § 1, 1-6-2014; Ord. No. 730-C, § 1, 7-20-2015) 
Sec. 82-53. - Enforcement. 
    Enforcement of this article shall be in the same manner as for parking violations, as provided in sections 82-38 through 82-42 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 730, § 1, 12-4-2006) 
Sec. 82-54. - Fine schedule. 
(a)  Fines for violations of section 82-52 shall be as follows: 
(1)  For the first violation in any period of six consecutive months: $250.00; 
(2)  For a second violation in any period of six consecutive months: $500.00; 
(3)  For a third violation in any period of six consecutive months: $750.00. 
(b)  If found to be in violation, the violator will be responsible to pay all hearing and administrative costs associated therewith. 
(Ord. No. 730, § 1, 12-4-2006) 
Secs. 82-55-82-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - IMPOUNDMENT OF VEHICLES 

Sec. 82-71. - Definitions. 
    The following definitions shall apply for the purposes of this article: 
    Business days means any day, Monday through Friday, which is not designated as an official city holiday. 
    Hearing officer means the code enforcement hearing officer(s) appointed by the city council pursuant to Article VIII, Section 8-1.5(g) of the Land Development Code. 
    Owner means the person(s) or entity to whom a particular motor vehicle is registered or titled; such term shall also mean all other persons whom can be reasonably identified as having a legal interest in the vehicle including lessors, renters or lien holders. 
    Police officer means any person who is elected, appointed, or employed by the city; who is vested with authority to bear arms, and make arrests; and whose primary responsibility is the prevention and detection of crime or the enforcement of the penal criminal, traffic or highway laws of the state, county or city. This definition includes all certified supervisory and command personnel of the police department, but does not include support personnel employed by the city police department. 
    Stolen means the trespassory taking and carrying away of the tangible personal property of another with the intent to permanently deprive. 
    Vehicle means any device capable of being moved upon a public highway or public waterway and in, upon or by which any person or property may be transported or drawn upon a public highway or public waterway. 
(Ord. No. 774, § 1, 7-20-2009) 
Sec. 82-72. - Seizure and impoundment of vehicles. 
    The city may cause to be seized, removed or impounded a vehicle when: 
(1)  A police officer has probable cause to believe that the vehicle: 
a.  Was used to facilitate the commission or attempted commission of an act of prostitution, assignation or lewdness as defined in F.S. § 796.07, as amended; or 
b.  Contains any controlled substance as defined in F.S. § 893.02, as amended; or 
c.  Was used, intended or attempted to be used, to facilitate the commission of any violation of F.S. § 316.061 (leaving the scene of an accident), as amended; or 
d.  Was used, intended or attempted to be used, to facilitate the commission of any violation of F.S. § 322.34(2), as amended, driving while license suspended, revoked, canceled, disqualified (with knowledge); or 
e.  Was used, intended or attempted to be used, to facilitate the commission of any violation of F.S. ch. 893 (drug abuse, prevention and control), as amended. 
(2)  A police officer has probable cause to believe that the operator of the vehicle or other person in charge of the vehicle is incapacitated to such an extent as to be unable to provide for its custody, control or removal. 
(3)  The operator of any vehicle is taken into custody by the police department and such motor vehicle would thereby be left unattended. 
(4)  The vehicle, the continued presence of which, because of the physical location or condition of the motor vehicle poses a danger to the public safety or to the motor vehicle. 
(5)  A police officer has probable cause to believe that the vehicle was used to facilitate the commission of any violation of F.S. § 316.3045, as amended, (operation of radios or other sound making devices in vehicles) or section 82-52 (operation of radios or other mechanical sound making devices or instruments in vehicles) of the City's Code of Ordinances; provided that a motor vehicle bearing the same license plate or an owner/operator has been previously cited for a violation of F.S. § 316.3045, section 82-52, unlawful or illegal parking, or any City Code regulating parking, traffic or vehicles and the citations are outstanding for more than 30 calendar days and have not been disposed of by payment of the fine or otherwise cancelled as a result of an order by the hearing officer. 
(6)  The vehicle is unlawfully parked in violation of a provision of this Code which prohibits the parking of vehicles at the place where or time when such motor vehicle is found and a vehicle bearing the same license plate or an owner/operator has been previously cited for violations of any City Code provision regulating parking, traffic or vehicles and the citations are outstanding for more than 30 calendar days and have not been disposed of by payment of the fine or otherwise cancelled as a result of an order by the hearing officer. 
    Except that, this section shall not apply and no vehicle shall be seized or impounded pursuant to this section if a law enforcement agency seizes the vehicle pursuant to the Florida Contraband Forfeiture Act. 
(Ord. No. 774, § 2, 7-20-2009) 
Sec. 82-73. - Procedures upon seizure or impoundment. 
    Upon seizing a vehicle, the police officer or other officer or agent of the city shall: 
(1)  Arrange for the towing or removal of the vehicle; and, 
(2)  Provide written notice to any owner present, or person in control of the vehicle, of the fact of the seizure, the right to request a preliminary hearing pursuant to section 82-74 and the right to request a final hearing pursuant to section 82-75; and, 
(3)  Provide notice of seizure by hand delivery or send notice by certified mail to all other owner(s) of the vehicle at address(es) set forth in the vehicle registration, if any, within three business days of the date of seizure; and, 
(4)  Notices as required by paragraph (2) and (3) of this section 82-73 shall include the fact of the seizure, the right to request a preliminary hearing pursuant to section 82-74 and the right to request a final hearing pursuant to section 82-75. 
(Ord. No. 774, § 3, 7-20-2009) 
Sec. 82-74. - Preliminary hearing. 
    Any owner of a seized or impounded vehicle may request a preliminary hearing in accordance with the following requirements: 
(1)  Within five calendar days of receipt of the notice of seizure any owner may request a preliminary hearing by delivering to the city, at the address set forth in the notice, a written request for a preliminary hearing. The written request must be received by the city within the allotted time or the right to a preliminary hearing shall be waived. The request must include a telephone number(s) where the owner or the owner's designated agent can be telephonically notified of the date, time and location of the preliminary hearing, and the hours indicating when the owner or designated agent will be available for such telephonic notification. 
(2)  Upon timely receipt of an owner's written request for a preliminary hearing, the city shall schedule a hearing to be held within five calendar days following the date of receipt of the request, or as soon as practicable thereafter. Notice of the preliminary hearing shall be provided in accordance with notice requirements set forth in Article VIII, Section 8-1.5(g)(4) of the Land Development Code and shall include the date, time and location of the preliminary hearing. If the requesting owner fails to attend the preliminary hearing, and the hearing officer finds that the city has complied with the notice procedures, as set forth herein, then such failure shall constitute a waiver of the owner's right to a preliminary hearing. Any failure of the requesting owner to receive actual notice of the preliminary hearing shall not otherwise invalidate the administrative penalty proceedings as set forth herein. 
(3)  The preliminary hearing shall be held before a hearing officer. The sole issue to be considered by the hearing officer is whether the seizing police officer, or other officer or agent of the City, had probable cause under this section to seize and impound the vehicle. The formal rules of evidence shall not apply and hearsay evidence, including any relevant police report, is admissible. The burden of demonstrating probable cause is on the city. 
(4)  If a preliminary hearing is not requested, or if it was waived, or if the hearing officer finds that there was probable cause to seize and impound the vehicle, then the vehicle shall continue to be impounded pending final hearing or the payment of the appropriate administrative civil penalty or fine, as designated in section 82-79, together with all towing costs and storage and outstanding penalties or fines for citations previously issued. Alternatively, the owner may secure release of the vehicle by posting a cash bond, either by money order or certified check, in the amount of the administrative penalty together with all towing and storage costs and outstanding penalties or fines for citations previously issued, plus final hearing costs of $50.00. If no probable cause is found at the preliminary hearing, the vehicle shall be released to the owner as soon as practical without the imposition of an administrative fine, towing and storage costs or hearing costs. 
(Ord. No. 774, § 4, 7-20-2009) 
Sec. 82-75. - Final hearing. 
    A final hearing may be requested by any owner in accordance with the following provisions: 
(1)  The vehicle owner may request a final hearing by delivering to the city, within 15 calendar days of receipt of the notice of seizure, a request for a final hearing. The request must be delivered to the address provided in the notice of seizure and must include an address where the owner or the owner's designated agent can be notified of the date, time, and place of the final hearing. 
(2)  Upon timely receipt of a request for final hearing, the city shall schedule a hearing to be held within 30 calendar days of the receipt of the request, or as soon as practicable thereafter. The city shall provide written notice, in accordance with notice requirements set forth in Article VIII, Section 8-1.5(g)(4) of the Land Development Code, to the requesting owner at the address on the request for final hearing. The notice shall state the date, time and location of the final hearing to be conducted by the hearing officer pursuant to this section. 
(3)  If an owner fails to timely request a final hearing, or if the owner fails to attend the final hearing, and the hearing officer finds that the city has complied with the notice procedures as set forth herein, then such failure shall constitute a waiver of the owner's right to a final hearing and it shall be deemed admitted that the seized vehicle was used in violation of section 82-72. 
(4)  If not waived, the final hearing shall be held before the hearing officer. The formal rules of evidence will not apply at the final hearing and hearsay evidence shall be admissible. The city shall have the burden to prove by clear and convincing evidence that the vehicle was used as set forth in section 82-72. It shall be a defense that the vehicle was stolen at the time that it was seized and impounded; or that the owner was without knowledge as to the use of the vehicle in any violation of section 82-72. The owner of the vehicle shall have the burden to prove said defense by a preponderance of the evidence. 
(5)  If the final hearing has been waived, or if, after the hearing, the hearing officer finds by clear and convincing evidence that the vehicle was used as set forth in section 82-72, the hearing officer shall enter an order authorizing the continued impoundment of the vehicle pending payment of the appropriate administrative civil penalty prescribed in section 82-79, towing and storage costs, outstanding penalties or fines for citations previously issued and hearing costs of $50.00 or until otherwise released by the city. In the event that an owner is in possession of his or her vehicle due to a bond posted pursuant to section 82-74 and the bond amount is insufficient to satisfy the administrative civil penalty and costs identified in the hearing officer's order, the remaining balance shall be paid within five calendar days of the date of the final order. If the hearing officer finds that the city did not meet its burden of proof, or that the vehicle owner has proven by a preponderance of the evidence a valid defense as set forth in paragraph (4) above, the vehicle shall be released to the vehicle owner as soon as practicable without the imposition of an administrative penalty, towing, storage or hearing costs, and any cash bond posted shall be returned. 
(Ord. No. 774, § 5, 7-20-2009) 
Sec. 82-76. - Enforcement; sale; proceeds; lien. 
(a)  A copy of the final order issued by the hearing officer shall be recorded in the public record and, upon recording shall constitute a lien against the vehicle. The city as holder of a lien against the vehicle, to the extent the lien has not been discharged or otherwise satisfied, may enforce the lien in any manner provided by law after 90 calendar days from the date of the final order. 
(b)  If the vehicle against which the lien is created is still under impoundment 90 calendar days from the date of the final order and the owner has not satisfied the lien or the lien has not otherwise been discharged, the city may elect to sell the vehicle through a public sale or auction. 
(c)  If the custodian elects to sell the vehicle, he or she must do so at public sale by competitive bidding. Notice of the time and place of the sale shall be given to the owner and an advertisement of the sale shall be published once a week for two consecutive weeks in a newspaper of general circulation in the county where the sale is to be held. The notice shall include a statement that the sale shall be subject to any and all liens, except the city's lien. The advertisement must include a description of the vehicle and the time and place of the sale. The sale may take place no earlier than ten calendar days after the final publication. 
(d)  If the owner is absent from the sale, the proceeds of a public sale pursuant to this section, after payment and satisfaction of the city's lien and the costs of transportation, storage and publication of notice, shall be deposited with the City into an interest-bearing trust account not later than 30 calendar days after the date of sale and held there for one year. If no claim is made for these funds within a period of one year after the date of the sale, the proceeds shall become the property of the city and deposited into the appropriate city fund. 
(e)  In the event that the sale proceeds are insufficient to satisfy the amount owed pursuant to the hearing officer's final order and the costs of transportation, storage and publication of notice, the order shall constitute a lien against any real or personal property owned by the vehicle owner. Such lien shall be superior to all other liens, except a lien for taxes, and shall bear interest at the maximum rate allowed by law, as set forth in F.S. § 687.03, as amended from time to time, from the date of its filing. Upon petition to the circuit court, such order may be enforced in the same manner as a court judgment by the sheriffs of this state, including levy against the real or personal property, but such order shall not be deemed to be a court judgment except for enforcement purposes. The city attorney or his designee is authorized to foreclose any lien established hereby in the same manner as is provided by law for the foreclosure of other municipal liens or alternatively, as provided by law for the foreclosure of mortgages. No lien created pursuant to this chapter may be foreclosed on real property which is homestead under § 4, Art. X of the State Constitution. In an action to enforce an order or to foreclose on a lien as provided in this section, the city shall be entitled to recover all costs, including a reasonable attorney's fee, which it incurs thereby. 
(f)  Any vehicle not disposed by public sale shall become the property of the city and may thereafter be disposed of in accordance with the provisions of applicable law. 
(Ord. No. 774, § 6, 7-20-2009) 
Sec. 82-77. - Exceptions. 
(a)  The police chief or the city manager or their respective designees are hereby authorized to enter into settlement agreements as may be appropriate to accomplish the objectives of this article. 
(b)  Nothing herein shall prohibit the city from releasing a vehicle seized under the provisions of this article, if such release is determined to be in the best interests of the city. 
(c)  Nothing herein shall be construed to prohibit the city from enforcing the provisions of this article against a vehicle initially seized pursuant to the Florida Contraband Forfeiture Act (but not both) if in the best interest of the city. 
(d)  Nothing herein shall preclude the city from utilizing the procedures specified under state law or under Chapter 38 of the City's Code of Ordinances governing the towing, storage and liens for the removal and storage of abandoned motor vehicles. 
(Ord. No. 774, § 7, 7-20-2009) 
Sec. 82-78. - Appeals. 
    The owner of the vehicle which was seized and impounded may appeal a ruling or order of the hearing officer by proceedings in the circuit court for the county in accordance with Rule 9.190, the Florida Rules of Appellate Procedure. An appeal shall be filed within 30 calendar days of the execution of the order to be appealed. The nature of the appeal shall be from a final administrative order. 
(Ord. No. 774, § 8, 7-20-2009) 
Sec. 82-79. - Administrative civil penalties and fines. 
    The following penalties and fines apply: 
(1)  A first violation shall be subject to an administrative civil penalty of $200.00 plus all towing and storage fees as well as any applicable hearing costs; and any other applicable penalties or fines provided for in the City's Code of Ordinances. 
(2)  A second violation shall be subject to an administrative civil penalty of $250.00 plus all towing and storage fees as well as any applicable hearing costs; and any other applicable penalties or fines provided for in the City's Code of Ordinances. 
(3)  A third violation shall be subject to an administrative civil penalty of $500.00 plus all towing and storage fees as well as any applicable hearing costs; and any other applicable penalties or fines provided for in the City's Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 774, § 9, 7-20-2009) 
Chapters 83-85 - RESERVED 
Chapter 86 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes:

State Law reference- Municipal Home Rule Powers Act, F.S. ch. 166; municipal public works, F.S. ch. 180; public utilities, F.S. ch. 366; water and wastewater systems, F.S. ch. 367; water resources, F.S. ch. 373; drinking water, F.S. § 403.850 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 86-1. - Utility system defined. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the term "utility system" shall mean the total city-owned or city-operated water, sanitary sewer and reclaimed water systems. 
(Code 1988, § 17-1; Ord. No. 875, § 11, 9-18-2017) 
Sec. 86-2. - Application of chapter throughout service area. 
    All provisions of this chapter which apply within the city limits, including mandatory connection requirements, shall apply in the same fashion throughout the entire city service area, except for those which specifically differentiate between customers, service and rates inside city limits and outside city limits. 
(Ord. No. 651, § 3, 3-17-2003) 
Sec. 86-3. - Permit required for all connections to water, sanitary sewer and reclaimed water systems. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person either inside or outside the corporate limits of the city to tap, cut in, connect or in any way use any line, branch or part of either the water, sanitary sewer or reclaimed water systems of the city without a written permit issued by the city authorizing the same, and then such connections shall be made only under the direction and supervision of the city. No permit to use the sanitary sewer system shall be issued for any location, unless such location shall be furnished by the city and be a current water customer of the city. 
(b)  Any person who is convicted of violating any of the provisions of this section shall be liable for all costs attributable to the correction of such tampering, including legal fees. The city may commence an action for appropriate legal or equitable relief in a court of competent jurisdiction to enforce the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1988, § 17-2; Ord. No. 875, § 12, 9-18-2017) 
Sec. 86-4. - Crossing private property of another person to make connection. 
    This chapter shall not be construed to require or entitle any person to cross the private property of another to make any sewer, water or reclaimed water connection. 
(Code 1988, § 17-3; Ord. No. 875, § 13, 9-18-2017) 
Sec. 86-5. - Connecting old plumbing. 
    Whenever it is desirable to connect old plumbing within the city to the sewer main or water line, the owner or plumber contemplating doing such work shall notify the city utilities division, which will inspect the old plumbing and notify the owner or plumber what alterations will be necessary to place the old plumbing in an acceptable condition for such connection. Any owner or plumber who shall make any connection without the approval of the utilities division shall, upon conviction, be subject to the penalties provided in this chapter. 
(Code 1988, § 17-4) 
Sec. 86-6. - Owner's responsibility for maintenance of plumbing system. 
    The owner of the property shall be responsible for maintaining and keeping clean the water, sewer and reuse water lines leading and connecting from the plumbing system to the city distribution lines and sewer mains. 
(Code 1988, § 17-5; Ord. No. 875, § 14, 9-18-2017) 
Sec. 86-7. - Dedication of water and sewer facilities to city required upon demand. 
    In those instances where a centralized water supply and distribution system, a central sewage collection and treatment system, or a reclaimed water system are required to be provided, such water, sewer or reclaimed water facilities shall be dedicated to the city so that the city will become the owner of such systems upon the request of the city for such facilities to be conveyed to it. The dedication of the water, sewer or reclaimed water facilities shall be made either by the inclusion on the face of the record plat of a dedication substantially in the form set out in Exhibit A below or by the entry into a contract or agreement between the developer and the city providing for the conveyance of the facilities. The construction of any such water supply and distribution or central sewage collection and treatment, or reclaimed water system shall meet or exceed any specifications or requirements established by the city by resolution for the construction of any such system to be dedicated to the city.

(Code 1988, § 17-6; Ord. No. 875, § 15, 9-18-2017) 
Secs. 86-8-86-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - WATER 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 86-41. - Connections with waterworks system. 
    Within one year after notification by the city that the same is available in a public right-of-way or easement abutting a lot or parcel of land, the owner of such lot or parcel of land within the city, shall connect or cause the plumbing of any building thereon to be connected with the municipal waterworks system of the city and use the facilities of such system. All such connections shall be made in accordance with the rules and regulations which shall be adopted by resolution from time to time by the city council, which rules and regulations shall provide for a charge for making any such connections in such reasonable amount as such council may fix and determine by resolution. 
(Code 1988, § 17-26; Ord. No. 653, § 1, 4-7-2003) 
Sec. 86-42. - Extensions of water service-Application. 
    Any person desiring to procure water service from the city, whether within or outside the city, shall make a written application to the city stating the purpose for which such service is required, giving the location and a definite description of the property to be served, the type of line to be laid, and any other information which will be of aid to the city in determining the necessity thereof, or any additional information required by the city. The application shall be accompanied by a plat showing the route along which such line is to be extended or laid, and where the connection with the city's existing line will be made. 
(Code 1988, § 17-27) 
Sec. 86-43. - Same-Applicant to convey easement for maintaining meter. 
    Before any applicant residing outside the city shall be granted the service for which application is made, he shall deliver to the city a deed of conveyance of easement of right-of-way for maintaining the meter. 
(Code 1988, § 17-28) 
Sec. 86-44. - Delinquent customer turning on water. 
    No person whose water bill is delinquent shall connect to, turn on, cut into, interconnect or use in any manner, the water supply of the city. 
(Code 1988, § 17-29) 
Sec. 86-45. - Tampering with meter. 
    No unauthorized person shall in any manner tamper with any water meter valve or service line which is the property of the city. 
(Code 1988, § 17-30) 
Secs. 86-46-86-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 1.1. - CITY WATER REUSE 

Sec. 86-51. - Short title. 
    This division shall be known as the City of Brooksville Reuse Water Ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 875, § 1, 9-18-2017) 
Sec. 86-52. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when and if used, shall have the meaning ascribed to them, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Applicant shall mean a potential developer, customer or authorized agent of a potential developer or customer where reclaimed water may be used. 
    Application shall mean the written instrument by which a developer or a customer applies for reclaimed water service of any sort. 
    City shall mean the City of Brooksville, Florida. 
    City manager shall mean the city manager or the city manager's designee. 
    Connection charge shall mean the charge established by the city for making the actual physical connection to the reclaimed water system. 
    Construction cost shall mean the cost to a developer, for the design and construction of all facilities as required to receive reclaimed water from the city. 
    Cross-connection shall mean a physical connection or arrangement that could allow the movement of fluids between the potable water system and any other piping system, such as the reclaimed water system. Any arrangement of pipes, fittings, fixtures or devices that connects a non-potable system to a potable system through which backflow could occur is a cross-connection. 
    Customer or consumer shall mean any individual, corporation, partnership, firm, or association that receives reclaimed water service from the city.
