    Developer shall mean any individual, corporation, partnership, firm, or association developing a property or properties for resale, rental, or lease, at or to which reclaimed water service is to be provided by the city and who shall have the legal right to negotiate for said service, and, where applicable, shall mean any individual, corporation, partnership, firm, or association applying for the extension of reclaimed water mains, sewers, or force mains in order to serve a certain property. 
    Development shall mean any proposed change in land use that alters the demands for water, wastewater, or reclaimed water services. 
    Director shall mean the director of the public works department for the City of Brooksville, Florida or his designee. 
    Discontinuation of service shall mean cessation of reclaimed water service or an appropriate method to ensure that no service of reclaimed water can be received. 
    Effluent shall mean sewage, water, or other liquid after some degree of treatment, flowing out of any treatment device or facilities. 
    Operation and maintenance shall mean the process and act of keeping all facilities for supplying reclaimed water in normal operation and in a good state or repair including the replacement of said facilities when necessary. 
    Plumbing shall mean all pipes, fittings, and appurtenances on the customer's side of the property line or outside easement areas. This includes the property owner's extension from all service laterals up to and including the house plumbing. 
    Point of connection shall mean a point of entry given by the city to a customer/developer for the customer's/developer's point of utility connection into the city's wastewater collection or transmission system; and or, the point at which the customer/developer receives reclaimed water service. 
    Reclaimed water shall mean domestic wastewater that has received at least secondary treatment, filtration, and high level disinfection as defined by the Florida Department of Environmental Protection and is reused after flowing from a wastewater treatment facility. 
    Reclaimed water distribution system shall mean facilities consisting of, but not limited to, distribution mains, valves, and appurtenances used to distribute reclaimed water to customers. 
    Reclaimed water facilities shall mean all facilities required for the production, storage, commission, distribution, and use of reclaimed water. 
    Reuse shall mean the deliberate application of reclaimed water in compliance with rules of the Florida Department of Environmental Protection, for a beneficial purpose, including irrigation. 
    Reuse system shall mean those facilities located downstream of the service connection for the purpose of practicing reuse. 
(Ord. No. 875, § 2, 9-18-2017) 
Sec. 86-53. - Source of reclaimed water. 
    The source of reclaimed water is the city's William S. Smith Water Reclamation Facility. The facility provides highly treated reclaimed water that meets the requirements and all applicable rules of the state department of environmental protection and other regulatory agencies having jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 875, § 3, 9-18-2017) 
Sec. 86-54. - Administration and availability of service. 
(a)  The distribution of reclaimed water shall be administered by the city public works department. The city manager is responsible for the development and promulgation of the necessary rules and regulations for the administration and enforcement of the distribution of reclaimed water to customers and developers. 
(b)  The existence of a reclaimed water main adjacent to or near the premises of an applicant for the service does not necessarily mean that service is available to that location. The director shall make a determination of reclaimed water availability based on total system demand, specific transmission/distribution capabilities within the subject project area, and the estimated cost of providing reclaimed water service to the subject project area. The city shall reserve the right to refuse to extend service based on a use detrimental to the system, inadequate supply of reclaimed water, or for any other reason that, in the judgment of the director, will cause the extension not to be of benefit to the city. 
(Ord. No. 875, § 4, 9-18-2017) 
Sec. 86-55. - Application required. 
    No person shall use the city's reclaimed water system without first making written application for such service to the city and paying all costs, charges, fees and deposit incident thereto. Such applications shall be in the form of a utility service agreement (USA) between the applicant and the city, to abide by all provisions of this ordinance and such applicable rules of the city in regard to the use of its reclaimed water systems as may from time to time be operative and effective. Applications for service by firms, partnerships, associations and corporations shall be tendered only by their duly authorized agents, and the official title of such parties shall be signed to the USA. 
(Ord. No. 875, § 5, 9-18-2017) 
Sec. 86-56. - Construction of new reclaimed water facilities by a developer. 
(a)  All reclaimed and/or reuse water facilities shall be designed and constructed in accordance with applicable federal, state, county and city policies, standards, and specifications. 
(b)  Each new development within the areas so identified in the reuse water service area by the city shall include a reuse water distribution system as a condition of wastewater service, provided construction of the reuse water distribution system is deemed to be in the best interest of the city as determined by the director and as noted on the plat. 
(c)  The developer shall construct the reuse water distribution system and all facilities necessary to extend city transmission mains from the stipulated point of connection, or receiving pond to the development. Subject to approval by the city, temporary provisions may be made to utilize ground or potable water until such time that the city is capable of supplying reclaimed water. 
(d)  New industries and other large water users with a substantial water demand shall evaluate the feasibility of utilizing reclaimed water, and provide the city with such written application. 
(e)  Reclaimed water line extension costs shall be borne by the person applying for such service unless the city has agreed to participate in a portion of the costs as provided for by Section 86-289 of the Brooksville Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 875, § 6, 9-18-2017) 
Sec. 86-57. - Use of reclaimed water. 
(a)  All uses of reclaimed water for reuse purposes shall be in accordance with applicable rules of Florida Administrative Code 62-610 "Reuse of Reclaimed Water and Land Application," and the Florida Department of Environmental Protection, and other regulatory agencies having jurisdiction. Applicable state mandated signage indicating reclaimed water is in use, must be posted at the receiving pond(s), common areas, landscaped areas, indicated on scorecards, and golf course(s). 
(b)  The city's public works department will monitor reclaimed water connections so as not to exceed the capacity of the system or the disposal site. It is the intent of the city to maximize the use of reclaimed water, and to provide service to as many customers as practical; however, at times, due to availability or capacity limitations, it may be necessary to limit a customer's use of reclaimed water. The city makes no representation as to the availability or implementation of reclaimed water services within, or outside of, the city's service area. Furthermore, nothing in this ordinance shall be construed to create a debt or general obligation of the city or a pledge of the full faith and credit or taxing power of the city. 
(c)  The city reserves the right to temporarily discontinue service to any portion of, or the entire, reclaimed water system as deemed necessary by the director. 
(d)  The city reserves the right to establish reclaimed water supply schedules. 
(e)  All uses of reclaimed water shall follow and be in accordance with the city's cross-connection control program. Backflow devices must be in full conformance with the American Water Works Association (AWWA) Standard C506-69 or latest version, and be approved by the city's public works department. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful for any person(s) to connect or cause to be connected to the city's potable water pipes, by any means whatsoever, any pipes containing reuse water or any water supply other than the potable water supply of the city's potable water distribution system per Florida Administrative Code 62-610.469 "Application/Distribution Systems and Cross-Connection Control." 
(g)  Reclaimed water shall not be used for body-contact recreation (including swimming pools, spas and the like), cooking or drinking, or irrigating vegetable and herb gardens (unless a drip or bubbler system is used). 
(Ord. No. 875, § 7, 9-18-2017) 
Sec. 86-58. - Inspections. 
(a)  The applicant shall grant or cause to be granted to the city without cost all rights, easements, permits and privileges which are necessary for rendering of reclaim water service to the property. Duly authorized employees of the city shall have access at all reasonable hours to the premises of the applicant for the purpose of installing or removing any of its property, examining pipes or fixtures, or for any purpose incidental to the rendering of reclaimed water service. 
(b)  The city reserves the right to make periodic inspections during normal working hours of the irrigation system to ensure the safe and proper use of reclaimed water, according to state regulatory requirements, where reclaimed water is used for irrigation purposes. 
(c)  In order to ascertain compliance with the provisions of state regulatory requirements, the city reserves the right to inspect, secure, and/or disconnect any and all devices wherever located that connect to or control any discharge from a reclaimed water distribution system. The city also reserves the right to inspect properties where reclaimed water is not connected, but is available or "on site." 
(Ord. No. 875, § 8, 9-18-2017) 
Sec. 86-59. - User rates and service charges. 
    The city council may establish, by resolution, appropriate fees or charges for connection to, and use of, reclaimed water. Rates and charges by classification for the use, and availability, of the city's reclaimed water system inside, and outside, the city limits may be adjusted annually, with respect to the effective rates for reclaimed water service. 
(Ord. No. 875, § 9, 9-18-2017) 
Sec. 86-60. - Maintenance. 
(a)  The property owner or customer shall be responsible for the maintenance of all water reuse lines and appurtenances on the property served by the city. 
(b)  The city shall make a reasonable effort to inspect and keep its own facilities in good repair, but assumes no liability for any damage caused by the system that is beyond the control of normal maintenance or due to situations not previously reported to the city. 
(c)  All facilities up to the point of connection to the customer's facilities that have been accepted by the city shall become the property of the city and will be operated and maintained by the city. No person shall perform any work, or be reimbursed for any work or in connection with any work on the system, unless written authorization from the city is received prior to the start of construction. 
(d)  The city shall not be liable for any damage resulting from the failure of any reuse water pond, service pipe or cock, or by discontinuing the operation of its reclaimed water collection, treatment and distribution facilities for repairs, extensions or connection, or from the accidental failure of the reuse water facility from any cause whatsoever. In cases of emergency the city may restrict the use of its reclaimed water system in any reasonable manner for the protection of the city and its reclaimed water system. 
(Ord. No. 875, § 10, 9-18-2017) 
DIVISION 2. - METERS 

Sec. 86-61. - Required. 
    Every person who receives his water supply from the city shall have a meter installed upon the line furnishing such water. No connection shall be made to any privately owned line connected to the city water supply unless and until permission is granted by the city and a water meter has been installed. 
(Code 1988, § 17-46) 
Sec. 86-62. - Installation by city; fees. 
    Every residential and commercial customer's service shall be provided with a curb stop and meter box at the curb, sidewalk or property line, as appropriate. Upon payment to the city of the sums required under the city's water extension policy, the city shall furnish all labor and materials to make water service available at the customer's property line. In addition, each applicant for water service, whether inside or outside the corporate limits of the city, shall pay to the city, prior to the issuance of a building permit, a water service installation fee. The city council shall, by resolution, fix the water service installation fee schedule required herein. 
(Code 1988, § 17-47) 
Sec. 86-63. - Oversize meters. 
    Requests for meters larger than two inches shall be referred to the city manager who will establish the installation charges. 
(Code 1988, § 17-48) 
Sec. 86-64. - Use of fees; installation by licensed plumber. 
    Installation fees are for setting the water meter and shall be in addition to any impact fee levied by the city. Any installation or connection to the city's water system, if not made by city personnel, shall only be made by a licensed plumber. The city reserves the right to stipulate whether water meters and associated appurtenances shall be installed by the city or owner. Should it be determined that installation by the owner would be more appropriate, then a contractual agreement will be executed to this effect and such fees as have been stipulated in this division for such installation shall be waived. 
(Code 1988, § 17-49) 
Sec. 86-65. - Reimposition of installation fees. 
    Water service installation fees, as provided in this division, shall be reimposed in the event of the discontinuance of the water account where such meter is located, or where the water meter has been removed from the premises. 
(Code 1988, § 17-51) 
Sec. 86-66. - Additional fee for expansion of capacity for consumption. 
    An additional water service installation fee shall be imposed against any nonresidential facility or building, where the same is expanded or otherwise increased in capacity, so that the number of equivalent residential units (ERU's) therein are increased beyond the immediately pre-existing equivalent residential units (ERU's) capacity thereof. Equivalent residential units (ERU's) and equivalent living units (ELU), wherever found or used in this Code, are deemed, defined and determined to be synonymous in definition, application and usage. 
(Code 1988, § 17-52) 
Sec. 86-67. - Service installation fees and impact fees differentiated. 
    Water and sewer service installation fees, sometimes referred to as hookup fees in other pertinent sections of this Code, established by the city council shall be uniform, and based upon the then current average costs of tapping the main, running the service line to the applicant's property line, and setting the meter if required. Water and sewer installation fees or charges are not included in the impact fee described in section 86-281 and other pertinent sections of this Code, and shall be paid directly to the division of finance, utilities billing office, city hall, at the time commencement is requested for each service installation. 
(Code 1988, § 17-53) 
Sec. 86-68. - Customers supplying water to others without meters. 
    No person who obtains water from the city reservoir shall furnish water to renters, lessors and others of similar capacity without the installation of a water meter. 
(Code 1988, § 17-55) 
Sec. 86-69. - Use of master meters restricted. 
    Master meters may be permitted at the discretion of the city for apartment houses, mobile or modular home parks, condominiums, apartment villas and other multiple-dwelling residences provided the meter size is sufficient to meet the city's minimum flow requirements. 
(Code 1988, § 17-56) 
Sec. 86-70. - Installation for commercial users. 
(a)  All billing for commercial users shall be based on the meter installed for the building occupied. One bill shall be prepared for each meter and the bill shall not exceed the charge on the basis of the water actually used, calculated for each meter. There shall be no multiplication or add-on of the actual bill for each meter regardless of how many businesses are served by the meter. 
(b)  The term "unit" shall mean a meter and shall be applicable only to nonresidential dwelling units. 
(Code 1988, § 17-57) 
Secs. 86-71-86-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - IRRIGATION METERS 

Sec. 86-81. - Irrigation only meters. 
(a)  Service request. Existing water and sewer customers of the city may apply for installation of an irrigation meter at the city hall customer service department and shall complete the form for such service as shall be required by the department. Installation fees for irrigation meters shall be established by the city council by resolution. Irrigation meters shall be the same size as the existing water meter for individually metered residences. For businesses or master metered entities, irrigation meters will be sized by the public works department on a case by case basis. The terms of sections 86-62, 86-63, and 86-65-86-70 apply equally to irrigation only meters. 
(b)  Installation. Irrigation only meters and an approved backflow prevention device may be installed by the city or by the customer through the use of a plumber licensed to do business in the county. In all cases, parts and materials will be provided by the city. If an installation is performed by the customer, the installation fees shall be reduced to the cost of parts and materials. 
(c)  Backflow prevention device. Once an irrigation only meter is installed, it will not be connected to the city water system until the customer has the backflow prevention device tested by a person who has a current backflow prevention assembly testing certificate from a course endorsed by the Florida Section of the American Water Works Association and said tester certifies to the city that the device is properly operating. 
(d)  Maintenance, testing and certification of backflow prevention device. Once an irrigation meter is installed and has been turned on by the city, maintenance of the backflow prevention device and periodic testing and certification of proper operation, as provided for by resolution of the city council, shall be the responsibility of the customer. An irrigation only meter is subject to being disconnected at any time if the backflow prevention device has not been recertified when required or is not operating properly, as determined by the city. 
(Ord. No. 663, § 1(17-61), 2-2-2004) 
Sec. 86-82. - Limitations on use of irrigation meters. 
(a)  Water from irrigation meters shall only be used for irrigation, filling of swimming pools, and other uses which do not return the used water to the city's wastewater system. 
(b)  Any use of water from an irrigation meter which returns the used water to the city's wastewater system shall be a misdemeanor subject to the provisions of sections 1-7 and 1-8 of this Code. Any such unauthorized use of irrigation water from an irrigation only meter shall also be grounds for the city's discontinuance of irrigation only service. 
(Ord. No. 663, § 1(17-62), 2-2-2004) 
Sec. 86-83. - Monthly charges. 
    Monthly rates and fees for water service through irrigation only meters shall be established by the city council by resolution. 
(Ord. No. 663, § 1(17-63), 2-2-2004) 
DIVISION 4. - CROSS CONNECTION CONTROL 

Sec. 86-84. - General provisions. 
(a)  Title. This ordinance shall be known as the City of Brooksville "Cross Connection Control Ordinance." 
(b)  Purpose and intent. 
(1)  This ordinance is enacted under the home rule power of the city to ensure the health, safety, and general welfare of the users of the city water service area by protecting the public potable water supply from the possibility of contamination or pollution by isolating actual or potential cross connections in the water distribution system. 
(2)  In compliance with the Federal Safe Drinking Water Act, the city has been designated to enforce state and federal regulations. 
(3)  This designation requires the city to develop and implement a cross connection control program which will systematically and effectively prevent the contamination or pollution of the city's water distribution system. 
(c)  Applicability. This ordinance shall apply to all water consumers and all properties connected to the city's water distribution system. 
(d)  Responsibility. The city shall be responsible for the protection of the public potable water distribution system from contamination or pollution due to the backflow of contaminants or, pollutants through the water service connection. If, in the judgment of the city's public works department an approved backflow prevention assembly is required for the safety of the water system, the public works department shall give written notice to the consumer to install an approved backflow prevention assembly on his/her premises. The consumer shall immediately install such approved assembly at his/her own expense; and, failure, refusal, or inability on the part of the consumer to install, have tested, and maintain said assembly shall constitute grounds for discontinuing water service to the premises until such requirements have been satisfactorily met. If water service is discontinued, the consumer will be subject to all charges to reinstate service. 
(Ord. No. 834, § 1, 1-7-2013; Ord. No. 834-A, § 1, 7-15-2013) 
Sec. 86-85. - Definitions. 
    Approved cross connection control measure shall reference an air-gap separation, a double check-valve assembly, a reduced-pressure principle backflow prevention assembly or other backflow prevention assemblies or methods that meet the requirements of state and federal regulations. 
    Auxiliary water supply shall mean any water supply on or available to the premises other than the water purveyor's approved public potable water supply. These auxiliary water supplies may include other potable water supplies, wells, ponds, pools, canals, receiving tanks, retention areas, reclaimed or reuse water supply, or any other natural or manmade water source. 
    Backflow shall mean the undesirable reversal of water flow or mixtures of water and other liquids, gases or other substances into the distribution pipes of the potable water system from any source or sources as defined by state and federal regulations. 
    Backflow prevention assembly shall mean an assembly or device that has been manufactured in full conformance with American Water Works Association (AWWA) Standard C506-69 or latest version, and be approved by the city's public works department. Backflow prevention assemblies must also meet the laboratory and field performance specifications of the Foundation for Cross Connection Control and Hydraulic Research of the University of Southern California, or other approved agency and shall also meet the requirements of state and federal regulations. 
    Backflow prevention assembly type shall mean any effective assembly used to prevent backflow into a potable water system. The type of device or assembly used shall be based on the degree of hazard either existing or potential. Acceptable types are: 
 Double check valve assembly; 
 Double detector check valve assembly; and 
 Reduced pressure principle assembly. 
    Certified backflow prevention assembly tester shall mean a person who can prove competency in testing backflow prevention assemblies to the satisfaction of the city's public works department. The tester shall have attended and successfully completed an AWWA approved course for backflow prevention assembly testers, or a similar course endorsed by the AWWA, or other programs or training acceptable to the city's public works department. A certified backflow prevention assembly maintenance and repair specialist as defined herein can also perform testing. 
    Certified backflow prevention assembly maintenance and repair specialist shall mean a person who can prove competency in repairing backflow prevention assemblies to the satisfaction of the city's public works department. The maintenance and repair specialist shall have attended and successfully completed an AWWA approved course for backflow prevention, assembly maintenance and repair, or a similar course endorsed by the AWWA. All backflow prevention assembly maintenance and repair specialists shall be licensed plumbers registered with the city's building department, or other programs or training acceptable to the city's public works department. 
    City shall refer to the designees having authority to enforce rules and regulations as set forth by the city in accordance with state and federal requirements for protecting the city's public water supply from a cross connection. 
    Consumer shall mean the property owner, user or customer who receives water from the city's potable water system. 
    Cross connection shall mean a connection or potential connection between any part of a potable water system and any other environment containing other substances in a manner that, under any circumstances would allow such substances to enter the potable water system. Other substances may be gases, liquids, or solids, such as chemicals, waste products, steam, water from other sources (potable or non-potable), or any matter that may change the color or add odor to the water. 
    Double check valve assembly shall mean an assembly consisting of two internally loaded check valves, either spring loaded or internally weighted, installed as a unit between two tightly closing resilient-seated shutoff valves and fittings with properly located resilient-seated test cocks. This assembly shall only be used to protect against a nonhealth hazard. 
    Double detector check valve assembly shall mean a specifically designed assembly composed of an approved double check valve assembly with a specific bypass water meter and an approved double check valve assembly all properly sized. The meter shall register accurately for low flow rates and shall total all flows. This assembly shall be permitted on fire lines only to protect against a non health hazard. 
    Health hazard shall mean an actual or potential threat of contamination to the public potable water system that could cause illness or such effects. 
    High-risk shall mean any residence, facility or business where backflow into the potable water system would be considered a health hazard. 
    Low-risk shall mean any residence, facility or business where backflow into the potable water system would be considered a non health hazard with the potential to become a health hazard. 
    Non health hazard shall mean an actual or potential threat of contamination to the public potable water system that would not be a health hazard, but would constitute a nuisance or be aesthetically objectionable. 
    Reduced pressure principle backflow prevention assembly shall mean an assembly containing two independently acting approved check valves together with a hydraulically operating, mechanically independent pressure differential relief valve, located between the check valves and at the same time below the first check valve. These units are located between two tightly closing resilient-seated shutoff valves as an assembly and equipped with properly located resilient-seated test cocks. This assembly shall be designed to protect against a health hazard. 
    Reuse water shall mean the deliberate application of reclaimed water; water that has received at least secondary treatment and basic disinfection from a wastewater treatment facility. 
(Ord. No. 834, § 2, 1-7-2013; Ord. No. 834-A, § 2, 7-15-2013) 
Sec. 86-86. - Technical reference. 
    Technical issues, references and applications not more specifically covered in this ordinance will be subject to the recommendations and specifications contained in the American Water Works Association, Manual of Water Supply Practices, M14, Recommended Practice for Backflow Prevention and Cross Connection Control or derivatives thereof. 
(Ord. No. 834, § 3, 1-7-2013; Ord. No. 834-A, § 3, 7-15-2013) 
Sec. 86-87. - Cross connection with private or reuse water supply prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to connect or cause to be connected to the city's water pipes, by any means whatsoever, other pipes containing water from any water supply other than the potable water supply of the city's water distribution system. 
(b)  If any person shall connect or cause to be connected to the city's water supply other than the supply of potable water furnished by the city, and also have upon the same property a water supply furnished by any other source, the property shall have and is hereby required to have a dual system of pipes, one system of pipes being for potable water supplied by the city, and the other system of pipes being for the supply of water from the private or reuse supply, and it shall be unlawful for the two systems to be connected together in any manner whatsoever. 
(c)  Any property connected to the city water lines and that also has an auxiliary water supply other than the supply of potable water furnished by the city shall have a backflow prevention assembly installed, in accordance with this ordinance. 
(d)  The city may adopt policies to regulate cross connections and shall enforce such adopted policies as if fully set out herein. 
(Ord. No. 834, § 4, 1-7-2013; Ord. No. 834-A, § 4, 7-15-2013) 
Sec. 86-88. - Backflow prevention assemblies. 
(a)  Each single-family residence, multi-family residence not individually metered, nonresidential or commercial premises connected to the city water lines where a potential cross connection exists, shall have a backflow prevention assembly installed, in accordance with the city's specifications, inspection, and approval. Any such backflow prevention assembly shall be operated, maintained and tested by the consumer in accordance with city policies and may be inspected at any time by the city. 
(b)  Several kinds of premises fall into the classification of a health hazard and require premises isolation from the city's potable water system by means of a backflow prevention assembly and some are noted as follows: 
 Premises with an auxiliary water supply; 
 Hospitals, mortuaries, medical / dental clinics and so forth; 
 Laboratories; 
 Sewage treatment plants and sewage pump stations; 
 Food and beverage processing plants; 
 Chemical plants using a water process; 
 Metal plating plants; 
 Car washing facilities; and commercial laundry facilities; 
 Premises with reuse water systems; 
(c)  Notice of time limit. In the event that any consumer does not install the backflow prevention assembly required hereunder, or whenever the city's public works department reasonably determines that a hazard to public health and safety exists by virtue of the absence of such backflow prevention devices at any establishment or premises, the consumer shall be required to install an appropriate backflow prevention assembly for the protection of the potable water system. Written notice of the requirement to install a backflow prevention assembly shall be mailed to the consumer's address as it appears on the city records. The notice shall state: 
(1)  The fact that a backflow prevention assembly is required. 
(2)  The type of backflow prevention assembly required to be installed. 
(3)  The fact that the assembly is required to be installed within the designated time limit from the date of the notice. 
(4)  The date that an inspection of the premises will occur to verify the installation of the backflow prevention assembly. 
(5)  The date on, and after, which delivery of water shall be discontinued to the premises if the assembly has not been installed. 
(Ord. No. 834, § 5, 1-7-2013; Ord. No. 834-A, § 5, 7-15-2013) 
Sec. 86-89. - Change of occupancy or land use. 
    At such times as a change of occupancy or land use occurs, the city shall have the right to review the new occupancy or land use and if, in the opinion of the city's public works department, a different type of backflow prevention assembly is required due to an increased possibility of a potential hazard to the health and safety of potable water users, the consumer shall be responsible for the installation of the new assembly. 
(Ord. No. 834, § 6, 1-7-2013; Ord. No. 834-A, § 6, 7-15-2013) 
Sec. 86-90. - Installation and location of backflow prevention assemblies. 
(a)  Backflow prevention assemblies shall be installed by properly licensed personnel. Installers shall consider potential pressure control issues caused by the location and installation of the backflow prevention assembly. 
(b)  Backflow prevention assemblies shall be installed at the property line on the service line for the property downstream of the meter discharge and upstream of any other connection. All assemblies shall have an inlet and outlet valve separate to the shut off of the water line being serviced. 
(c)  Alternate installation locations may be considered for existing connections to existing structures. All alternate installations must be downstream of the meter and upstream of any connection. 
(d)  All installation locations are subject to approval by the city's public works department. 
(e)  A double detector check valve assembly shall be used on all unmetered fire supply lines. 
(f)  A double check valve assembly may be used on metered fire lines and residential properties without an auxiliary water supply or irrigation system. 
(g)  A reduced pressure principle backflow prevention assembly shall be used on all nonresidential properties and all residential properties with an auxiliary water supply or irrigation system. Reduced pressure principle backflow prevention assemblies shall be installed 12 inches minimum above the ground or higher if the area is subject to flooding. All freeze control must be provided for the free flow from the relief of the assembly. 
(h)  A reduced pressure principle backflow prevention assembly shall be used on all irrigation systems with water supplied from the city's potable water system. 
(i)  All backflow prevention assemblies that automatically vent water shall have some means of controlling ground erosion caused by discharge of the assembly. 
(Ord. No. 834, § 7, 1-7-2013; Ord. No. 834-A, § 7, 7-15-2013) 
Sec. 86-91. - Inspections. 
(a)  The city shall be allowed access to perform inspections and make an operational test(s) on any premises where backflow prevention assemblies are installed. 
(b)  The city shall be allowed reasonable access to any property receiving water service from the city to perform inspections for cross connections within the property or to comply with any other regulatory requirement of law. 
(c)  The consumer is required to provide an inspection report of their backflow prevention assembly to the city at a frequency as follows. Inspections are to be performed by a certified backflow prevention assembly tester as defined herein. 
(1)  For high risk water users, the city's public works department will provide a notice to the consumer when an annual inspection of their backflow prevention assembly is becoming due. The notice will be mailed to the billing address on file for the water account. 
For low risk water users, the city's public works department will provide a notice to the consumer when a biennial (every two years) inspection of their backflow prevention assembly is becoming due. The notice will be mailed to the billing address on file for the water account. 
(2)  The consumer will be given a designated time limit from the date of the notice to have their backflow assembly inspected and repaired, as necessary, by a certified backflow prevention assembly repair specialist as defined herein. 
(d)  Where inspection or testing demonstrates a significant hazard to potable water users, the city's public works department may perform or require inspections and tests at intervals more frequently. 
(e)  Backflow prevention assemblies shall be repaired, overhauled, or replaced whenever such devices are found to be so defective as to present an increased likelihood of a potential hazard to the health and safety of potable water users. Records of such repairs, overhauls or replacements shall be submitted to the city's public works department. 
(f)  Any backflow prevention assembly which does not meet the requirements of this section but was an approved device for the purposes described herein at the time of installation and which has been properly maintained shall be inspected by the city's public works department as it deems appropriate. Such device shall not be subject to the requirements of this section so long as the city's public works department is assured such device will satisfactorily protect the public potable water supply system. Wherever the existing device is moved from the present location, or requires more than minimum maintenance, or constitutes a hazard to the health and safety of potable water users, the device shall be replaced by a backflow prevention assembly meeting the requirements of this section. 
(Ord. No. 834, § 8, 1-7-2013; Ord. No. 834-A, § 8, 7-15-2013) 
Sec. 86-92. - Enforcement. 
(a)  The city's public works department shall cause the water service to the premises to be immediately terminated for a cross connection until the consumer has corrected the condition in conformance with this ordinance in any of the following situations: 
(1)  When it becomes known that a condition such as a cross connection, plumbing, structural or health hazard, or other violation of this ordinance is present. 
(2)  In those cases of extreme emergency, and where an immediate threat to life or public health is found to exist. 
(b)  The city shall cause the water service to the premises to be terminated when the installation, testing, repairs, or replacement of backflow prevention assemblies or any other requirement within this ordinance is not performed in accordance with this ordinance. The city's public works department shall provide written notice specifying the requirements needed. 
(1)  First notice. The city's public works department will provide written notice and be given 30 days to comply with the requirements of this ordinance. 
(2)  Second notice. After the first 30 day notice period has expired, the city's public works department will provide a second written notice extending the compliance period an additional 15 days. 
(3)  Termination for noncompliance. If the consumer has not complied after the expiration of the second-notice period, the city's public works department shall terminate water service to the premises and service will not be restored until the deficiencies cited in the written notice are corrected. Termination of service is subject to the same charges for discontinuance of service for default payment of bill as established by Code. 
(Ord. No. 834, § 9, 1-7-2013; Ord. No. 834-A, § 9, 7-15-2013) 
Sec. 86-93. - Consumer responsibility. 
    It shall be the consumer's responsibility to prevent contaminants and pollutants from entering the public water supply system by means of a cross connection from his premises. All costs associated with testing, installation, repairs and maintenance of backflow prevention assemblies on his property is the sole responsibility of the consumer. 
(Ord. No. 834, § 10, 1-7-2013; Ord. No. 834-A, § 10, 7-15-2013) 
Secs. 86-94-86-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SEWERS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 86-101. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Sewage disposal system means and includes those facilities owned and operated by the city for the disposal of sanitary sewage and embracing all conduits, structures and appurtenances through which the sewage flows to the point of final disposition, including such purification and treatment facilities and works as may be provided during the course of such disposal. 
    Sewer system means the completed municipal sewer system, including any sanitary sewers and lateral sewer lines or other sewer facilities heretofore constructed or acquired by the city, together with any and all improvements, extensions and additions to the sewer system or any part thereof, hereafter constructed or acquired, and shall include, without being limited to, all lands or interest therein, plants, buildings, machinery, franchises, pipes, fixtures, equipment, and all property, real or personal, tangible or intangible, now or hereafter owned or used in connection with the sewer system. 
    Wastewater system shall have the same meaning as the term "sewer system" as defined in this section. 
(Code 1988, § 17-71) 
Sec. 86-102. - Structures for human habitation to be provided with water-carried sewerage when city sewer available; disposal requirements. 
(a)  No person shall build or remodel or cause to be built or remodeled any structure used for human habitation or occupancy within the city which is within 200 feet of a public sanitary sewer line, unless it is provided with water-carried sewerage facilities. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person owning or leasing any premises in the city to permit the disposal of any human excrement on any property, leased or rented by any such person or the agent of any such person except in a sanitary water closet where sewage lines are available. 
(Code 1988, § 17-72) 
Sec. 86-103. - Connection with sewer. 
(a)  Required if service available. The owner of each lot or parcel of land, upon which lot or parcel of land any building, or mobile home trailer used as a dwelling, is now situated or shall hereafter be situated, for either residential, commercial or industrial use, shall connect or cause such buildings, trailers or mobile homes to be connected with the public facilities of the municipal sewer system of the city and use such facilities within one year after notification by the city that the sewer system is available as defined in F.S. § 381.0065. All such connections shall be made in accordance with rules and regulations which may be adopted from time to time by the city council, which rules and regulations shall provide a charge for making such connections in such reasonable amount as the council may determine and fix by resolution. Since sewer rates are based on water consumption, connection to the city's water system shall be required at the same time as connection to the sewer system is required under this subsection if the city's water system is also available and if the lot or parcel of land is not already connected to another central water system. 
(b)  Upon failure of owner to comply connections may be made by city; procedure for recovering cost. If any such owner of any lot or parcel of land shall fail and refuse to connect with and use the facilities of the sewer system of the city after notification by the city, then the city shall be authorized to begin assessing monthly user fees or make such connections, entering on or upon any such lot or parcel of land for the purpose of making such connection. The city shall thereupon be entitled to recover the cost of making such connection, together with applicable installation and impact fees, reasonable penalties, interest and attorney's fees, by suit in any court of competent jurisdiction. In addition and as an alternative means of collecting the cost of making such connections, the city shall have a lien on such lot or parcel of land for the cost, which lien shall be of equal dignity with the lien of state, county and municipal taxes. Such lien may be foreclosed by the city in the same manner provided by state laws for the foreclosure of mortgages upon real estate. 
(c)  Use of septic tank restricted; discontinuance of use upon availability of city sewer. Every residence and building in which human beings reside, are employed or congregated shall be required to have an approved method of disposing of human excrement, namely either a sanitary water closet that is connected to the city sewer, or an approved type of septic tank. A septic tank may be used only if the sewer system is not available as defined in F.S. § 381.0065. When the sewer system becomes available, the use of any septic tank, cesspool or privy, privy vault, or any other similar private sewage disposal facility shall cease upon one year's notice from the city. 
(Code 1988, § 17-73; Ord. No. 651, § 5, 3-17-2003) 
Sec. 86-104. - When construction of septic tanks or any other private facility unlawful; state approval required. 
    Except where a sanitary sewer is not available as defined in F.S. § 381.0065, it shall be unlawful to construct or maintain any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool or any other private facility intended or used for the disposal of sewage. No septic tank other than those approved by the State of Florida shall be constructed within the corporate limits of the city. No septic tank shall be constructed within 200 feet of the sewer line. 
(Code 1988, § 17-74) 
State Law reference- Individual on-site sewage disposal systems, F.S. § 381.272. 
Sec. 86-105. - Application for service. 
    No person shall use the city's sewer system without first making written application for such service to the city at least three days, in the case of initial cut-in, before the service is desired, and paying all costs, charges, fees and deposit incident thereto. Such applications shall be on forms furnished by the city to abide by all provisions of this article and such applicable rules of the city in regard to the use of its sewer and sewage disposal systems as may from time to time be operative and effective. Applications for service by firms, partnerships, associations and corporations shall be tendered only by their duly authorized agents, and the official title of such parties shall be signed to the application. 
(Code 1988, § 17-75) 
Sec. 86-106. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 809, § 1, adopted July 19, 2010, deleted § 86-106, which pertained to deposit required and derived from Code 1988, § 17-76. 
Sec. 86-107. - Payment of sewer service installation fees prerequisite to issuance of building permits; schedule of charges. 
(a)  Upon payment to the city of sums required under the city's sewer extension policy, the city shall furnish all labor and materials to make sewer service available at the customer's property line. In addition, each applicant for sewer service, whether inside or outside the corporate limits of the city, shall pay to the city, prior to the issuance of a building permit, a sewer service installation fee. The city council shall, by resolution, fix the sewer service installation fee schedule required in this section. 
(b)  Commercial and industrial sewer service installations for larger than six-inch lateral shall be referred to the city manager or his designee, who will establish the service installation fee. 
(c)  Sewer service installation fees are for locating the sewer lateral and making the actual connection to the city sewer collection system and are a separate fee and in addition to any other fee levied by the city. Service installations to the city's sewer system shall be performed only by a licensed plumber or city personnel. The city reserves the right to stipulate whether sewer service laterals, and associated appurtenances, shall be installed by the city or owner. Should it be determined that installation by the owner would be more appropriate, then a contractual agreement will be executed to this effect and such fees as have been stipulated in this section for such installation shall be waived. 
(d)  Sewer service installation fees provided for in this section shall be reimposed in the event of the discontinuance of the water and sewer service account where such meter is located, where the water meter has been removed from the premises and the sewer lateral has been disconnected in some manner from the premises. 
(e)  An additional sewer service installation fee shall be imposed against any nonresidential facility or building, where the same is expanded, or otherwise increased in capacity, so that the existing sewer lateral facility is considered inadequate to accommodate such expansion or modification, as shall be determined by the city. 
(f)  Special area assessments will be processed by separate city council directive. 
(Code 1988, § 17-77) 
Sec. 86-108. - Permit required for unauthorized persons to enter sewers; connections to be made only by city personnel. 
(a)  No person, other than an authorized city employee, shall enter any public sewer or appurtenance thereof without a written permit from the city. 
(b)  No person, except those persons duly employed or authorized by the city for such purpose, shall tap or make any connections to the city's sewer mains. 
(c)  No person shall connect to or turn on any sewer service, or cut-in, interconnect, tap or make any alteration to any main or distribution or collection pipe of the city's sewer system, or permit any connection or tapping to be made to the city's sewer system on his premises or the premises occupied by him, or knowingly use city sewer service from connections in violation of any of the provisions of this article, or any rules or regulations adopted by the city council with respect thereto. 
(Code 1988, § 17-78) 
Sec. 86-109. - Inspection of plumbing required prior to tapping. 
    No sewer service shall be connected until the plumbing connections incident thereto shall have been inspected and approved by the city. 
(Code 1988, § 17-79) 
Sec. 86-110. - Granting easements to city; right of entry to city employees. 
    The applicant shall grant or cause to be granted to the city without cost all rights, easements, permits and privileges which are necessary for rendering of sewer service. Duly authorized employees of the city shall have access at all reasonable hours to the premises of the applicant for the purpose of installing or removing any of its property, examining pipes or fixtures, or for any purpose incidental to the rendering of sewer service. 
(Code 1988, § 17-80) 
Sec. 86-111. - Responsibility of owner to maintain pipes to sewer main free from obstructions; right of city to cut off water for noncompliance. 
(a)  The owner, tenant or occupant of the property shall be continuously responsible for maintaining and keeping the sewer pipes leading to and between the plumbing system of his premises to the city's sewer main clean and free from obstructions, and shall not cause, suffer nor permit any article or thing to be introduced into the pipe which causes a stoppage thereof. 
(b)  Failure to keep the sewer pipe, i.e., the pipe leading from the plumbing system to the city main, clean and maintained in a proper manner will give the city the right to cut off the water connection, which shall not be reconnected until the sewer pipe is cleaned and maintained properly. In those instances where the owner has his own private water supply, the city shall have the right to cut off such water supply to the plumbing system, and the owner shall have no right to reconnect his own private water supply until the sewer pipe leading from the plumbing system to the city main has been maintained and cleaned and is in proper condition. Any violation of this provision by reconnecting his private water supply or the connection from the city water line, until such sewer pipes are cleaned and maintained properly, shall be considered a violation of this article. 
(Code 1988, § 17-81) 
Sec. 86-112. - Disclaimer of liability by city for damages. 
(a)  The city shall not be liable for any damage resulting from the bursting of any sewer main, service pipe or cock, or by discontinuing the 
operation of its sewer collection, treatment and disposal facilities for repairs, extensions or connection, or from the accidental failure of the sewage collection treatment and disposal system from any cause whatsoever. 
(b)  In cases of emergency the city may restrict the use of its sewage collection, treatment and disposal system in any reasonable manner for the protection of the city and its sewage disposal system. 
(Code 1988, § 17-82) 
Secs. 86-113-86-130. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - DISCHARGES TO SANITARY SEWER SYSTEM 

Sec. 86-131. - General provisions. 
(a)  Where private water wells are used, disposal into the sanitary sewer system shall be done only by special agreement with the city and at rates for disposal to be fixed in the same manner as for industrial waste. 
(b)  No industrial waste shall be discharged into the city sewer system, the content of which shall have a deleterious effect upon the bacterial or biological processes of the sewage treatment works as determined by the city. Properly pretreated waste, with removal of objectionable material, may be discharged into the system. 
(c)  No stormwater drains, air conditioning waters, condenser waters, swimming pool waters, or other similar type waters shall be discharged into the sanitary sewer system, except by special agreement with the city. 
(d)  Wastes containing oils and gasoline from service stations, garages and similar industries shall not be discharged into the sanitary sewer system. Requirements of the state fire prevention code must be met. 
(e)  Sewers from restaurants or places where a large amount of cooking is done, or where the waste carries large amounts of grease, shall not be connected into the sewer system without providing and maintaining an efficient grease trap. 
(f)  The city shall have the final decision as to whether any waste may be discharged into the sanitary sewer system. 
(g)  Where monthly service charges are based upon the amount of the monthly water bill from the city, separate meters may be allowed at the expense of the customer for irrigation waters and an allowance may be made for water not entering the sanitary sewer system as waste. 
(Code 1988, § 17-96) 
Sec. 86-132. - Wastes and waters which are prohibited in sanitary sewer system. 
(a)  No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any stormwater, surface water, groundwater, roof runoff, or subsurface drainage to the sanitary sewer system. 
(b)  Except as provided in this division, no person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any of the following described waters or wastes to the sanitary sewer system: 
(1)  Any liquid or vapor having a temperature higher than 150 degrees Fahrenheit. 
(2)  Any waters or wastes that may contain more than 100 parts per million, by weight, of fat, oil or grease. 
(3)  Any gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil or other flammable or explosive liquid, solid or gas. 
(4)  Any garbage that has not been properly shredded to one-half inch or less. 
(5)  Any ashes, cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers, tar, plastics, wood, paunch manure or any other solid or viscous substance capable of causing obstruction to the flow in the sanitary sewers or other interference of the proper operation of the sanitary sewer system. 
(6)  Any waters or wastes having a pH lower than 6.5 or higher than 8.5 or having other corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to structures, equipment or personnel of the sanitary sewer system. 
(7)  Any waters or wastes containing deleterious, toxic or poisonous substances in sufficient quantity to injure or interfere with any sewage treatment process, to constitute a hazard to humans or animals, or to create any hazard in the receiving waters of the sanitary sewer system. 
(8)  Any noxious or malodorous gas or substance capable of creating a public nuisance. 
(9)  Any waters or wastes containing more than 350 parts per million of suspended solids. 
(Code 1988, § 17-97) 
Sec. 86-133. - City's right of refusal to accept certain wastes. 
    The city shall have the right to refuse to accept into the city sanitary system any of the wastes prohibited by the terms of this division or of any other chapter of this Code, or otherwise shown or determined to be detrimental to the city sanitary system or normal operation of the sanitary system, and upon a showing or determination shall upon 24 hours' previous notice served in writing upon the premises of the offending person or organization, corporate or otherwise, have the full right and authority to discontinue the acceptance of wastes or other materials into the city sanitary system of any kind or nature whatsoever from such an entity. 
(Code 1988, § 17-98) 
Sec. 86-134. - Preliminary treatment facilities; when required; maintenance. 
(a)  The admission into the sanitary sewer system of any waters or wastes containing any quantity of substances having the characteristics described in section 86-132(b) shall be subject to the review and the approval of the city. Where necessary, in the opinion of the city, the owner shall provide at his expense such preliminary treatment, including grease, sand and oil interceptors, as may be necessary to reduce objectionable characteristics of constituents to within the maximum limits provided in section 86-132(b) or control the quantities and rates of discharge of such waters and wastes. 
(b)  Plans and specifications, and any other pertinent information relating to proposed preliminary treatment facilities shall be submitted for the approval of the city, and except for grease, sand and oil interceptors, for the approval of the State of Florida and as necessity and requirement may dictate, and no construction of such facilities shall be commenced until approvals are obtained in writing. 
(c)  Where preliminary treatment facilities are provided for any waters or wastes, they shall be maintained continuously in satisfactory and effective operation, by the owner at his expense, or according to a special rate schedule duly adopted by the city council by resolution. 
(Code 1988, § 17-99) 
Sec. 86-135. - Control manhole or wet well for measurement of industrial wastes. 
    When required by the city, the owner of any property served by a building sewer carrying industrial wastes shall install a suitable control manhole or wet well in the building sewer to facilitate observation, sampling and measurement of the wastes. Such manhole or wet well, when required, shall be accessibly and safely located, and shall be constructed in accordance with plans approved by the city. The manhole or wet well shall be installed by the owner at his expense, and shall be maintained by him so as to be safe and accessible at all times. 
(Code 1988, § 17-100) 
Sec. 86-136. - Standards for measurements and analyses. 
    All measurements, tests, and analyses of the characteristics of waters and wastes to which reference is made in section 86-132(b) and section 86-134 shall be determined in accordance with the current requirements of the State of Florida and as necessity and requirement may dictate, and shall be determined at the control manhole or wet well provided for in section 86-135, or other suitable samples taken at the control manhole or wet well. If no special manhole or wet well has been required, the control manhole or wet well shall be considered to be the nearest downstream manhole or wet well in the sanitary sewer from the point at which the building sewer is connected. 
(Code 1988, § 17-101) 
Sec. 86-137. - Discharge of sanitary or industrial wastes in other than sanitary sewer system of city. 
    It shall be unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within the city any sanitary sewage, industrial wastes, or other polluted waters, and it shall be unlawful to place, deposit, or permit to be deposited in any insanitary manner upon any public or private property within the city any human or animal excrement, garbage or other obnoxious or objectionable wastes. 
(Code 1988, § 17-102) 
Secs. 86-138-86-160. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - EXTENSION OF SEWER SYSTEM OUTSIDE CITY 

Sec. 86-161. - Application. 
(a)  Whenever any person desires to secure service beyond the present limits of the city he shall make written application to the city stating the kind of service desired, the purpose for which such service is required, a definite description and a definite location of the property where such service is to be rendered, and other such information as will aid the city in determining the advantages to be derived from such service. The application shall be accompanied by a plat showing the route along which such lines are to be extended, and where the connection with the city's existing line is to be made, and in such application there shall also be stated the name of the person or the members of the firm, or the presiding officer of the corporation making such request for service, with the post office address of each. 
(b)  Such application will be made in a form acceptable to the city. 
(Code 1988, § 17-116) 
Sec. 86-162. - Consideration of application by; granting of easement. 
    All applications for service outside the city shall be carefully considered and examined, and if it is found that the service requested is feasible and it will be to the best interest of the city to grant such application, then before agreeing to such extension it shall be required that the applicant give easement of way for constructing and maintaining of the lines, and until such easement is granted to the city no service shall be allowed. 
(Code 1988, § 17-117) 
Secs. 86-163-86-180. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - SERVICE RATES, CHARGES AND BILLING 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 86-181. - No service free; disposition revenues. 
(a)  The city will not render or cause to be rendered any free services of any nature by its water and sewer system or any part thereof, to any person, whatsoever, nor will any preferential rates be established for users of the same class. If the city or any department, agency or instrumentality, officer or employee thereof, shall avail itself of the facilities or service provided by the water and sewer system or any part thereof, the same rates, fees or charges applicable to other customers receiving like services under similar circumstances shall be charged the city and any such department, agency, instrumentality, officer or employee. Such charges shall be paid as they accrue, and the city shall transfer from funds other than funds of the water and sewer system, sufficient monies to pay such charges. 
(b)  Revenues so received from the city for services and facilities furnished by the water and sewer system shall be deemed to be revenues derived from the operation of the water and sewer system, and shall be deposited and accounted for in the same manner as other revenues derived from the operation of the water and sewer system; provided, nothing contained in this section shall be construed as requiring the city to avail itself of the services and facilities afforded by the system. 
(Code 1988, § 17-126) 
Sec. 86-182. - Surcharge. 
    Those provisions stipulated and providing for an additional surcharge to those citizens and users of the utility systems located outside the corporate limits of the city, will remain in full force and effect with the adoption of this section in that citizens and users of the facilities will continue to be assessed an additional 25 percent surcharge above those amounts and rates which have been provided for corresponding levels of water and sewer services. 
(Code 1988, § 17-131) 
Sec. 86-183. - Collection of sewer fees where owner has private water supply. 
    Where sewage disposal fees are not paid in accordance with the provisions outlined in section 86-181, and in those instances where the owner has his own private water supply, the city shall have a right to cut off such water supply to the plumbing system and the owner shall have no right to reconnect his own private water supply until the sewage disposal fees shall have been paid in full. Any violation of this provision by reconnecting his private water supply, until such sewage disposal fees are paid in full, shall be considered a violation of this article. 
(Code 1988, § 17-133) 
Sec. 86-184. - Liability for charges. 
    Liability for sewer service charges shall begin on the date the user is connected to the city's sewer main in accordance with the provisions of this article and shall continue thereafter unless the user is disconnected for nonpayment or other cause or until written request is given to the city by the user to terminate the service. 
(Code 1988, § 17-134) 
Sec. 86-185. - Service charge for temporary discontinuance and reconnection of service. 
    There is fixed and established a service charge for the discontinuation of service to a customer. If for any reason a customer shall request a temporary discontinuance of service of the customer's residence or commercial establishment, the customer shall be charged a fee as fixed by the city council by resolution for the disconnection or reconnection of service. 
(Code 1988, § 17-135) 
Sec. 86-186. - When bills payable; penalty for delinquency; service subject to discontinuance. 
(a)  Bills for the monthly charges and fees mentioned in this article shall be payable on the 20th calendar day after the billing date and, if such monthly bill shall be and remain unpaid on or after the 20th calendar day after the billing date, a penalty of ten percent shall be imposed and be added to the bill, and, the service (water, sewer, irrigation water, and solid waste collection, if applicable) to the customer shall be subject to discontinuance and shall not be reconnected or resumed after discontinuance until all past due bills and fees are fully paid, together with the discontinuance and reconnection charge as provided in section 86-187. If the 20th calendar day after the billing date falls on a date in which the city is closed, the monthly charges and fees shall be payable on the next business day in which the city is open. 
(b)  Unless otherwise specified herein, monthly bills for charges and fees for water service, sewer service and solid waste collection shall be mailed, or transmitted electronically, to all utility account holders. Where water, sewer or solid waste collection services are furnished to a single account, all charges for said services shall be included on one bill rendered by the city; provided, however, that each such bill shall show water, sewer or solid waste collection charges and fees separately. A monthly bill for an amount less than an administratively determined minimum billable amount, which may be established by the city manager, shall not be required, and the balance due on any such account shall be added without penalty to the next billing. 
(Ord. No. 663-A, § 1(17-136), 5-3-2004; Ord. No. 809, § 2, 7-19-2010) 
Sec. 86-187. - Charge for discontinuance of service for default in payment of bill. 
    There is fixed and established a charge for discontinuance of service for default in payment of any bill. If a customer's service is discontinued for default in payment for any water, sewer or garbage charge levied by the city, the customer shall be charged a fee as fixed by the city council by resolution for the reconnection of service during normal working hours. If reconnection is requested before or after normal working hours from Monday through Friday, weekends or on a holiday, the customer shall be charged a fee as fixed by the city council by resolution. Service shall not be reconnected to any residence, or nonresidential, commercial or industrial establishment, until the default in question and the charge fixed and established by resolution are paid in full. 
(Code 1988, § 17-137) 
Secs. 86-188-86-210. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - DEPOSITS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 809, § 3, adopted July 19, 2010, amended the former Art. IV, Div. 2, §§ 86-211-86-221, and enacted a new Div. 2 as set out herein. The former Div. 2 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1988, §§ 17-151-17-161. 

Sec. 86-211. - Deposits required. 
(a)  The owner, tenant or occupant of each lot or parcel of land within the city, who may become obligated to pay for water, sewer or solid waste collection services, and from the customer applicant therefor, shall pay a deposit as established by the city council by resolution, as reasonable and equitable, to ensure payment of such water, sewer or solid waste collection fees and charges as the same become due and payable. Such deposits shall be posted with the finance department and a receipt obtained therefor before any such service is made to either city water, sewer or solid waste collection services. 
(b)  The city reserves the right to analyze a customer's account and payment record to determine the amount of deposit required, to ensure payment of any and all sums which may be or become due and owing to the city for such water, sewer or solid waste collection service. If additional deposits are required, such deposits shall be made in that additional amount to be determined in accordance with procedures established by city council and set forth by resolution. 
(c)  If an applicant for new or additional water, sewer or solid waste collection service is already served by one of the city's water, sewer or solid waste systems, the deposit required for the existing account shall be deemed sufficient, unless an additional deposit may be required pursuant to subsection (b). 
(Ord. No. 809, § 3, 7-19-2010) 
Sec. 86-212. - Receipt for deposit. 
    For each deposit a receipt shall be prepared and provided to the depositor and the city shall retain a record of such deposit. 
(Ord. No. 809, § 3, 7-19-2010) 
Sec. 86-213. - Credit to deposit fund; interest. 
    All deposits shall, upon receipt, be credited to the respective water, sewer or solid waste collection deposit fund and shall be held, in trust, until date of refund or until date of default, if any, in payment of bills. The accrued interest on any deposit shall be payable from the respective deposit fund upon date of refund of deposit, upon date of default, if any, in payment of bills, as authorized by the city manager, or as otherwise required by law. 
(Ord. No. 809, § 3, 7-19-2010) 
Sec. 86-214. - Refund of deposits. 
(a)  If all bills are promptly paid and no default shall occur, then such deposit shall be refunded in full to the depositor upon discontinuance of service at his or her request, together with accrued interest, if any; or 
(b)  If all bills are promptly paid and no default shall occur, the city may determine to issue a refund of such deposit for water, sewer or solid waste collection accounts that meet certain criteria. Said criteria shall be established and set forth by resolution of the city council. Refunds provided under this provision shall be credited to the eligible water, sewer or solid waste collection accounts. 
(Ord. No. 809, § 3, 7-19-2010) 
Sec. 86-215. - Procedure for refund. 
(a)  Upon demand for or authorization of refund of any deposit, and interest accrued thereon, and provided that there is at the time no outstanding bill or charge legally secured thereby, the finance department shall make such refund forthwith of both principal and interest. 
(b)  In all cases of refund, or partial refund after charging a deposit with sums due and secured thereby, or in case of complete exhaustion of any such deposit by reason of such charges, notation shall be made on the appropriate city records to the end that such copy may at all times show what charges, if any, have been made against it, and what refund, if any, has been made on account thereof. 
(Ord. No. 809, § 3, 7-19-2010) 
Sec. 86-216. - Requests to discontinue service; subsequent customers. 
(a)  In every case where a customer ceases to require water, sewer or solid waste collection service, whether by reason of ceasing to occupy the premises served or for any other reason, whether or not such customer shall have been required to post a deposit in accordance with the provisions of this division relating to deposits, such customer shall promptly notify the city and request that service be disconnected. 
(b)  In every case where such request for disconnection is not made as provided in this section, the regular charges for water, sewer or solid waste collection service will continue to be made against such customer and shall be collectible from him, including charges for water consumed, if any, through such service connection, whether such consumption is by such customer, or by any successor in occupancy, or otherwise, and whether such consumption is with the knowledge and consent of such customer or not. 
(c)  Notwithstanding the foregoing provisions of this section, but in addition thereto, each person, before beginning to use water or sewer service from any service connection or solid waste collection services, shall first comply with the provisions of section 86-211 even in those cases, if any, where he may find such service already on and available for use or being provided. 
(Ord. No. 809, § 3, 7-19-2010) 
Sec. 86-217. - Deposit required for water used in construction. 
    All contractors or builders shall post a minimum meter deposit for construction water. If the final water bill is greater than the amount of deposit, the bill must be paid in full before any further connections will be allowed. 
(Ord. No. 809, § 3, 7-19-2010) 
Sec. 86-218. - Transfer fee for meter deposits. 
    Any user of the city's solid waste collection, water or sewer system, whether residential or commercial, who wishes to transfer the deposit as required for such service, for any reason permitted by the city, shall be charged a transfer fee, which shall be fixed by the city council by resolution. 
(Ord. No. 809, § 3, 7-19-2010) 
Secs. 86-219-86-240. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - ADJUSTMENTS TO BILLS 

Sec. 86-241. - Adjustments to water and wastewater bills. 
    The city shall not be responsible for any loss of water from leaks or otherwise on the private property of a customer and shall be under no obligation to make adjustment for such leaks, except as provided herein. 
(Ord. No. 663, § 2(17-166), 2-2-2004) 
Sec. 86-242. - Adjustments for errors. 
    When a customer is determined by the city to have been overcharged or undercharged as a result of incorrect meter reading, defective metering, incorrect application of rate schedule fees and charges or mistake in billing, the amount so determined may be reimbursed, credited or billed to the customer as the case may be. The adjustment shall be accomplished over a period not to exceed 90 days, unless otherwise directed by the city manager or the city manager's designee and such direction is so noted on the account. The city shall read and inspect meters periodically to determine their condition and accuracy and as a basis for periodic billings. If a customer requests more than two inspections of a meter within a six-month period, the city shall impose a service charge therefor in the amount of $25.00. 
(Ord. No. 663, § 2(17-167), 2-2-2004) 
Sec. 86-243. - Adjustments for unique circumstances. 
    The city, through the city manager or the city manager's designee, shall provide a reimbursement, credit or adjustment to a customer's water or wastewater bill, or both, for the following limited circumstances: 
(1)  Filling and refilling of a residential swimming pool. To qualify for this adjustment, for wastewater only, the customer must either provide the city with construction plans that will enable the city to determine the pool volume or allow the city to measure the pool. 
(2)  Extraordinary circumstances outside of the customer's control, including acts of God, natural disasters, and similar matters, provided the customer is not directly at fault, as determined by the city. 
(3)  Line breaks. The city manager or the city manager's designee may approve reducing a customer's bill by providing a credit for wastewater for line breaks that occur on the owner's side of the meter, provided that repair of the break occurs within 30 days of the date of the owner's discovery of the leak. Actual reimbursement, credit or adjustment may be delayed while the city verifies the facts. In order to be eligible for a credit, for wastewater only, the customer must timely provide to the city's customer service department: 
a.  A letter requesting the credit, describing the location, time and date of discovery of the leak and subsequent repair. 
b.  A copy of the invoice for repair of the break or, if the homeowner repairs the break, a copy of all receipts for the purchase of materials, or other acceptable evidence of repair, and certification by the water and sewer superintendent that the water did not enter the wastewater system. 
(Ord. No. 663, § 2(17-168), 2-2-2004) 
Secs. 86-244-86-270. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - CONNECTION AND SERVICE OF WATER AND SANITARY SEWER FACILITIES OF CITY 

Sec. 86-271. - Purpose. 
(a)  The purpose of this article is to establish procedures and policies for obtaining water or sanitary sewer service from the city in its service area, the payment of impact fees and the issuance of commitments for the services requested. 
(b)  For the purposes of this article, the service area of the city shall be defined as all real property within the corporate limits of the city, and all real property in an unincorporated area or zone adjacent to the existing city limits, which unincorporated area or zone shall not extend more than five miles from the corporate limits of the city, all in accordance with F.S. § 180.02 and the city's comprehensive plan, and more specifically described as all the lands lying within the City of Brooksville Service Area, as on file in the city clerk's office. 
(Code 1988, § 17-177) 
Editor's note- The service area described in section 86-271 above was adopted by Ordinance No. 353 on March 19, 1984. 
Sec. 86-272. - Administration. 
    This article shall be administered by the city public works department under the supervision of the city manager. 
(Code 1988, § 17-178) 
Sec. 86-273. - Jurisdiction. 
    This article shall apply to all real property within the city's service area, as defined in this article, unless the city consents to allow the county or franchise service areas to provide such service under such terms and conditions as the city may set forth. 
(Code 1988, § 17-179) 
Sec. 86-274. - Service of utilities to customers outside of the city limits. 
    The city council shall have the power to supply water, sanitary sewer, electricity or gas, for domestic or other purposes, or the products of any other city-owned public utility services, to individuals, firms or corporations outside the city limits, and to charge and collect reasonable rates, prices and compensation therefor. 
(Code 1988, § 17-180) 
Sec. 86-275. - Availability of service.
