(a)  A franchise application to construct privately owned and operated facilities, within the unincorporated service area, as defined by F.S. § 180.02, shall be submitted to the city. If service cannot be provided by the city or the county, or by an existing franchise previously approved by either governing entity, then such ownership of the system shall be governed by city ordinance. 
(b)  The city will, within 60 days of receipt of the franchise application, review the franchise application and advise the franchise applicant of such terms and conditions as will be required for the issuance of a franchise agreement. This report will be returned within 60 days, unless extended by action of the city council or request of the petitioning franchise applicant. 
(c)  Where it is deemed beneficial to the applicant and the city, an agreement may be entered into for the construction and dedication of the facility by the applicant to the city, in lieu of issuance of a franchise. 
(d)  The availability of service for all applicants shall be determined as follows: 
(1)  Upon receipt of an application for water or sanitary sewer service, the public works department will locate and stipulate the most appropriate point of connection to the city's water and sanitary facilities. 
(2)  The public works department will then make a determination as to whether or not line extensions, if required, will be installed by the city or the applicant. If it is determined that the city will install the necessary line extensions, an estimate will be made as to the appropriate cost which shall be incurred, and the applicant will be assessed such costs prior to any such installation of improvements on the part of the city. If the applicant is required to install the necessary line extensions, all expenses associated with such installation shall be borne entirely by the applicant provided the city has not required oversizing of the improvements greater than the city's minimum pipe size, in which case the provisions of section 86-285 shall then apply. 
(3)  Based on the costs which shall be incurred in providing the requested service, and contingent upon agreement by the applicant to fund such costs, the determination as to availability of water and/or sanitary sewer service shall then be made by the public works department. 
(Code 1988, § 17-181) 
Sec. 86-276. - Requests for service-Generally. 
(a)  No person shall divide real property, or construct any residential, commercial or industrial building, within the service area, as described in this article, without first requesting water and sanitary sewer service from the city. In the unincorporated portion of the service area, requests for service will not be required for a single-family residence, and single-building construction, utilizing individual private wells or septic tanks; provided preliminary plat approval has been obtained from the proper jurisdiction having authority over the approval of preliminary or record plats; and further provided that the use of private wells or septic tanks has the approval of applicable county, state and federal agencies. 
(b)  All requests for service shall be made by submitting a formal application for water or sanitary sewer service to the city. The initial application will be reviewed by the public works director to determine the feasibility of, and the requirements for, providing service. 
(c)  No connection to the city's utility system shall be made without prior approval of the public works director or his designee. 
(Code 1988, § 17-182) 
Sec. 86-277. - Same-Forms. 
(a)  All applicants for service in the service area described in this article shall complete the city form, "Application for Water or Sanitary Sewer Service," and submit same to the city. 
(b)  All applications for single-family, or multifamily developments with more than two living units in such developments, and all commercial and industrial establishments shall be certified by a registered professional engineer as to the water and sanitary sewer average and maximum daily flow expectations, unless such requirement shall be waived by the public works department. 
(Code 1988, § 17-184) 
Sec. 86-278. - Review of applications. 
(a)  Preliminary review. The application for water or sanitary sewer service will be reviewed and evaluated as to the feasibility of providing service, with a written response issued to the applicant within two weeks of receipt of the application indicating the availability, or unavailability of service, or requesting additional information. Upon receipt of the preliminary review, or if no written response is issued within two weeks of receipt of the application, then the applicant shall request a final review in writing. 
(b)  Final review. Within two weeks of receipt of request for final review, and the furnishing of all additional information requested, the public works department shall advise the applicant in the appropriate sections of the form "application for water or sanitary sewer service" as to the impact fees, point of connection, and any other pertinent information. All applications for water or sanitary sewer service, other than for one single-family residential unit, will be formally approved by the execution of a utility service agreement in a format and with stipulations as shall be determined by the public works department. Such utility service agreement may be executed on the part of the city by the city manager. 
(Code 1988, § 17-185) 
Sec. 86-279. - Vesting title to extended lines in city. 
(a)  Before allowing or agreeing to any extension of the water or sanitary sewer system, the public works department shall approve a route to be adopted for such extension, and shall require the applicant to procure and deliver to the city deeds conveying an easement of way over the entire route proposed for the constructing and maintenance of such extension. 
(b)  As a condition of service, upon completion and start-up of such extension and after a minimum of a one-year warranty period, the applicant shall transfer and assign the same to the city by a deed of conveyance or through a utility service agreement, vesting title to such lines the city has agreed to accept. 
(Code 1988, § 17-186) 
Sec. 86-280. - Construction costs for water and sanitary sewer line extensions. 
    Water and sanitary sewer line extension costs shall be borne by the person applying for such service unless the city has agreed to participate in a portion of the costs as provided for by section 86-289. 
(Code 1988, § 17-187) 
Sec. 86-281. - Impact fees. 
(a)  Impact fees shall be uniform and based upon current or projected expansion costs of potable water supply facilities or sanitary sewer facilities. Impact fees for all single-family residential units shall be assessed on an equivalent residential unit (ERU) basis. Multifamily, apartments and mobile or modular homes in a park will be assessed at 64 percent of the ERU rate. The above residential rates are predicated on the basis that an ERU contains 24 water supply fixture units and 24 drainage fixture units. For the purpose of calculating flows, an ERU is considered 250 gallons per day for water and 200 gallons per day for sanitary sewer. The city has the authority to recalculate and determine the appropriate impact fee should a conflict occur between the number of fixture units attributable to the connection and the actual water demand or sewage generation expected. The city shall then have the authority to assess all connections according to that number of water supply or drainage fixture units or average daily flow that the city determines most accurately represents the expected water demand or sewage generation from the connection being assessed. In no case will the assessed value for water and sanitary sewer impact fees be less than one ERU per living or commercial unit with the exception of multifamily and mobile or modular homes in a park as has been stipulated hereinabove. Mobile or modular homes located outside of a park and on individual lots will be assessed the same as single-family units. Where existing structures are being renovated or modified, an additional impact fee may be assessed, according to the provisions stipulated hereinabove, should plans for such renovation or modification reveal additional water supply or sanitary sewer demand greater than that presently being served. 
(b)  Water and sanitary sewer installation charges are not included in the impact fee described in subsection (a) of this section and shall be paid directly to the city at the time actual service is requested for each hook-up. 
(c)  Impact fee rates shall be fixed by the city council by resolution. 
(Code 1988, § 17-188) 
Sec. 86-282. - Point of connection; generally. 
    The point of connection of the water or sanitary sewer facilities shall be where the city deems its system adequate to provide service. 
(Code 1988, § 17-189) 
Sec. 86-283. - Construction of water or sanitary sewer extensions. 
(a)  Construction by applicant. Upon request by the applicant and approval by the public works department, the applicant may engage an engineer to design and construct the required line extension. Design, construction and connection to the city's utility system shall be at the applicant's expense and shall be approved by the public works department in accordance with the appropriate policy, standards and specifications of the city. 
(b)  Construction by city. Upon request by the applicant, the city will cause to be constructed the necessary line extensions to the project. Upon receipt of such request, the city will advise the applicant of the estimated construction cost (including engineering, legal and administrative costs) and the estimated time of completion. The estimated design, legal and administrative costs will be paid to the city with the application. Payment of estimated construction costs will be required prior to initiating construction. Adjustment to be paid the city, or refunded to the applicant, will be made based upon final construction costs. 
(c)  Determination by city. The city shall determine which entity shall design and construct the line extension. 
(Code 1988, § 17-190) 
Sec. 86-284. - Designation of connection point. 
    Point of connection for all residential, industrial and commercial units shall be made by the property owner as designated by the public works director, unless specified exceptions are agreed upon by the city prior to issuance of building permits. 
(Code 1988, § 17-191) 
Sec. 86-285. - Oversizing of water or sanitary sewer extensions. 
    Where the city requires the oversizing of the extensions greater than the minimum city design standards, the applicant shall be so advised. All construction costs associated with oversizing the extension shall be borne by the city. On extensions by the applicant, the cost of oversizing shall be applied against impact fees. All costs for oversizing in excess of impact fees shall be borne by the city. Cost of oversizing shall be based upon the installed cost of the oversized extensions, less the city's approved estimated cost of the extension, sized in accordance with this article. 
(Code 1988, § 17-192) 
Sec. 86-286. - Line extensions by special assessment. 
(a)  Where water or sanitary sewer service is requested by individual property owners, either residential or commercial, in areas adjacent to existing city facilities having adequate capacity, involving potential future customers in addition to those requesting service, the city public works department will determine the feasibility of constructing the necessary line extensions, with payment to be by contract or special assessment, or other applicable provisions of law. Assessment of line extension costs shall be on a proportionate basis, in accordance with the front footage or anticipated flow associated with each property. All special assessments shall be approved by the city council at a properly advertised public hearing. Any assessments may be paid at the offices of the county tax collector within 30 days after the confirmation thereof, without interest. Thereafter, all assessments shall be payable in equal annual installments, with interest at the rate of ten percent per annum from the expiration of the 30 days, in each of the succeeding number of years for which the assessment will be payable as determined by resolution at the time in each year at which the general city/county taxes are payable; provided that the council may, by resolution, fix a shorter period of payment for any assessment or adjust the interest rate so as to preserve the interest rate on the principal amount of the assessment at or within one percent of the prime lending rate on the interest rate, not to exceed what is authorized by state statutes; further provided that any assessment may be paid at any time before due, together with interest accrued thereon to the date of payment. 
(b)  Impact fees associated with this type of service request will be required as stipulated in this article. Impact fee payment shall be made prior to connection to the facilities, or if requested by the applicant, and approved by the city council, may be included in the special assessment as outlined in subsection (a) of this section. 
(Code 1988, § 17-193) 
Sec. 86-287. - Service commitments. 
(a)  Acceptance of final review. Within 90 days of receipt of the final review, setting forth the impact fees, point of connection and extension requirements, the applicant for water or sanitary sewer service shall advise the city of the acceptance of the city's proposal. 
(b)  Development schedule. Along with the acceptance of the proposal, the applicant shall provide to the city public works department an estimated schedule of development, with the schedule showing the estimated number of units to be constructed yearly until completion. 
(c)  Formal commitment. Within two weeks after receipt of the applicant's notification of acceptance and development schedule, the city council shall cause a formal commitment letter to be issued. The commitment letter shall bind the city to provide services to the applicant, subject to receipt of impact fees payment. Commitments are nontransferable from one property to another, but commitments are transferable to a new owner of the same property. 
(d)  Expiration of commitment. Commitments shall expire four years after issuance of the formal commitment for projects involving lump sum payment. Commitments shall expire at the end of the last year indicated on the applicant's development schedule for projects involving incremental payment of impact fees. Commitments and proof of payment will be honored for any initial building permit issued by the county and/or the city. 
(e)  Time extensions to commitment or previous agreements. 
(1)  Time extensions to written agreements may be granted for periods not to exceed two years provided that capacity within the water or sanitary sewer system remains available and that a request is submitted in writing prior to 30 days before the expiration of the agreements. 
(2)  Service agreements or commitment contracts entered into prior to the effective date of this article, by which the city agreed to accept advanced impact fees and reserve capacity at its water or sanitary sewer treatment facilities, and by which the developer agreed to connect a certain number of units to the city facilities in accordance with an agreed upon schedule, may be granted two-year time extensions in accordance with subsection (e)(1) of this section. 
(Code 1988, § 17-194) 
Sec. 86-288. - Impact fee payments. 
(a)  Impact fee payment schedule, lump sum. Fees shall be paid either as a lump sum or in increments as provided for in this section. Impact fees shall be paid in full prior to the issuance of a building or remodeling permit, unless a specific incremental payment structure has been provided for by a utility service agreement. 
(b)  Incremental payments, other than single-family subdivisions. Upon execution of a utility service agreement, the applicant shall pay a minimum down payment equal to 50 percent of the total impact fee. However, if the city does not have the capacity to serve the applicant without expending public funds for new facilities, the entire impact fee must be paid upon execution of the utility service agreement. If a partial payment is allowed, the remaining balance may be paid by one of the following methods which will be incorporated into the utility service agreement. The applicant must provide an irrevocable letter of credit, surety bond or other instrument acceptable to the city, to guarantee payment of all fees to the city. 
(1)  If the remaining balance is $5,000.00 or less, it may be paid in two equal installments, with the first payment, along with a processing fee of $25.00, being made not later than 180 days after the initial payment on execution of the utility service agreement, and the last payment, along with a processing fee of $25.00, 360 days after the initial payment. 
(2)  If the remaining balance exceeds $5,000.00, it may be paid in four equal annual installments. Payments shall be made on the annual anniversary date of the execution of the utility service agreement, along with a processing fee of $25.00 per payment and interest at the rate of 18 percent per year on the unpaid balance. The applicant may pay the remaining balance, with interest prorated to date, at any time. 
(c)  Incremental payments, single-family subdivisions. Upon execution of a utility service agreement, the applicant shall pay a minimum of 20 percent of the total impact fee. However, if the city does not have the capacity to serve the applicant without expending public funds for new facilities, the entire impact fee must be paid upon execution of the utility service agreement. If a partial payment is allowed, the remaining amount may be paid on a per house basis as building permits are issued during the first 12 months, along with a processing fee of $25.00 for each payment, after receipt of the initial payment. An additional payment equal to 20 percent of the original balance shall be paid 12 months and one day after the execution of the utility service agreement. The remaining balance may be paid by one of the following methods which are deemed to be incorporated in the utility service agreement: 
(1)  If the remaining balance is $5,000.00 or less, the entire balance may be paid in full or it may be paid along with a processing fee of $25.00, 24 months and one day after execution of the utility service agreement. 
(2)  If the remaining balance exceeds $5,000.00, the total may be paid in full, or in four equal annual installments. If the balance is to be paid in installments, each payment shall be made on the annual anniversary date of the execution of the utility service agreement, along with a processing fee of $25.00 per payment and interest at the rate of 18 percent per year on the unpaid balance. The applicant may pay the remaining balance, with interest prorated to date, at any time. 
(3)  If fees are collected in excess of the total amount due, the city will return to the applicant any collections above the total amount due at such time as all lots are developed or all fees paid. 
(d)  Incremental payments-Alternative method for single-family subdivisions larger than 20 acres and for 50 or more dwelling units. For single-family subdivisions larger than 20 acres and for 50 or more dwellings units, an alternative method of making incremental payments may be used if incorporated into the utility service agreement. Upon execution of the utility service agreement, the applicant shall pay 20 percent of the total connection fees due. Thereafter, connection fees at the then current rate will be paid as each building permit is issued for construction within the development. The original 20 percent payment will remain on deposit with the city until applied or returned as provided herein. At any time that the amount on deposit is equal to or exceeds the connection fees due, at the then current rate, for the remaining development to be constructed in the subdivision, the deposit shall, at the request of the developer, be applied to make such payments and the remainder, if any, shall be refunded to the developer. If connection fees are not paid for all of the development in the subdivision within four years after the date of execution of the utility service agreement, any remaining deposit shall be applied, at the then current rate, to the payment thereof, and all unpaid connection fees for the remaining development shall become due and payable at the then current rate. Until such connection fees for the remaining development are paid, with interest at the rate of one and one-half percent per month from the four-year anniversary date of the utility service agreement, no utility service will be provided for any further construction in the subdivision. 
(e)  Expiration and refunds. Pursuant to this article, commitments on the part of the city to provide service will expire four years after final execution of the utility service agreement if construction has not commenced on the project by that date. After four years from execution of the utility service agreement, the city's commitment to provide service shall expire, as to any uncompleted portion of the project, if the development permit or building permit for the project is revoked or lapses. If the city commitment expires pursuant to this subsection, 50 percent of all impact fees paid for the uncompleted portion of the project, less processing charges and other expenses incurred by the city in contemplation of providing services to the project, shall be refunded to the applicant. 
(f)  Payment when connection of existing buildings is required. When connection of any existing building to the city's water or sewer system, or both, is required pursuant to section 86-41 or section 86-103, the impact fees for such building required to be paid under this article may be paid in five annual installments, the first being due one year after the required connection is made and the remaining installments being due on the same date of the next ensuing four years. Provided all such payments are timely made, no interest shall be owed on the installment payments. However, if any payment is not timely made, the owner of the lot or parcel for which the impact fees are due shall be obligated to also pay interest, at the rate of ten percent per annum on the entire impact fee or balance thereof until the entire amount is paid. 
(Code 1988, § 17-195; Ord. No. 638, § 1, 6-17-2002; Ord. No. 651, § 1(17-195), 3-17-2003; Ord. No. 653, § 2, 4-7-2003; Ord. No. 651-A, § 1, 1-23-2006) 
Sec. 86-289. - Impact fee/credit for construction costs. 
(a)  Upon application by a developer, up to 100 percent of water or sewer impact fees paid to the city may be applied against the cost of water or sewer line improvements made by the developer in excess of 300 feet, excluding extensions adjacent to property owned by the developer or located within the physical boundaries of the development, provided the pipe size is 12 inches in diameter or larger for water lines or gravity sewer lines, or eight inches in diameter or larger for sewer force mains, and provided at the time of approval the expenditure of the impact fees has not been previously committed to another developer pursuant to subsection (b) of this section. 
(b)  If the proposed water or sewer line extension route is conducive to future connections and the length of the extension is greater than 300 feet, excluding extensions adjacent to property owned by the developer or located within the physical boundaries of the development, the city may also offset the developer's off-site costs by contributing up to 50 percent of certain future water or sewer impact fees collected by the city. This payback provision applies only to direct connections made to the off-site water line extension within ten years of completion of the original extension. Connections of properties beyond the end of the water line extension are not subject to this payback provision. 
(c)  The total impact fee refund under this section shall not exceed: 
(1)  The actual amount paid by the developer for the off-site extension costs, including the cost of necessary off-site easements, minus any oversizing contributions paid by the city; or 
(2)  The total impact fees paid by the applicant. 
(d)  The city shall determine required line sizes. When the city has required the oversizing of lines or the installation of additional facilities in order to serve potential future developments or customers, the reasonable cost for such requirement may be reimbursed to the developer, after completion of the extension and connection to the city's system, through a refund of all or part of the impact fees paid to the city by the developer or through the payment to the developer of impact fees paid to the city by subsequent developers or customers connecting in the future to such extension, or by a combination of such refunds and payments. 
(e)  Where the city has agreed to participate in the off-site line construction extension costs through the payment to the developer of future impact fees relating to connections to such line extension by subsequent developers or customers, impact fees from such subsequent developers or customers shall be payable at the time of their application for service or at the time of their execution of a utility service agreement. Such fees will be first applied to any pre-existing applicable payback agreement before any repayment of a portion of any subsequent developer's line extension costs by the city. 
(f)  Line extension agreements will be reviewed and any refund payments due to developers from the city will be made annually. 
(Code 1988, § 17-196; Ord. No. 651, § 1(17-196), 3-17-2003) 
Sec. 86-290. - Impact fee revisions. 
    Any changes in regard to impact fees listed in this article shall be fixed by the city council by resolution at a properly advertised public meeting. Revised impact fees shall apply to commitments then in effect as follows: 
(1)  Commitments or agreements involving impact fees fully paid under the lump sum payment method or by construction cost refunds shall not be affected by the revised fee schedule until expiration of the commitment or agreement. If a time extension is granted upon expiration of the commitment or agreement, the new fees shall apply for all units in which building permits or hook-up of meters have not been issued. The applicant shall have the option of either paying the difference in impact fees for each connection made after expiration of the original commitment or agreement prior to issuance of a building permit or hook-up, or having the remaining unused impact fee balance applied toward a revised number of prepaid connections. 
(2)  Commitments or agreements involving impact fees paid under the incremental payment method shall be revised in the following manner: 
a.  Down payments shall be applied in the same manner as lump sum payments described in subsection (1) of this section. 
b.  Upon full utilization of the lump sum payment, impact fees for remaining units shall be based upon the impact fees in effect at the time application is made for a hook-up or building permit. 
(Code 1988, § 17-197) 
Sec. 86-291. - Impact fee expenditures. 
(a)  All impact fees will be accounted for separately, one each for water and sanitary sewer. These funds shall be known and designated as the city water impact fee account and the city wastewater impact fee account unless otherwise required by the provisions of debt instruments, in which event the requirements of such instruments will apply. The city manager is authorized and directed to establish these accounts. All interest earned by investments of monies in each account will be deposited in the same account. 
(b)  The use of monies in each account is restricted to payment of engineering, construction and associated costs for new facilities built to provide additional capacity, replacing that utilized capacity for which the impact fee was collected, or to serve additional customers. These monies can also be used to pay debt service on financing obtained to expand facilities and provide service capacity for new connections. These funds cannot be used for operating or maintenance expenses, or debt service paying the cost of capacity utilized by existing customers. The term "capacity" shall mean and include the total capacity of the system, including wells, pumps, treatment plants, supply lines, collection lines, disposal system and all appurtenances thereto. 
(Code 1988, § 17-198) 
Sec. 86-292. - Franchise impact fee extended payment plan. 
    When franchise holders serving single-family residences, apartments, mobile or modular homes, multifamily and commercial establishments, are required by the city or other regulatory agencies to connect such facilities to the city's water or sanitary sewer systems, the impact fee required by section 86-281 may be paid as a lump sum in accordance with section 86-288 or, if approved by the city council, on an extended payment plan. The extended payment plan shall require a down payment equal to five percent of the impact fee. The remainder shall be payable in equal monthly installments at an interest rate of ten percent per annum over a period of time not to exceed ten years. The city council may, however, set the period of assessment to a shorter or longer period at its discretion and may also adjust the interest rate so as to preserve the interest rate on the principal amount of the assessment at or within one percent of the prime lending rate, not to exceed what is authorized by state statutes. It is further provided that any assessment due under the provisions of this section may be paid at any time before due, together with the interest accrued thereon to date of payment. Monthly installments shall be billed and paid separately along with the monthly water or sanitary sewer service bills from the city. 
(Code 1988, § 17-199) 
Sec. 86-293. - Impact fee refunds. 
(a)  Requests for impact fee refunds will be considered if submitted in writing prior to 30 days before expiration of commitment or agreement. 
(b)  Upon receipt of a written request for an impact fee refund and termination of service commitment, the public works director will determine and advise the applicant within 30 days as to the amount of the refund. Any costs expended by the city related in any way to the service request in question, including, but not limited to, engineering and construction, shall be deducted from the prepaid impact fee, as part of determining the amount of the refund. Refunds shall be made within 90 days of the original request. 
(c)  If a force majeure or an act of a state or federal government regulatory agency prohibits the city from connecting the applicant to the water or sanitary sewer system, the city agrees to refund all impact fees paid. 
(d)  Impact fees previously committed by agreement to cover line extension costs or payback provisions are not refundable. 
(Code 1988, § 17-200) 
Sec. 86-294. - Impact fee credits, variance to terms of article, by city council agreement. 
    The city council may, by agreements with property owners: 
(1)  Approve impact fee credits for current or future development of such owners' properties in return for the donation of necessary utility easements or necessary utility facilities or improvements; or 
(2)  Vary the terms of this article as they relate to impact fee credits and payment schedules, for proposed developments over 20 acres in size, in consideration of the size of the proposed development, the locations of water and sewer improvements to be constructed by the developer, any regional benefits from such improvements or from any donations by the developer of utility easements or facilities, and future accessibility of such improvements and facilities. 
(Ord. No. 651, § 2(17-201), 3-17-2003) 
Sec. 86-295. - Design and construction standards. 
(a)  General. Design and construction standards shall be in accordance with existing city policies standards and specifications in effect at the time plans and specifications are submitted for review. 
(b)  Sanitary sewer system. Sanitary sewer system design, pipe and manhole layout shall conform to the recommendations contained in the publication "Recommended Standards for Wastewater Facilities," 1990, Health Education Services, Albany, N.Y. Gravity lines shall be sized for peak demands and shall be minimum eight-inch pipe size with manholes at every bend, end of line and every 400 feet. Force mains shall be minimum six-inch pipe size. Lines shall be installed in road rights-of-way or easements as approved by the public works department. 
(c)  Water system. Water system design, pipe and valve layout shall conform to the requirements and recommendations contained in the publication by the American Water Works Association, Manual of Practice M-31, first edition. Water lines shall be sized to supply peak demands including fire flows and not exceed five feet per second pipe velocity. Minimum water line size for systems supplying fire flows shall be eight-inch pipe. Previously developed areas located outside the city's corporate limits may be exempted from this minimum line size requirement by the public works department on a case by case basis. The minimum line size for systems not supplying fire flows shall be two-inch pipe. Lines shall be installed in road rights-of-way. 
(Code 1988, § 17-201; Ord. No. 651, § 2(17-202), 3-17-2003) 
Chapters 87-89 - RESERVED 
Chapter 90 - WATER RESOURCES[1]
